cars travelling in opposite direction - same velocity?
question.questiontext: Neil is driving his car from Glace Bay to Sydney at 80 km/hr. Heather passes him going in the opposite direction, also going at 80 km/hr. Choose the statement that most correctly describes the situation.

answer.answertext: Neil's and Heather's speeds are the same but their velocities are different.
Neil's and Heather's velocities and speeds are the same.
Neil's and Heather's velocities and speeds are different.
Neil's and Heather's speeds are different but their velocities are the same.

question.name: Which are accelerating?
question.questiontext:
Which of the following descriptions describe an object that is accelerating?

a) A jet is speeding up as it takes off.

b) A car with its brakes on comes rapidly to a stop.

c) You turn a corner, coasting at constant speed, on your bike.

multichoice.correctfeedback: Acceleration (to a physicist) refers to any change in velocity. This can be a change (increase or decrease) in the magnitude of velocity (speed). It could also be a change in the direction of the velocity. So the answer is all of a), b) and c) (in c direction of the velocity is changing).

question.name: Average velocity definition (r) - broken temporarily?
question.questiontext: The correct definition of average velocity is

answer.feedback: r here is indicated as a scalar (not in bold face and without vector symbols over it). If the v on the left side of the equation were indicated as a scalar then this would be a correct definition of average speed, but not average velocity.
This answer is not dimensionally correct. It has dimensions LT.
This answer is not dimensionally correct. It has dimensions T/L. Also, dividing by a vector has no defined meaning.
v and r here are indicated as scalars (they are not in bold face and do not have vector symbols over them). So this is a correct definition of average speed, not average velocity.

question.questiontext: The correct definition of average velocity is

answer.feedback: x here is indicated as a scalar (not in bold face and without vector symbols over it). If the v on the left side of the equation were indicated as a scalar then this would be a correct definition of average speed, but not average velocity.
This answer is not dimensionally correct. It has dimensions LT.
This answer is not dimensionally correct. It has dimensions T/L. Also, dividing by a vector has no defined meaning.
v and x here are indicated as scalars (they are not in bold face and do not have vector symbols over them). So this is a correct definition of average speed, not average velocity.

question.name: Average velocity definition (x) - no vectors (BROKEN)
question.questiontext: The correct definition of velocity is

answer.feedback: x normally represents a position. But velocity is change in position (displacement) per unit time. The bottom of the fraction must be the change in time that the displacement takes place over, not just a time.
This answer is not dimensionally correct. It has dimensions length X time.
This answer is not dimensionally correct. It has dimensions time/length.
The answer is not dimensionally correct (length/time squared). It has the dimensions of an acceleration.

question_category.name: Measurements and Errors
question_category.info: questions for unit 1 including: sig. figs. representing quantities with errors agreement of values

question.name: Choose the correct equation (1)
question.questiontext: A firefighter is sliding down a fire pole. While sliding she is undergoing a constant downward acceleration. The fire pole is 4.0 m tall. She starts from rest (i.e. her initial speed is zero) and she hits the floor going at 2.0 m/s. To find the firefighter's acceleration from the information given, which of the following equations would you need to use?

answer.feedback: This equation contains $$a$$ which is the quantity we are trying to solve for. Unfortunately, it also contains $$\Delta t$$ which we don't know. So this gives us one equation in two unknowns, which we can't solve.

This equation contains $$a$$ which is the quantity we are trying to solve for. Unfortunately, it also contains $$\Delta t$$ which we don't know. So this gives us one equation in two unknowns, which we can't solve.
Yes, this equation contains $$a$$ which is what we want to know. It also contains $$\Delta x$$, $$v_f$$ and $$v_i$$ all of which we know. So we can solve for what we are looking for.

answer.answertext: None of them. Not enough information is given to solve the problem.
answer.feedback: We know three quantities ($$v_f$$, $$v_i$$ and $$\Delta x$$). Each of the equations of uniformly accelerated motion contains four quantities. So if you know three quantities you can always solve for a fourth one by choosing the appropriate equation.

question.name: Choose the correct equation (2)
question.questiontext: A firefighter is sliding down a fire pole. While sliding he is undergoing a constant downward acceleration. The firefighter takes 2.0 s to slide all the way down the fire pole and he starts from rest (i.e. his initial speed is zero). He hits the floor at 2.0 m/s. To find the firefighter's acceleration from the information given, which of the following equations would you need to use?

answer.feedback: Yes, this equation contains $$a$$ which is what we are trying to find. It also contains $$v_f$$, $$v_i$$ and $$\Delta t$$ all of which we know. So we can solve for the quantity we are looking for.

This equation contains $$a$$, which is the quantity we are trying to solve for. Unfortunately, it also contains $$\Delta x = x_f - x_i$$ which we don't know. So this gives us one equation in two unknowns, which we can't solve.
This equation contains $$a$$ which is what we are looking for. Unfortunately, it also contains $$\Delta x$$ which we don't know. This gives us one equation in two unknowns, which we can't solve.

answer.answertext: None of them. Not enough information is given to solve the problem.
answer.feedback: We know three quantities ($$v_f$$, $$v_i$$ and $$\Delta t$$). Each of the equations of uniformly accelerated motion contains four quantities. So if you know three quantities you can always solve for a fourth one by choosing the appropriate equation.

question.name: Choose the correct equation (3)
question.questiontext: A firefighter is sliding down a fire pole. While sliding, the firefighter is undergoing a constant downward acceleration of 2.0 m/s2. The firefighter takes 2.0 s to slide all the way down the fire pole and starts from rest (i.e. the firefighter's initial speed is zero). To find the height of the fire pole from the information given (in one step), which of the following equations would you need to use?

answer.feedback: We want to know the height, which is simply the displacement of the firefighter has during the motion. So we need to use an equation which contains positions so we can solve for the displacement (you can't solve for something if it isn't in the equation). We could use this equation to solve for the firefighter's final velocity, which might then make it easier to use another equation to find the height of the pole. But the question asks you to choose the equation which will allow you to solve for the height in one step.

Yes. This equation contains $$x_f$$ and $$x_i$$ (so it can be solved for $$\Delta x = x_f - x_i$$ which is the displacement). It also contains $$v_i$$, $$\Delta t$$ and $$a$$, all of which we know. So there is only one unknown and it is the thing we are looking for.

This equation contains $$\Delta x$$ (the firefighter's displacement) which is the thing we are looking for. Unfortunately, it also contains $$v_f$$ which we don't know. So using this equation gives us one equation in two unknowns, which we can't solve.

answer.answertext: None of them. Not enough information is given to solve the problem.
answer.feedback: We know three quantities ($$a$$, $$v_i$$ and $$\Delta t$$). Each of the equations of uniformly accelerated motion contains four quantities. So if you know three quantities you can always solve for a fourth one by choosing the appropriate equation.

question.name: Match\: position, displacement, distance, distance travelled
question.questiontext: Suppose you walk from the room you are in to the book stacks at the university library. There are many paths you could take (infinite, actually). In describing your motion we would need to set coordinate axes. Your motion could then be described in terms of position, displacement, distance from start point to end point and distance travelled. Match each of these quantities to the statement that best describes their properties.

match.answertext: vector, depends on choice of coordinate axes
vector, independent of choice of coordinate axes

question.name: matching - Sam's kinematic quantities
question.questiontext: Sam has a set of axes conveniently located near his home (that was one of the major reasons he chose to buy this house). Sam's house is exactly 50 m east of the origin of the axes. One day Sam steps out of his back door and walks exactly 50 m north. It takes him 40 s to do this. Match each listed quantity to its value (there is one more option available than quantities listed because one option is not a correct answer for any of the quantities asked for).

question.name: Bruce running to class (position vs. displacement)
question.questiontext: Bruce is shown at t = 0 s running to his physics class and passing x = -10 m. The door of the physics class is at the origin (x = 0 m). When Bruce has run 5 m since t = 0 s (choose the most correct statement)

answer.answertext: his position is -5 m and his displacement is +5 m.
his position is -5 m and his displacement is also -5 m
his position is +5 m and his displacement is also +5 m.
his position is +5 m and his displacement is -5 m.
his position is -10 m and his displacement is +5 m.

Your velocity is the same on both parts of the trip, but your speeds are different.
Your velocity and speed are the same on both parts of the trip.
Your speeds and velocities are both different on both parts of the trip.

moving to the left and slowing down.

question.name: mass and weight on the moon
question.questiontext: The acceleration due to gravity on the Moon is about 1/6 of accleration due to gravity on Earth. On the moon

answer.answertext: your mass is the same as on Earth, but your weight will be about 1/6 of what it is on Earth.
your mass and weight are both the same as what they are on the Earth.
your weight is the same but your mass is about 1/6 of what it is on the Earth.
your mass and weight are both about 1/6 of what they are on the Earth.
You are weightless since there is no atmosphere.

question.name: net force on falling ball
question.questiontext: You drop a ball. At the instant you let go (i.e. just after you let go) the net force acting on the ball is
question.generalfeedback: The only force acting on the ball is its weight (the gravitational force on the ball). This acts down. So the net force is down. As the ball falls there will be a drag force (due to the air) which opposes the motion. But, at least for the first while, this drag force will be much smaller than the weight and so the net force will still be down.

answer.answertext: there is no net force on the ball since nothing is pushing on it.

question.name: ball projected up incline
question.questiontext: You push a ball and let go, giving it an initial speed v<sub>0</sub> up a steady incline. The ball will

answer.answertext: roll at constant speed up the incline then reverse direction and roll down the incline at constant speed
immediately start rolling down when you let go because there is no force to keep it going up
roll up the incline at steadily decreasing speed until it stops, then roll down the incline with steadily increasing speed
roll up the incline until the push you gave it runs out, then stop

question.name: Force to stretch a spring [1]
question.questiontext: It takes a force of 2.00 N to stretch a given spring by 0.100 m. How much will the spring stretch when pulled with a force of 6.00 N?

answer.answertext: We need to know the spring constant to be able to answer this.

question.name: Force to stretch a spring [2]
question.questiontext: It takes a force of 40.0 N to stretch a given spring by 0.060 m. How much will the spring stretch when pulled with a force of 20.0 N?

answer.answertext: We need to know the spring constant to be able to answer this.

question.name: How can you make force on you different from force due to you?
question.questiontext: You are pushing a box across the floor. How can you cause the force that the box exerts back on you to be greater than the force you are exerting on the box?
question.generalfeedback: The magnitude of the force you exert on the box is always the same as the magnitude of the force that the box exerts back on you.

answer.answertext: By pushing hard enough that the box accelerates in its direction of motion.
By pushing the box over a very rough spot on the floor.
By pushing the box into a wall.

question.name: tow truck pulling car
question.questiontext: A tow truck is pulling a car up a hill while speeding up. The force exerted by the car on the tow truck is

answer.answertext: equal to the force exerted by the tow truck on the car and directed down the hill.
equal to the force exerted by the tow truck on the car and directed up the hill.
less than the force exerted by the tow truck on the car and directed down the hill.
less than the force exerted by the tow truck on the car and directed up the hill.

question.name: how many cars in an airplane
question.questiontext: According to your textbook a large airliner has a mass on the order of 1 X 10<sup>5</sup> kg and a small car has a mass on the order of 1 X 10<sup>3</sup> kg. If you could completely disassemble an airliner and use all of its mass (none left over) to build small cars roughly how many cars would you end up with?

question.name: pancake stack to the moon
question.questiontext: The average distance from the Earth to the Moon is about 3.8 X 10<sup>8</sup> m. A typical pancake is about a cm thick (1 X 10<sup>-2</sup> m). If you could make a stack of pancakes that reached all the way to the moon, how many pancakes would be in it?

answer.answertext: What kind of ridiculous question is this anyway?!

multichoice.partiallycorrectfeedback: You are finding out how many pancake thicknesses "fit" into the Earth-Moon distance. Typically when we as how many X fit into Y, the answer is found by dividing Y/X (this is one of the *meanings* of division).

question.name: acceleration of a harmonic oscillator
question.questiontext: The acceleration of a mass on a spring, or any other harmonic oscillator, is best described as

answer.answertext: restoring (directed towards the equilibrium position) and its magnitude is proportional to the distance from the equilibrium position
restoring (directed towards the equilibrium position) and its magnitude is constant

question.name: which object is easier to angularly accelerate
question.questiontext: Barbell A consists of a 20 cm lightweight bar connecting two 1.0 kg masses. Barbell B consists of an identical 20 cm lightweight bar connecting two 2.0 kg masses. You apply the same torque to both barbells. Which one has the larger angular acceleration while you are applying this torque?

answer.answertext: They both have the same angular acceleration

question.name: net torque on object in total equilibrium
question.questiontext: A rectangular sign hanging from two chains is in total static equilibrium. The sum of torques calculated about its center of mass is zero. What is the sum of the torques calculated about one corner?

answer.answertext: The net force on the sign times the moment arm

question.name: Solid wheel, omega and v (BROKEN)

answer.answertext: The angular velocity, <FONT FACE=symbol>w</FONT>, is the same for every part of the wheel, but different parts of the wheel may have different tangential velocity components, v<sub>t</sub>.
Both the angular velocity, <FONT FACE=symbol>w</FONT>, and tangential velocity components, v<sub>t</sub>, can differ for different parts of the wheel.
The angular velocity, <FONT FACE=symbol>w</FONT>, differs from one part of the wheel to another, but all parts of the wheel have the same tangential velocity component, v<sub>t</sub>.
Both the angular velocity, <FONT FACE=symbol>w</FONT>, and tangential velocity component, v<sub>t</sub>, are the same for all parts of the wheel.

answer.answertext: According to the observer on the ship the light goes 2 m. According to you it goes much farther than 2 m.
You both measure the light to travel 2 m.
According to you the light goes 2 m but according to the person on the ship it goes less than 2 m.
According to you the light goes 2 m but according to the person on the ship it goes more than 2 m.

question.name: particles decaying in a beam

answer.answertext: live for longer than 5 X 10<sup>-8</sup> s.
live for less than 5 X 10<sup>-8</sup> s.

If you were to travel to Sirius at 0.9c (90% of the speed of light) then, during the voyage, you would measure the distance between Earth and Sirius to be

question.name: pendulum viewed from passing ship
question.questiontext: A pendulum on Earth is measured (by observers on Earth) to have a period of 1.0 s. To an observer on a spaceship passing the Earth at 0.5c (half the speed of light) the period of the pendulum is

question.name: match force with type

question.name: truck pulling log [redo as cloze]
question.questiontext: Suppose that truck with a cable tied to it is used to drag a heavy log over the ground at constant speed. If our system is defined to be the log and the ground then (select the statement that is most correct)

answer.answertext: The tension in the cable is an external force doing work on the system and increasing the system's total energy. The friction between the log and the ground is a nonconservative internal force converting mechanical energy to thermal energy.

The tension in the cable is an external force doing work on the system and decreasing the system's total energy. The friction between the log and the ground is a nonconservative internal force converting mechanical energy to thermal energy.

The tension in the cable is an external force doing work on the system and increasing the system's total energy. The friction between the log and the ground is an external force decreasing the system's total energy.

The tension in the cable is an nonconservative internal force doing converting chemical energy to mechanical energy. The friction between the log and the ground is a nonconservative internal force converting mechanical energy to thermal energy.

match.questiontext: the spring is fully compressed with the mass on top of it
the spring has been released and the ball has just left contact with the spring
match.answertext: mostly kinetic energy, and a bit of gravitational potential energy

match.questiontext: the ball is half way towards its maximum height
match.answertext: equal amounts of kinetic energy and gravitational potential energy

match.questiontext: the ball has reached its maximum height

answer.answertext: they both have the same kinetic energy

question.questiontext: Ball A has a kinetic energy of 60 J. Ball B, which has a different mass from ball A, has a kinetic energy of 40 J. Which ball is moving faster?

question.name: definition of power
question.questiontext: What is the definition of power?

answer.answertext: Power is the rate of energy transformation/transfer per unit time.
Power is the change of energy per unit time.
Power is the amount of force exerted per unit time.
Power is the force times the speed.
Power is the energy divided by the time.

question.name: Work by friction

answer.answertext: positive or negative depending on how you define your coordinates

question_category.name: Match v vs. t to x vs. t

question.name: Match v vs. t to x vs. t (1)
question.questiontext: Below is a velocity vs. time graph. Below it (graphs A, B and C) are three position vs. time graphs. Which of A, B and C is/are the best match for the velocity vs. time graph?
question.generalfeedback: The v vs. t graph shows a decreasing velocity. B and C both show x vs. t graphs with decreasing slopes. B and C are identical except that the axes have been shifted. We do not know the initial position of the object (it has not been given), so the answer could be either B or C

answer.feedback: C is identical except that the axes have been shifted. We have not been given the initial position of the object. So while B is a good match, C is just as good. So this answer is worth half marks (the correct answer is B or C).

B is identical except that the axes have been shifted. We have not been given the initial position of the object. So while C is a good match, B is just as good. So this answer is worth half marks (the correct answer is B or C).

question.name: Match v vs. t to x vs. t (2)
question.questiontext: Below is a velocity vs. time graph. Below it (graphs A, B and C) are three position vs. time graphs. Which of A, B and C is/are the best match for the velocity vs. time graph?
question.generalfeedback: The v vs. t graph shows a constant, positive velocity. So the correct answer will be an x vs. t graph with constant slope. A has a constant positive slope. C has a constant zero slope, which is not what we are looking for (this would be an object that is not moving).

question.name: Match v vs. t to x vs. t (3)
question.questiontext: Below is a velocity vs. time graph. Below it (graphs A, B and C) are three position vs. time graphs. Which of A, B and C is/are the best match for the velocity vs. time graph?
question.generalfeedback: The v vs. t graph shows an increasing velocity. So we need an x vs. t graph with an increasing slope. C is the only one that has an increasing slope.

question.name: What's the average acceleration from graph (1)
question.questiontext: Below is a velocity vs. time graph. During the time period indicated (from 0 s to 4.0 s) what is the average acceleration?

question.name: What's the displacement from v vs. t graph (1)
question.questiontext: Below is a velocity vs. time graph. During the time period indicated (from 0 s to 4.0 s) what is the displacement of the object? Hint: examine the graph and think geometrically.
question.generalfeedback: The displacement can be found from the v vs. t graph by getting the area under the graph. This v vs. t graph is a triangle and the area of a triangle is (1/2) X base X height. So this gives (1/2) X (4.0 s) X (3.0 m/s) = 6.0 m.

question.name: sign of g

answer.answertext: positive when an object is moving up and negative when it is moving down
negative when an object is moving up and positive when it is moving down

question.name: which are in free fall
question.questiontext:
Which of the following objects are in free-fall?

A. a water balloon that is dropped off of a high building

B. a rock that is thrown upwards

C. a football that has been kicked towards the goal posts

answer.answertext: all of A, B and C

question.name: Correct freefall motion diagram
question.questiontext: A dense ball is dropped from rest.  Which of the following is the most correct motion diagram for the ball after it is dropped?

answer.feedback: Yes, it speeds up as it goes down.  The acceleration is down the whole time.

No.  This motion diagram is actually impossible for any object.  It shows the ball speeding up (distances between points increasing) but it claims that the acceleration is zero.  So the diagram contradicts itself.

No.  After it is released the ball will be in freefall.  The defining characteristic of freefall is that the object moves with the acceleration due to gravity.  This diagram is showing constant velocity motion, not accelerated motion.
No.  This motion diagram is actually impossible for any object.  It shows the ball moving with a constant velocity but it claims that the acceleration is non-zero.  So the diagram contradicts itself.

No.  After it is released the ball will be in freefall.  The defining characteristic of freefall is that the object moves (the whole time...) with the acceleration due to gravity.  This diagram is showing the ball initially accelerating, then moving with a constant veolocity.

question.name: Correct y vs. t for freefall
question.questiontext: Which of the graphs below is the most correct y vs. t (vertical component of position vs. time) graph for an object in freefall, dropped from rest?

answer.feedback: Yes.  The initial slope should be zero and it should be a curve that gets steeper.

No.  This is showing an object which initially has a large, negative y-component of velocity, and slows down until it has a (constant) zero y-component of velocity.  An object dropped from rest should start with zero velocity and should speed up.

No.  This is showing an object which initially has a large, positive y-component of velocity which remains constant for some time.  Then it slows down and eventually reverses direction.  An object dropped from rest should start with zero velocity and should speed up.
No.  This is showing an object moving with a constant y-component of velocity.  An object in freefall would be accelerating.
No.  This is showing an object moving with a constant y-component of velocity.  An object in freefall would be accelerating.

question.name: Correct v_y vs. t for freefall
question.questiontext: Which of the following graphs is the most correct \( v_y \) vs. t (vertical component of velocity vs. time) graph for an object in freefall that has been dropped from rest?

answer.feedback: Yes.  The acceleration is constant so the slope is constant.  The initial value of v_y is zero.

No.  This is showing an object which starts with some positive v_y.  Then v_y decreases, is eventually zero, and switches sign.  So this object reverses its direction of motion.  But you've been asked for a graph of an object which is dropped *from rest*.
No.  This is showing an object which starts with some positive v_y.  Then v_y increases.  But you've been asked for a graph of an object which is dropped *from rest*.
No.  This is showing an object with a constant y-component of velocity.  After it is dropped, the ball must speed up.

No.  Remember that the slope of a v_y vs. t graph is the y-component of acceleration.  An object in freefall has a constant vertical component of acceleration.  But the graph you have chosen has a changing slope.

question.name: Sig. figs. in adding [1]
question.questiontext:
9.8 + (2.45 X 103) =

Note: all the answers provided are numerically correct. The issue is how many significant figures we should use in expressing the answer.

answer.feedback: When adding numbers we round to the decimal place of the least precise number. In this case 2.45 X 103 = 2450 is only quoted with precision to the nearest 10, so it is much less precise than 9.8 which is precise to the nearest 0.1 (nearest 10th). So we round our answer to the nearest 10 and the correct answer is 2.46 X 103.
Yes, when adding numbers we round to the last decimal place of the least precise number, which is what has been done here.

When adding numbers we round to the decimal place of the least precise number. In this case 2.45 X 103 = 2450 is only quoted with precision to the nearest 10, so it is much less precise than 9.8 which is precise to the nearest 0.1 (nearest 10th). So we round our answer to the nearest 10 and the correct answer is 2.46 X 103.

This answer is rounded to the correct number of sig. figs. But the way it is expressed with the trailing zero is ambiguous at best (at worst, it implies that we know the answer to the nearest one and the trailing zero is a significant figure). So this answer is almost correct and receives half marks. The correct answer is to use scientific notation and write it as 2.46 X 103 so that there is no ambiguity with a trailing zero.

When adding numbers we round to the decimal place of the least precise number. In this case 2.45 X 103 = 2450 is only quoted with precision to the nearest 10, so it is much less precise than 9.8 which is precise to the nearest 0.1 (nearest 10th). So we round our answer to the nearest 10 and the correct answer is 2.46 X 103. So this answer, which is quoted to the nearest 10, is over rounded.

So we round our answer to the nearest 10 and the correct answer is 2.801 X 105.
Yes, when adding we round to the last decimal place of the least precise number, which is what has been done here.

So we round our answer to the nearest 10 and the correct answer is 2.801 X 105.

This answer is rounded to the correct number of sig. figs. But the way it is expressed with the trailing zero is ambiguous at best (at worst, it implies that we know the answer to the nearest one and the trailing zero is a significant figure). So this answer is almost correct and receives half marks. The correct answer is to use scientific notation and write it as 2.801 X 105 so that there is no ambiguity with a trailing zero.

When adding numbers we round to the decimal place of the least precise number. In this case 2.798 X 105 = 27 980 is quoted with precision to the nearest 10, so it is much less precise than 26.3 which is precise to the nearest 0.1 (nearest 10th). So we round our answer to the nearest 10 and the correct answer is 2.801 X 105. So this answer is over rounded since it is only quoted with precision to the nearest 100.

question.name: Sig. figs. in multiplying [1]
question.questiontext:
3.56 X (2.489 X 103) =

Note that all of the answers provided are numerically correct. The issue is in expressing the answer with the correct number of significant figures.

answer.feedback: When multiplying two numbers we keep the same number of significant figures as the factor with the fewest significant figures. In this case 3.56 has 3 sig. figs. while 2.489X10<sup>3</sup> has 4. So we keep 3 significant figures in the answer. The trailing zero in this answer indicates that the 0 is a significant figure and so we have 4 significant figures, so this answer is incorrect.

When multiplying two numbers we keep the same number of significant figures as the factor with the fewest significant figures. In this case 3.56 has 3 sig. figs. while 2.489X10<sup>3</sup> has 4. So we keep 3 significant figures in the answer. This answer has 7 significant figures so it is incorrect.

The answer should have 3 significant figures because the factor with the fewest sig. figs. (3.56) has 3 sig. figs. This answer is ambiguous because it is not clear whether the trailing zero is a sig. fig. or if it is there to place the decimal. This answer is almost correct since it could be interpreted as having 3 sig. figs. So it gets half marks. The correct answer would be to express this using scientific notation as 7.65 X 103 so that there is no ambiguity about how many significant figures are in the answer.

When multiplying two numbers we keep the same number of significant figures as the factor with the fewest significant figures. In this case 3.56 has 3 sig. figs. while 2.489X10<sup>3</sup> has 4. So we keep 3 significant figures in the answer. This answer has 7 significant figures so it is incorrect.

question.name: Sig. figs. in multiplying [2]
question.questiontext:
8.74 X (5.8652 X 106) =

Note that all of the answers provided are numerically correct. The issue is in expressing the answer with the correct number of significant figures.

answer.feedback: When multiplying two numbers we keep the same number of significant figures as the factor with the fewest significant figures. In this case 8.74 has 3 sig. figs. while 5.8652X10<sup>3</sup> has 5. So we keep 3 significant figures in the answer. So this is the correct answer.

When multiplying two numbers we keep the same number of significant figures as the factor with the fewest significant figures. In this case 8.74 has 3 sig. figs. while 5.8652X10<sup>3</sup> has 5. So we keep 3 significant figures in the answer. This answer has 8 significant figures so it is incorrect.

When multiplying two numbers we keep the same number of significant figures as the factor with the fewest significant figures. In this case 8.74 has 3 sig. figs. while 5.8652X10<sup>3</sup> has 5. So we keep 3 significant figures in the answer. This answer has 5 significant figures so it is incorrect.

When multiplying two numbers we keep the same number of significant figures as the factor with the fewest significant figures. In this case 8.74 has 3 sig. figs. while 5.8652X10<sup>3</sup> has 5. So we keep 3 significant figures in the answer. This answer has 8 significant figures so it is incorrect (and it is very hard to read because it is not in scientific notation).

When multiplying two numbers we keep the same number of significant figures as the factor with the fewest significant figures. In this case 8.74 has 3 sig. figs. while 5.8652X103 has 5. So we keep 3 significant figures in the answer. This answer is ambiguous because it is not clear whether the trailing zeros are sig. figs. or if it is there to place the decimal. This answer is almost correct since it could be interpreted as having 3 sig. figs. So it gets half marks. The correct answer would be to express this using scientific notation as 5.12 X 107 so that there is no ambiguity about how many significant figures are in the answer.

question.name: Interpreting velocity vs. time graph (1)
question.questiontext: The velocity vs. time graph shown represents the motion of an object that is
question.generalfeedback: The object had a positive velocity at t = 0, and the slope of the v vs. t graph is positive. So the velocity is getting more positive. Thus, the object is speeding up.

answer.answertext: speeding up or slowing down (it depends on the coordinate system chosen).
answer.feedback: The choice of where we put our axes has no bearing on the v vs. t graph since it only depends on differences in position (displacements). The v vs. t graph does depend on which direction we designate as positive, but the v vs. t graph implies that this choice has already been made and the current direction of motion of the object has been designated positive.

answer.answertext: speeding up or slowing down (it depends on the coordinate system chosen).

The v vs. t graph does depend on which direction we designate as positive, but the v vs. t graph implies that this choice has already been made and the current direction of motion of the object has been designated positive.

question.name: Behaviour of object with acceleration and velocity not parallel (2)

An object is moving so that at some instant its velocity and acceleration vectors are as shown below. 

At that instant the object is:

answer.answertext: speeding up and its trajectory is curving up.

answer.answertext: speeding up and moving in a straight line.

answer.answertext: slowing down and its trajectory is curving up.

answer.answertext: slowing down and moving in a straight line.
answer.feedback: No.  The acceleration is not parallel to the velocity so the object must be turning.

answer.answertext: speeding up and its trajectory is curving down.
answer.feedback: No.  The acceleration has a component up so the object must be turning up.  The acceleration also has a component opposite the direction of motion, so the object must be slowing down.

answer.answertext: slowing down and moving in a straight line.
