answer.feedback: Yes.
No.  The flare would be in freefall.  The acceleration is always down for any object in freefall.
No.  Throw an object horizontally (or even better, get someone else to throw it, so you can watch the path it follows).  Does it move in a straight line?
No.  Throw an object horizontally (or even better, get someone else to throw it, so you can watch the path it follows).  Does it move in a straight line?
No.  Throw an object horizontally (or even better, get someone else to throw it, so you can watch the path it follows).  Does it move in a straight line?
No.  Throw an object horizontally (or even better, get someone else to throw it, so you can watch the path it follows).  Does it move straight down immediately after it leaves your hand?

question.name: ant on conveyor belt
question.questiontext: An ant is crossing from one side of a conveyor belt to the other as shown in the diagram. The conveyor belt is running and carrying things from left to right in the diagram. If the ant points its head straight across the conveyor belt (straight at the other side) then the ant's velocity relative to the ground will be

answer.answertext: across the belt and to the right
across the belt and to the left

question.name: swimming across a river
question.questiontext: You are swimming due east across a river. That is, your velocity relative to the shore is directed straight to the east. There is a current to the south (i.e. the velocity of the water relative to the shore is southward). Which diagram correctly shows your velocity relative to the shore, vys, your velocity relative to the water, vyw, and the velocity of the water relative to the shore, vws? (Think physically: to compensate for the southward current which way do you need to swim to go straight east?)

question.name: horizontal component of projectile motion
question.questiontext: You throw a ball horizontally off the edge of a roof. Its initial velocity is 15 m/s horizontal. After 2.0 s, the ball's distance from the side of the building (i.e. its horizontal distance from its starting point) will be

answer.answertext: less than 30 m because gravity is slowing it down
greater than 30 m because gravity is speeding it up
we need more information to be able to answer this

question.name: Ball thrown horizontally vs. ball dropped from rest
question.questiontext: Natasha and Jason are standing on the roof of the A-block. Natasha throws a ball horizontally off of the roof. At the same instant, Jason drops a ball off of the roof. Which ball reaches the ground first?

answer.answertext: They both hit at the same time.
It depends on the initial speed of Natasha's ball.
It depends on the masses of the two balls.

question.name: vertical component of ball's trajectory
question.questiontext: A ball is thrown horizontally off of high a building. One second later the vertical component of the ball's velocity is (neglecting air drag)

answer.answertext: it depends on how hard the ball was thrown
equal to the horizontal component of its velocity

question.name: description of components of projectile motion
question.questiontext: As you have read in your text, projectile motion can be analyzed in terms of the horizontal, x, and vertical, y, components of its motion. The x and y motions are best described as:

answer.answertext: The x and y motions are independent. The horizontal motion is at constant velocity and the vertical motion has a constant acceleration.
The x and y motions are independent. The horizontal and vertical motions are each at constant velocity.
The x and y motions are independent. The horizontal and vertical motions are each with constant acceleration.
The x and y motions depend on each other because the vertical velocity depends on the horizontal velocity.

question.name: agent of frictional force
question.questiontext: A block is sliding down an inclined plane. There is a frictional force acting on it. The source (agent) of the friction force that acts on the block is

answer.answertext: the surface that the block rests on.

question.name: Agent of force on falling ball
question.questiontext: A ball is released and falls (accelerates down). The dominant force acting on the ball is the gravitational force. The agent (source) of this force is
question.generalfeedback: Gravity is not the source, it is the force itself. The source of the gravitational force is the Earth itself. All objects with mass pull on all other objects with mass. So the Earth pulls on the ball with a force that we call gravity.

answer.feedback: The gravitational force acts on the mass of the ball. But the mass of the ball is not the source of the force. The source (agent) is the thing that is doing the pulling. The Earth is pulling on the ball. So the Earth is the agent.

There is a common misconception that there is a connection between the presence of air and the presence of a gravitational force. People seem to think that there is no gravity in space (actually, there is gravity in space, but we'll discuss that later) because there is no air. This is incorrect. Gravity is a force that objects with mass exert on other objects with mass.

question.name: Agent of force on you
question.questiontext: As you are sitting at a computer doing this quiz there are forces acting upon you. One is the gravitational force, which pulls you down. If there were no other force acting on you then you would accelerate down (falling through the chair, the floor, etc.). So there must be an upward force acting on you. The agent (source) of this upward force is
question.generalfeedback: The chair and floor under you are pushing on you. They are the active agents (they are pushing, you are being pushed). So the floor and chair are the agents (sources) of the force that is acting to keep you from accelerating down. One part of this is the normal force (there may be some friction acting on you as well). But this is the name of the force, not the agent.

answer.answertext: the chair and floor that are under you.

question.name: Identify forces on box (1)
question.questiontext: You kick a box. The box slides some distance across the floor after leaving contact with your foot. The forces acting on the box after it has left contact with your foot are (select all that apply)
question.generalfeedback: The box keeps sliding for some distance. The friction and (very small) drag force would produce an acceleration in the opposite direction to the motion. This would reduce the speed of the box to zero over some period in time. Note that there is no force that keeps the box going. No force is needed for this. With no forces at all the box would just keep going forever. What the forces are doing here is gradually bringing the box to rest.

answer.answertext: A force applied by your foot on the box.
answer.feedback: The force applied by your foot was acting on the box while you were kicking it (for the fraction of a second that your foot was in contact with the box). But once the box has left contact with your foot this force will no longer exist.

answer.answertext: Friction between the box and the floor.
A normal force exerted on the box by the floor.
The inertia of the box which keeps it sliding.
answer.feedback: Inertia is not a force. It is the tendency of an object to resist changes to its velocity.

answer.answertext: A very small force of air drag (which can probably be neglected).
A normal force exerted on the floor by the box.
answer.feedback: Note that the question asks for forces acting on the box. We are going through the thought process we would as we draw a free body diagram. We are thinking of all the forces exerted on the box. These forces will affect its motion. Forces exerted by the box do not affect its motion.

question.name: Identify forces on box (2)
question.questiontext: You are pulling a box across the floor using a rope. The forces acting on the box are (select all that apply)

answer.answertext: The tension force in the rope.
Friction between the box and the floor.
A normal force exerted on the box by the floor.
A force equal to the mass of the box times its acceleration which keeps it sliding.
answer.feedback: This force does not exist. The net force on the box must equal its mass times its accleration. But the net force is, by definition, just the sum of all the real forces on the box.

answer.answertext: A very small force of air drag (which can probably be neglected).
A normal force exerted on the floor by the box.
answer.feedback: Note that we are thinking about forces on the box. We are going through the same thought process that we would while drawing a free body diagram. We are interested in forces on the box because these are the forces that will affect the box's motion. Forces exerted by the box have no affect on the box's motion.

question.name: identify forces on a skater
question.questiontext: You are skating. You want a rest so you just let yourself glide for a while. The forces acting on you are (select all that apply)
question.generalfeedback: You glide across the ice, probably for quite some distance. The small friction and drag forces acting on you would produce a small acceleration opposite to your direction of motion and this would slowly reduce your speed to zero.

answer.answertext: A normal force on you due to the ice surface.
A (small) friction force between your skates and the ice.
Your inertia which keeps you going.
answer.feedback: Inertia is not a force. It is the tendency of an object to resist having its velocity changed.

answer.answertext: A very small force of air drag.
A normal force exerted on the ice by you.
answer.feedback: Note that we are thinking about forces on you. We are going through the same thought process that we would while drawing a free body diagram. We are interested in the forces on you because these are the forces which affect your motion. Forces exerted by you do not affect your motion.

question.name: FBD of elevator accelerating up
question.questiontext: An elevator is accelerating upwards. Which of the following is the correct free body diagram for the elevator?

answer.answertext: It could be a or b depending on the acceleration.

question.name: FBD of puck
question.questiontext: A hockey puck is gliding across the ice. The ice is newly cleaned and the puck has been well chilled so that friction between the puck and ice is negligible. Air resistance is also negligible. Hence the puck is gliding along with constant velocity (at least to a good approximation). The most correct free body diagram for the puck is
question.generalfeedback: The only forces acting on the puck are its weight (which is due to the Earth) and the normal force due to the ice surface (really there would be a small frictional force and a drag force, but you have been told that they are small enough to be negligible). So these two forces are the only ones that should be on the FBD. The force labeled ma in A, C and D has no identifiable source so it cannot exist. Note that nobody is pushing the puck (e.g. with their hockey stick). The puck is not accelerating up or down so the wieght and normal force must be equal. So the net force on the puck is zero. The puck continues moving because in the absence of a nonzero net force, the acceleration is zero, so it moves at constant speed. Changes in velocity are caused by forces.

question_category.name: details of normal and friction forces

question.name: kinetic vs. static friction
question.questiontext: A block is stationary on an inclined plane. If you slowly tip the plane at steeper and steeper angles then the block will eventually start sliding. The friction force that acts on the block while it slides is

answer.answertext: less than the friction force that held it in place.
the same as the friction force that held it in place.
greater than the friction that held it in place.

question.name: block held in place by friction
question.questiontext: You place a block on a sloped surface. When you let go of it the block does not move. It is held in place by

answer.answertext: nothing is needed to hold it in place. Nothing is trying to make it move.

question.name: direction of normal force
question.questiontext: A block is sitting on an inclined plane. The normal force acting on the block is directed

answer.answertext: perpendicular to the surface of the incline.
straight up (opposite to the force of gravity).
At an angle to the slope that guarantees that the block does not slide.

question.name: What is inertia?
question.questiontext: What is inertia?

answer.answertext: Inertia is the tendency of an object to resist any change to its velocity.
Inertia is the force that tends to keep an object moving in the absence of other forces.
answer.feedback: Inertia is not a force.

answer.answertext: Inertia is the same a weight.
answer.feedback: The weight is a force. Inertia is not a force. Inertia is made more precise as a concept by defining the inertial mass. But inertia is not the mass either. Inertia is the tendency of a body to resist acceleration (if this seems vague, then good - it is vague).

answer.answertext: Inertia is the same as velocity.
Inertia is the same as momentum.

question.name: Why does an object stop?
question.questiontext: You give a book a hard push and it slides across the table. It eventually stops. The reason it stops is that

answer.answertext: There must be a force acting on it causing it to slow down.
There is no force acting on it to keep it moving.
Its "natural state" is to be at rest.
It eventually runs out of inertia.

question.name: net force on 1.0 kg object
question.questiontext: A 1.0 kg object is accelerating at a constant 2.0 m/s2. The net force on the object must be
question.generalfeedback: F<sub>net</sub> = ma = 1.0 kg X 2.0 m/s<sup>2</sup> = 2.0 N

answer.answertext: It depends on what other forces are acting on the object.

question.name: acceleration of steel block on ice
question.questiontext: A 1.0 kg steel block is on a flat frozen surface of a lake. The ice is very smooth and friction between the block and the ice is negligible. There is a high wind which is exerting a constant force of 0.5 N on the block. The block's acceleration is
question.generalfeedback: F<sub>net</sub> = ma, so a = F<sub>net</sub>/m = 0.5 N/1.0 kg = 0.5 m/s<sup>2</sup>

answer.answertext: 0 (the block is too heavy to be moved by wind)

question.name: dropping two balls of different masses
question.questiontext: You drop two balls from rest and from the same height (about head height) simultaneously. The balls are made of iron and both are round. However, one ball has a mass of 1.0 kg and the other has a mass of 2.0 kg. Which ball hits the ground first?

answer.answertext: Both balls hit the ground at the same time since they both have the same acceleration.
The heavier ball hits the ground first since the gravitational force on it is stronger.
The lighter ball hits the ground first since it has less inertia so it is easier to accelerate.

question.name: dropping crumpled and uncrumpled paper
question.questiontext: You have two identical pieces of paper. You crumple one of them up. You now drop them simultaneously from the same height. What happens, and why?

answer.answertext: The crumpled paper falls faster because there is less air drag on it.
The two pieces of paper fall at the same rate since they have the same mass.
The two pieces of paper fall at the same rate because all objects fall with the same acceleration due to gravity (g down).
The uncrumpled paper falls faster because gravity pulls on it more effectively.

question.name: forces acting on ball thrown up in the air
question.questiontext: You throw a ball straight up in the air. The forces acting on the ball after it leaves your hand are (choose all that apply)
question.generalfeedback: The only forces acting on the ball should be its weight and air drag. If you answered just the weight then you get 0.8/1 since the drag force is likely small (possibly negligible).

answer.answertext: a constant upward force equal to the force that you imparted on the ball with your hand.
answer.feedback: After the ball leaves your hand there is no longer an upward force on the ball (you cannot exert a force on the ball if you are not touching it).

answer.answertext: an upward force imparted by your hand which gradually decreases, reaching zero when the ball reaches its maximum height.
answer.feedback: After the ball leaves your hand there is no longer an upward force on the ball (you cannot exert a force on the ball if you are not touching it).

answer.answertext: A constant upward force imparted by your hand while the ball is on its way up which is replaced by a constant downward force due to gravity when the ball reaches its maximum height and starts coming down.
answer.feedback: After the ball leaves your hand there is no longer an upward force on the ball (you cannot exert a force on the ball if you are not touching it).

answer.answertext: There are no forces acting on the ball since it is in freefall.
answer.feedback: "Freefall" is a word we use to describe the situation of an object where the only force on the object is its weight, not an object with no forces acting on it.

answer.answertext: Air drag, which acts opposite to the direction of the velocity.

question.name: Falling blocks of different masses
question.questiontext: Two square blocks are dropped from rest simultaneously. One block has twice the mass of the other, but they are both made of the same, fairly dense, material. They are observed to fall through some fairly small distance (say, 3 m). You should expect that
question.generalfeedback:
The blocks are square and fairly dense. Also, the fall is relatively short so the speeds involved will be low. Under these conditions, air drag is negligible. So we only have to be concerned with the weights acting on the blocks. Acceleration due to gravity is independent of mass because Newton's 2nd law for an object in freefall is

mg = ma

and the mass cancels out of both sides. So the blocks should certainly fall through the distance in the same time.

answer.answertext:
the more massive block falls through the distance in less time because
gravity pulls on it more strongly.

the blocks fall through the distance in the same amount of time because
acceleration due to gravity is independent of mass.

the more massive block falls through the distance in more time because its
greater mass causes it to be accelerated more slowly.
We would need to know more about the blocks to be able to answer this.

question.name: reason for balls of different masses falling at same rate
question.questiontext: You have two, round, iron balls. One has a mass of 1.0 kg and the other has a mass of 2.0 kg. You drop them from the same height and observe that they hit the ground at the same time. Why is this?

answer.answertext: Both fall with the same acceleration because the force of gravity on them is proportional to their masses, but their accelerations are inversely proportional to their masses.
Both fall with the same acceleration because the force of gravity on each is the same.
Both fall with the same speed because gravity pulls everything at the same speed.
Both fall at the same rate because Galileo said so.
Both fall at the same rate because the gravitational force on them is inversely proportional to their mass but their acceleration is proportional to their mass.

question_category.name: identify correct FBD - old crappy questions

question.name: Pushing box at const. speed (identify correct FBD)
question.questiontext: You are pushing a box across the floor at constant speed. Which of the following is the correct free body diagram for the block?

question.name: Pulling box at const. speed (identify correct FBD)
question.questiontext: You are pulling a box across the floor at constant speed using a rope. Which of the following is the correct free body diagram for the block?

question.name: strength of normal force on box
question.questiontext: A box is sitting stationary on a flat floor. The normal force exerted by the floor on the box is

answer.answertext: equal to the gravitational force on the box since clearly the box's acceleration is zero.
greater than the gravitational force on the box since this is necessary to keep the box from falling through the floor.
less than the gravitational force on the box since the force is spread out over the whole bottom surface of the box.
zero since nothing is pushing or pulling on the box.
Equal to the strength of the floor.

question.name: strength of tension force holding up ball.
question.questiontext: A light is hanging, stationary, by a chain attached to the ceiling. The force exerted on the light by the chain is

answer.answertext: The same as the gravitational force on the light since clearly the light's acceleration is zero.
Greater than the gravitational force on the light since the light would fall otherwise.
Less than the gravitational force on the light due to mechanical advantage.
Zero since nobody is pushing or pulling on the light.
Equal to the force it would take to break the chain.

question.name: Net force on tow truck while towing at const. v
question.questiontext: A tow truck is towing a car down a straight highway at constant speed. The net force on the tow truck is

answer.answertext: dependent on the mass of the car and the force of rolling friction.

question.name: Net force on car uphill at constant speed
question.questiontext: A car is driving uphill at constant speed. The net force on the car is
question.generalfeedback: The car is moving at constant speed (zero acceleration). Thus, the net force acting on it must be zero. If this confuses you (surely there is a force pulling the car up the hill!) then realize that there is a force pulling the car up the hill (the force exerted by the road on the car's wheels). But there is also a component of the car's weight pulling downhill. The fact that the car is moving at constant speed tells us that these forces are equal. If there were no force pulling the car up the hill then gravity would be slowing the car down (i.e. the net force would be downhill and so the acceleration would be directed downhill as well).

answer.answertext: there is no net force since nothing is pulling on the car.

question.name: Reaction force while throwing ball
question.questiontext: You are throwing a ball. Your hand pushes on the ball to accelerate it during the throw. The magnitude of the force that the ball exerts back on your hand is:

answer.answertext: the same as the magnitude of the force that you exert on the ball.
less than the magnitude of the force that you exert on the ball
greater than the magnitude of the force that you exert on the ball
nonexistent. Your hand is doing the pushing here. The ball exerts no force.
We need more information (such as how hard you are throwing the ball).

question.name: Pushing box at const. speed (compare force on box with reaction force)
question.questiontext: You are pushing a box across the floor at a constant speed. The magnitude of the force that you are exerting on the box is
question.generalfeedback: According to Newton's 3rd Law (and in accordance with about three hundred years of careful experiment) the force exerted by one object on another is equal in magnitude and opposite in direction to the force exerted back on it. So the force that you exert on the box has the same magnitude as the force that the box exerts back on you.

answer.answertext: the same as the magnitude of the force that the box is exerting back on you.
greater than the magnitude of the force that the box is exerting back on you.

the only force to consider (the box exerts no forces since it is not doing the
pushing).
less than the magnitude of the force that the box is exerting back on you.
We need more information (such as how much friction there is between the box and the floor).
answer.feedback: It doesn't matter how much friction there is, the force you exert on the box will be equal in magnitude to the force that the box exerts on you. What does depend on the friction is the acceleration of the box (which depends on the force you exert on the box, the friction and the mass of the box).

answer.answertext: It depends on whether the box is speeding up or slowing down.

question.name: Reaction force to normal force on you
question.questiontext: You are sitting on a chair. The chair exerts a normal force upwards on you. The reaction force to this force is

answer.answertext: a normal force that you exert downward on the chair.
the gravitational force acting on you.
the gravitational force acting on the chair.
a normal force that you exert upwards on the chair.
a normal force that the floor exerts upwards on the chair.

question.name: Reaction to your weight
question.questiontext: As you read this there is a gravitational force acting downwards on you. The reaction force to this is

answer.answertext: a gravitational force that you exert upwards on the Earth.
an upward normal force on you due to the chair and/or floor.
a downward force that you exert on the chair and/or floor.
there is no reaction force to a gravitational force.
a downward gravitational force that you exert on the chair and/or floor.

question.name: tug-o-war
question.questiontext: Evan has a mass of 75 kg and pulls one end of a rope with a force of 300 N. Karen has a mass of 55 kg and pulls on the other end of the rope. The force that Karen is exerting on the other end of the rope is

answer.answertext: dependent on how hard she pulls.
dependent on whether one or the other of Evan or Karen are slipping as a result of all this pulling.

question.name: pulling on rope attached to wall
question.questiontext: A rope is attached to a wall. You pull on the free end of the rope with a force of 400 N. The force exerted on the rope by the wall is

question_category.name: direction of net force in UCM

question.name: direction of net force on child on merry-go-round
question.questiontext:
A child is riding a merry-go-round. It turns with constant angular velocity. The
child’s acceleration is

answer.answertext: toward the center of the merry-go-round.
away from the center of the merry-go-round.
tangent to the edge of the merry-go-round.

question.name: direction of net force on person in roller coaster
question.questiontext: You are riding a roller coaster which has a loop. At the instant that you pass through the top of the loop the net force on you is.

answer.answertext: forward (i.e. in the direction of your motion)

question.name: FBD of child on merry-go-round
question.questiontext: A child is sitting on a merry-go-round (not holding on) without falling off while the merry-go-round turns with constant angular velocity. If, at some instant, the center of the merry go round is to the right, the free body diagram for the child is

question.name: FBD of ball swinging in circle on string
question.questiontext: Imagine that you have a ball on the end of a string. You hang the ball from your hand and then swing it in horizontal circle (i.e. it is hanging from the string and moving in a circle underneath your hand). If, at some instant, the center of the circle is to the right, which of the diagrams below is the correct free body diagram for the ball?

question_category.name: dependence of f and T on radius

question.name: period vs. radius
question.questiontext: Amy and Brian are running on two circular tracks. They are both running at the same speed. Brian's track is inside Amy's track (so it must be smaller). Which runner is going around their track with the greater period.

answer.answertext: We need to know the precise radii of the tracks.
We can't determine this from their periods.
They are running at the same speed.

question.name: ants on turntable (frequency)
question.questiontext: Two ants are standing still on a turntable (in case you don't know, a turntable is an ancient device used to play "records" which were an audio recording format used in antiquity). The turntable is turning. Ant A is 1.0 cm from the center of the turntable. Ant B is 5.0 cm from the center of the turntable. Which ant's circular motion has the greater frequency?

answer.answertext: The ants have the same frequency.

question.name: frequency vs. radius
question.questiontext: Amy and Brian are running on two circular tracks. They are both running at the same speed. Brian's track is inside Amy's track (so it must be smaller). Which runner is going around their track with the greater frequency.

answer.answertext: We need to know the precise radii of the tracks.
We can't determine this from their periods.
They are running at the same speed.

question.name: period vs. speed
question.questiontext:
Amy runs around a circular track with a period of 120 s. Meanwhile Brian
runs around the same track with a period of 150 s. Which runner is running faster?

answer.answertext: We need to know the track’s radius to be able to answer this.
We can't determine this from their periods.

question.name: ants on turntable (speed)
question.questiontext: Two ants are standing still on a turntable (in case you don't know, a turntable is an ancient device used to play "records" which were an audio recording format used in antiquity). The turntable is turning. Ant A is 1.0 cm from the center of the turntable. Ant B is 5.0 cm from the center of the turntable. Which ant has the greater speed?

answer.answertext: The ants are moving at the same speed.

question.name: velocity vs. radius
question.questiontext: Amy and Brian are running on two circular tracks. The track that Amy is running on is inside the track that Brian is running on (so it must be smaller). They are each running around their respective tracks with a period of 120 s. Which runner is running faster?

answer.answertext: We need to know the precise radii of the tracks.
We can't determine this from their periods.
They are running at the same speed.

question.name: balls of different momentum [1]
question.questiontext: A 1.0 kg aluminum ball is moving to the right at 2.0 m/s. A 3.0 kg brass ball is moving to the left at 1.0 m/s. Which ball has a greater magnitude of momentum?

question.name: balls of different momentum [2]
question.questiontext: A 1.0 kg wooden ball is moving to the right at 5.0 m/s. A 3.0 kg lead ball is moving to the left at 1.0 m/s. Which ball has a greater magnitude of momentum?

question.name: Putty ball collides with steel ball
question.questiontext:
A 1.0 kg Silly PuttyTM ball moving 2.0 m/s to the right collides head on
with a 2.0 kg steel ball moving to the left at 1.0 m/s. Which ball has more
momentum?

answer.answertext: The magnitudes of their momenta are equal.

question.name: force due to putty ball vs. steel ball
question.questiontext: A 1.0 kg putty ball, moving at 10 m/s, hits a wall and sticks to it. A 1.0 kg steel ball, also moving at 10 m/s, hits the wall and bounces off with a speed after the collision of nearly 10 m/s. Which ball should you expect to exert a greater force on the wall during the collision and why?

answer.answertext: The steel ball will have exerted a greater force because the impulse delivered to it was greater and its collision likely took less time as well.
They both were moving at the same speed and had the same mass so they will have exerted equal forces.
The impulse on the steel ball is zero (final speed = initial speed). So the putty ball must have exerted a greater force.
The putty ball will have exerted a greater force because its collision with the wall is completely elastic.
The steel ball will have exerted a greater force because steel is stronger than putty.

question.name: force in collision of unequal mass balls
question.questiontext: A steel ball of mass 3.0 kg moving at 1.0 m/s to the right collides with another steel ball of mass 1.0 kg moving at 2.0 m/s to the left. Which ball exerts the larger magnitude of force on the other ball over the course of the collision?

answer.answertext: They each exert the same magnitude of force on the other.

question.name: force in steel ball/putty ball collision
question.questiontext: A steel ball of mass 2.0 kg moving at 1.0 m/s to the right collides with a silly putty ball of mass 2.0 kg moving at 1.0 m/s to the left. Which ball exerts the larger magnitude of force on the other during the collision?

answer.answertext: They each exert the same magnitude of force.

question.name: impulse in collision of unequal mass balls
question.questiontext: A steel ball of mass 3.0 kg moving at 1.0 m/s to the right collides with another steel ball of mass 1.0 kg moving at 2.0 m/s to the left. Which ball receives the larger magnitude of impulse over the course of the collision?

answer.answertext: They each receive the same magnitude of impulse.

question.name: impulse in steel ball/putty ball collision
question.questiontext: A steel ball of mass 2.0 kg moving at 1.0 m/s to the right collides with a silly putty ball of mass 2.0 kg moving at 1.0 m/s to the left. Which ball receives the larger magnitude of impulse over the course of the collision?

answer.answertext: They each receive the same magnitude of impulse.

question.name: momentum conservation of bouncing ball and Earth
question.questiontext:
A ball is dropped and bounces off of the floor. Its speed immediately
before the bounce is the same as its speed immediately after the bounce.
What must we consider as "the system" for the momentum of the system to be conserved in this collision?
question.generalfeedback: We need more information.

answer.answertext: The momentum is conserved no matter what we consider to be the system.

question.name: momentum conservation of bouncing ball
question.questiontext: A ball is dropped and bounces off of the floor. Its speed immediately before the bounce is the same as its speed immediately after the bounce. If the system that we consider is only the ball, is the momentum of the system conserved?

answer.answertext: We need to know the mass and velocity of the ball to answer this.
The momentum is only partly conserved because the Earth is not moving.

question.name: isolated collision?
question.questiontext: Compare a collision between two billiards balls on a flat surface (in which the two balls are in contact for on the order of a millisecond) with a collision between two water balloons sliding down an inclined plane (which are in contact for nearly a second). Which of these collisions is better approximated as an isolated collision?

question.name: putty ball sticks to steel ball
question.questiontext: A silly putty ball collides with a steel ball and sticks to it. This is an example of

question.name: match collision types
question.questiontext: Match the following collisions with their types

match.questiontext: a lump of clay collides with a ball and sticks to it
A rubber ball bounces off of the floor. The floor and ball are both slightly warmer after the collision.

question.name: what quantities are conserved in collisions
question.questiontext: Two of the following statements are correct descriptions of what physical quantities are conserved in collisions. Select the two correct statements.

answer.answertext: Momentum is conserved in all isolated collisions.
Energy is conserved in perfectly elastic collisions. Most collisions are not even approximately elastic.
Momentum is conserved in all collisions.
Energy is conserved in all collisions.
Energy is only conserved when the two objects stick together.

question.name: definition of elastic collision
question.questiontext: What is a perfectly elastic collision?

answer.answertext: A collision in which mechanical energy is conserved.
A collision in which mechanical energy is lost.
A collision in which momentum is conserved.
A collision in which the colliding objects stick together.

question.name: Ball having fallen some distance
question.questiontext: You release a ball from rest. As the ball falls, the energy transformation taking place is

answer.feedback: Energy is converted only to other forms of energy. Momentum is not energy and so the ball's initial energy (gravitational potential) cannot be converted to momentum.

question.name: energy transformation in burning match
question.questiontext: As a match burns what energy transformation is taking place?

question.name: falling object vs. object on track
question.questiontext: A roller coaster goes down the first hill on its track. Its speed at the top of the hill is essentially zero. As the roller coaster starts down the hill one rider drops their glasses over the side of the roller coaster. The glasses fall straight to the ground. The speed of the glasses just before they reach the ground is

answer.answertext: the same as the speed of the train when it gets to the bottom of the hill
greater than the speed of the train when it gets to the bottom of the hill
less than the speed of the train when it gets to the bottom of the hill
possibly greater and possibly less than the speed of the train depending on the shape of the roller coaster track.

question.name: energy of ball at instant of release
question.questiontext: You are dropping a ball. At the instant that you let go of the ball it is at rest. At that instant all of its mechanical energy is

answer.answertext: Captain! It's a form of energy we've never encountered before!

question.name: Dropping balls of different masses
question.questiontext: You drop an iron ball of mass 200 g and another iron ball of mass 500 g. After they have both fallen 1.0 m the kinetic energy of the 500 g ball is

answer.answertext: greater than the kinetic energy of the 200 g ball
the same as the energy of the 200 g ball
less than the energy of the 200 g ball

question.name: mass on spring - greatest U
question.questiontext: A mass on a frictionless surface is vibrating back and forth on the end of a spring. When does the mass and spring system have the largest potential energy?

answer.answertext: When the spring is either fully compressed or fully stretched.
When the mass is passing through the equilibrium postion
The energy is conserved so the mass and spring always have the same potential energy
When the mass is moving at maximum speed
There is no vertical motion so the potential energy is not changing

question.name: mass on spring - greatest K
question.questiontext: A mass on a frictionless surface is vibrating back and forth on the end of a spring. When does the mass and spring system have the largest kinetic energy?

answer.answertext: When the spring is either fully compressed or fully stretched.
When the mass is passing through the equilibrium postion
The energy is conserved so the mass and spring always have the same potential energy
When the force exerted by the spring is a maximum
There is no vertical motion so the potential energy is not changing

question.name: energy conservation of falling ball
question.questiontext:
You drop a ball. At the instant you let go, it has mechanical energy E1.
After falling 1.0 m it is still in midair and has mechanical energy E2. Neglecting air resistance, which of the following is true?

question.name: energy conservation of mass on spring
question.questiontext: You hang a mass on a spring. You pull the spring down. At this instant the mass and spring has mechanical energy E<su><sub>1</sub>. You now release the mass. The mass initially accelerates upward. A short time after releasing the mass it is moving upward at some speed and has mechanical energy E<sub>2</sub>. At this instant</su>

question.name: pulling boxes with horizontal vs. angled rope
question.questiontext: Al pulls a box along the ground using a rope that is horizontal (parallel to the ground). Betty pulls another box, applying the same magnitude of force over the same distance, but her rope is at a 45 degree angle from horizontal. Which statement is true?

answer.answertext: Al and Betty do the same amount of work.
Neither Al nor Betty do any work.

question.name: energy of two objects, same force, same distance
question.questiontext: Two carts, A and B, are initially at rest on a table top. A has a mass of 0.5 kg and B has a mass of 0.25 kg. You push each of them with a force of 1 N over a distance of 1 m. Which cart will have the greater kinetic energy. Ignore friction.

answer.answertext: They both have the same kinetic energy.
A has more kinetic energy because kinetic energy is proportional to mass.
B has more kinetic energy because it will be moving at a greater speed by the end of the 1 m.

question.name: work by force perpendicular to motion
question.questiontext: A conveyor belt moves a box horizontally over a distance of 4.0 m. The perpendicular force on the object due to the conveyor belt is (50 N, up). How much work does the perpendicular force do on the object?
question.generalfeedback: The force is perpendicular to the motion and, therefore, does no work.

question.name: mechanical energy while bicycling (2)
question.questiontext: You put on the brakes of your bicycle and cause yourself and the bicycle to slow down along a flat (level) piece of road. Consider "the system of interest" to be yourself and the bicycle. The mechanical energy of this system is
question.generalfeedback: The mechanical energy is certainly decreasing (you are going slower -> decreasing K) while staying at the same height (U is staying constant). The reason is that there is a force due to the ground (static friction on the wheels) pushing you and accelerating you back (the force points opposite to the direction of motion and so it does negative work).

answer.answertext: Decreasing because kinetic energy is being converted to thermal energy in the brakes.
Conserved because energy is always conserved.
Increasing because the ground is doing work on the system.
Conserved because the system is isolated.

question.name: mechanical energy while bicycling (1)
question.questiontext: You push on the pedals of your bicycle and cause yourself and the bicycle to speed up along a flat (level) piece of road. Consider "the system of interest" to be yourself and the bicycle. The mechanical energy of this system is
question.generalfeedback: The mechanical energy is certainly increasing (you are going faster -> increasing K) while staying at the same height (U is staying constant). The reason is that there is a force due to the ground (static friction on the wheels) pushing you and accelerating you forward. The source of this energy is more subtle. You, in your cells, are metabolizing various chemicals (particularly ATP) and using the liberated chemical energy to make your muscles do work.

answer.answertext: Increasing because the chemical energy is being converted to mechanical energy.
Conserved because energy is always conserved.
Decreasing because there must be friction acting on the bicycle.
Conserved because the system is isolated.

question.name: Energy transfer while stretching an elastic band
question.questiontext: You pull the ends of an elastic band and stretch it. Consider the system to be the elastic band and the environment to be you. What energy transfer is taking place as you stretch the elastic band?

question.name: Energy transfer while pushing a sled
question.questiontext: In Olympic bobsled races the athletes get the sled going by pushing it. Consider the system to be the sled and the environment to be the athletes. What energy transfer is taking place?

question.name: putting on the brakes
question.questiontext: You are riding your bike when you apply the breaks and stop. The kinetic energy that the bike had before you put on the breaks

answer.answertext: has been converted to thermal energy.
was conserved because energy is always conserved.
kept going and left you behind.

question.name: ball hitting ground and coming to rest
question.questiontext: A ball that has been falling hits the ground and comes to rest. Its mechanical energy that it had while falling is converted to another form as the ball comes to rest. This conversion of energy from one form to another happens because

answer.answertext: During the collision with the ground the ball did work on the ground through nonconservative forces
The energy was able to flow out of the ball once it was in contact with the ground
Energy was no longer conserved once the ball hit the ground
The ball couldn't go any farther once it had hit the ground so its kinetic energy left it behind.

question_category.name: dependence of frequency on m and k

question.name: effect on omega of increasing k
question.questiontext: Suppose we have a mass on a spring which oscillates with some frequency. If we replace the spring with a stiffer on (one with a larger spring constant, k) then the frequency of oscillation will be

answer.answertext: higher than with the original (weaker) spring
lower than with the original (weaker) spring
the same as with the original (weaker) spring

question.name: effect on omega of increasing m
question.questiontext: Suppose we have a mass on a spring which oscillates with some frequency. If we replace the mass with a larger (more massive) one then the frequency of oscillation of the new mass on the spring will be

answer.answertext: lower than with the original (smaller) mass
higher than with the original (smaller) mass

question.name: Interpreting position vs. time graph (1)
question.questiontext: The position vs. time graph here represents the motion of a train along a track during some time period. The train is

answer.feedback: Yes, the slope is decreasing in magnitude so the train must be slowing down.

You may be confused because the curve is showing something that is increasing in value. But this is an x vs. t graph so it is the position that is increasing (the train is moving towards more positive values of x). But the velocity is the slope of the x vs. t graph and the speed is the magnitude of the velocity.
This is an x vs. t graph. The velocity is the slope of the x vs. t graph and the speed is the magnitude of the velocity.

answer.answertext: we don't have enough information to describe the motion of the train.
answer.feedback: You certainly have enough information. The graphs gives the position of the train at every instant of time within the time range shown. This is a lot of information and, in fact, contains all of the information that could be known about the train's motion during this time period.

question_category.name: adaptive interpreting v vs. t graphs

question.name: Interpreting velocity vs. time graph (1)
question.questiontext: The velocity vs. time graph shown represents the motion of an object that is

answer.feedback: Yes. The object had a positive velocity at t = 0, and the slope of the v vs. t graph is positive. So the velocity is getting more positive. Thus, the object is speeding up.
This is a velocity vs. time graph. So it shows the velocity directly and the speed is the magnitude of the velocity.
You may be confused about what kind of graph this is. This is a velocity vs. time graph. So the speed is simply the magnitude of the value that you read off of the graph at any point (not the slope).

answer.answertext: speeding up or slowing down (it depends on the coordinate system chosen).
answer.feedback: The choice of where we put our axes has no bearing on the v vs. t graph since it only depends on differences in position (displacements). The v vs. t graph does depend on which direction we designate as positive, but the v vs. t graph implies that this choice has already been made and the current direction of motion of the object has been designated positive.

There is certainly enough information. The graphs gives all of the information about the motion of the object during the time period shown except for the initial position. This allows us to determine from the graph whether the object is speeding up or slowing down.

question.name: Ave vs. inst. v
question.questiontext: The figure shows the x vs. t graph for the motion of some object. Two times, A and B are indicated. If vA is the instantaneous speed at time A, vB is the instantaneous speed at time B and vave is the average speed between A and B then from the graph we can say that

answer.feedback: Yes. The line connecting the point at A to the point at B is intermediate in slope between the first and second time intervals on the graph.

Remember that the velocity is given by the slope of the x vs. t graph. In the first time interval (the one containing time A) the graph shows a fairly shallow slope, indicating a small speed. The later time interval (the one containing time B) shows a much steeper slope.
The velocity is given by the slope of the x vs. t graph. This x vs. t graph does not have the same slope everywhere, and certainly the slope at B is different from the slope at A.

To get the average velocity between A and B you would draw a line from the graph at point A to the graph at point B. Imagine this line and think about how its slope relates to the slopes at A and B. It might help to sketch it on a piece of paper.

question.name: What's the average acceleration from graph (1)
question.questiontext: Below is a velocity vs. time graph. During the time period indicated (from 0 s to 4.0 s) what is the average acceleration?

answer.feedback: Yes. $$\Delta v / \Delta t$$ = (1 m/s - 3 m/s)/(4 s - 0 s) = - 0.5 m/s<sup>2</sup>
Over the indicated time period the velocity decreases. So the average acceleration over this time period must be negative.
Over the indicated time period the velocity decreases. So the average acceleration over this time period must be negative.

The change in velocity, $$\Delta v$$, over this time period is -2 m/s, and this might be what has prompted you to choose the answer you just did. But recall that the average acceleration is $$a_{ave} = \Delta v / \Delta t$$. An object experiencing the same $$\Delta v$$ in a shorter time would be accelerating faster.

Recall that the average acceleration is $$a_{ave} = \Delta v / \Delta t$$ where $$\Delta v$$ is the change in the velocity. You probably got -0.75 m/s2 by combining 3 m/s with 4 s. But the initial velocity is 3 m/s, not the change in velocity.

question.name: What's the displacement from v vs. t graph (1)
question.questiontext: Below is a velocity vs. time graph. During the time period indicated (from 0 s to 4.0 s) what is the displacement of the object? Hint: examine the graph and think geometrically.

answer.feedback: Yes. The displacement can be found from the v vs. t graph by getting the area under the graph. This v vs. t graph is a triangle and the area of a triangle is (1/2) X base X height. So this gives (1/2) X (4.0 s) X (3.0 m/s) = 6.0 m.
The object starts going at 3 m/s. If it moved at this speed for 1 s this is how far it would go. But this object is not moving at a constant 3 m/s and we are interested in how far it goes in 4 s.

Did you just multiply the initial velocity (3 m/s) by the time interval (4 s)? An object moving at a constant velocity of 3 m/s would travel 12 m in 4 s. But this object is not moving at a constant 3 m/s. Note from the graph that it is slowing down. How, in general do we find the distance traveled from a velocity vs. time graph?

Have you, just taken the initial velocity (3 m/s) and divided by 2 to get this? Is this because you remember something about a 1/2 when you are finding the area of a triangle? Think about area of a triangle. It must in some way depend on the height and the length of the base...

Did you just look at the time interval (4 s) and conclude this? If the object were moving at a constant 1 m/s then it would go 4 m/s in 4s. But it isn't moving at a constant speed, and it doesn't start out going at 1 m/s.

question_hint.hint: No, see the hint given beside the answer that you chose.
No, see the hint given beside the answer that you chose.

question.name: sign of g
question.questiontext: The sign of g (acceleration due to gravity) is

answer.feedback: Yes. The acceleration due to gravity (on Earth) is g [down]. If we are working in 1D with up defined as positive then we will often state this as $$a_{freefall} = - g$$. Note that the -ve sign is out where we can see it, not buried inside a symbol.

No. It is bad practice (i.e. leads to many errors) to bury negative signs inside symbols. You may be thinking that acceleration due to gravity is down and this makes it negative. But we don't put the negative inside the symbol, g.

answer.answertext: positive when an object is moving up and negative when it is moving down
answer.feedback: No. An object in free fall that is on its way up (i.e. a ball that has just been thrown upward) is slowing down. So while it is going up (its velocity vector points up) it is also slowing down so its acceleration points in the opposite direction to the velocity (i.e. down). When it is on its way down it is speeding up so the acceleration points in the same direction as the velocity (still down). So the acceleration due to gravity always points down. Careful, though! This doesn't necessarily tell you the sign of g.

answer.answertext: negative when an object is moving up and positive when it is moving down
answer.feedback: No. An object in free fall that is on its way up (i.e. a ball that has just been thrown upward) is slowing down. So while it is going up (its velocity vector points up) it is also slowing down so its acceleration points in the opposite direction to the velocity (i.e. down). When it is on its way down it is speeding up so the acceleration points in the same direction as the velocity (still down). So the acceleration due to gravity always points down. Careful, though! This doesn't necessarily tell you the sign of g.
No. This is a convention that we adopt for convenience. It is probably not a good idea to deviate from this convention as it can lead to confusion.

question_hint.hint: No, see the hint beside the answer you chose.
No, see the hint beside the answer you chose.

question.name: which are in free fall
question.questiontext:
Which of the following objects are in free-fall?

A. a water balloon that is dropped off of a high building

B. a rock that is thrown upwards

C. a football that has been kicked towards the goal posts

answer.feedback: Many people think of "falling" as only meaning the downward motion of objects that are dropped. But this is not the physics meaning of "freefall". Review the precise meaning in your text.
This suggests that you might be thinking that only objects moving vertically are said to be in freefall. This is not the meaning of the term. Review the precise definition of freefall in your text.

This answer is the one that most students would identify as "projectile motion" and some students equate this type of motion with freefall. This is not quite the meaning of freefall. Review the precise meaning in your text.

answer.answertext: all of A, B and C
answer.feedback: Yes. Any object which is accelerated at g [down] is said to be in free fall.
This suggests that you are thinking that only objects moving vertically are said to be in freefall. This is not the meaning of the term. Review the precise definition of freefall in your text.

question_hint.hint: No, see the hint beside the answer you chose.
No, see the hint beside the answer you chose.

question.name: Agent of force on you
question.questiontext: As you are sitting at a computer doing this quiz there are forces acting upon you. One is the gravitational force, which pulls you down. If there were no other force acting on you then you would accelerate down (falling through the chair, the floor, etc.). So there must be an upward force acting on you. The agent (source) of this upward force is

answer.answertext: the chair and floor that are under you.
answer.feedback: Yes, the chair and floor under you are pushing on you. They are the active agents (they are pushing, you are being pushed). So the floor and chair are the agents (sources) of the force that is acting to keep you from accelerating down. One part of this is the normal force (there may be some friction acting on you as well). But this is the name of the force, not the agent.
No. An object cannot exert a net force on itself. So you cannot be the source of the force that holds you up. You are the object that the force acts upon.

No. The air around you is exerting forces upon you (this is referred to as the "hydrostatic pressure forces"). However, these forces are directed inward from all directions. The sum of all of these inward forces is zero (they cancel each other out).

The force that holds you up is mostly a normal force (there might be some friction as well). But these are the names of the forces themselves. These are not the agents (sources) of the forces. The agent of a force is always a physical object.

Ha, ha! You're joking right?

The agent of a force is always a physical object. James Bond is not a physical object. He is a fictional character.

question.name: agent of frictional force
question.questiontext: A block is sliding down an inclined plane. There is a frictional force acting on it. The source (agent) of the friction force that acts on the block is

answer.answertext: the surface that the block rests on.
answer.feedback: Yes, the force is exerted by the surface.
No. An object cannot exert a nonzero net force on itself. The block cannot be the source of the force that keeps it from sliding down the slope.

We distinguish between friction (which has to do with interactions of solid objects) and drag (which is due to motion through a fluid). The question describes a friction, not a drag. More importantly, however, air drag is a force, not the agent (source) of a force. The agent of a force is always a physical object.
No. First of all gravity is not a frictional force. More importantly, however, gravity is a force, not the agent (source) of a force. The agent of a force is always a physical object.

No. The kinetic friction force is the frictional force that is acting on the block. But the question asked you for the agent (the source) of the force. The agent of a force is always a physical object.

question.name: Agent of force on falling ball (adapt)
question.questiontext: A ball is released and falls (accelerates down). The dominant force acting on the ball is the gravitational force. The agent (source) of this force is

answer.feedback: Yes, the gravitational force is exerted by the Earth (i.e. the Earth gravitationally pulls on the ball).

The gravitational force acts on the mass of the ball. But the mass of the ball is not the source of the force. The source (agent) is the thing that is doing the pulling. The agent of a force is always a physical object. Note that the mass of the ball is not a physical object, it is a property of a physical object.

There is a common misconception that there is a connection between the presence of air and the presence of a gravitational force. People seem to think that there is no gravity in space (actually, there is gravity in space, but we may discuss that later) because there is no air. This is incorrect. Gravity is a force that objects with mass exert on other objects with mass.
Gravity is not the source; it is the name we give to the force itself. An agent (source) of a force is always a physical object.

Ha, ha! You're joking right?

The agent of a force is always a physical object. James Bond is not a physical object. He is a fictional character.

question_category.name: details of normal and friction forces (adaptive)

question.name: block held in place by friction
question.questiontext: You place a block on a sloped surface. When you let go of it the block does not move. It is held in place by

answer.feedback: No, remember that inertia is not a force. It is the tendency of an object to remain in the same state of motion. So inertia cannot hold an object in place.
Yes.
No, the object is not sliding on the surface (it is stationary on the surface) so there is no force of kinetic friction.

answer.answertext: nothing is needed to hold it in place. Nothing is trying to make it move.
answer.feedback: There is something "trying make it move". The Earth is exerting a gravitational force downward on the object. Unopposed by other forces, this gravitational force will cause the block to accelerate downward.
Tee hee! This is a science course. We try to avoid appealing to magic to explain phenomena. Scientific explanations are "naturalistic" (i.e. they rely on natural, not supernatural, influences).

question.name: direction of normal force
question.questiontext: A block is sitting on an inclined plane. The normal force acting on the block is directed

answer.answertext: perpendicular to the surface of the incline.
answer.feedback: Yes. A normal force is always perpendicular to the surface that exerts it (this is what "normal" means).

answer.answertext: straight up (opposite to the force of gravity).
answer.feedback: No. When a surface is horizontal it exerts a normal force vertically. But this surface isn't horizontal. Hint: what does "normal" mean?
No. A force exerted by the surface that is directed up the slope (parallel to the surface) would be a frictional force, not a normal force.

answer.answertext: At an angle to the slope that guarantees that the block does not slide.
answer.feedback: No. The normal force is always in one particular direction relative to the surface. The angle never changes. Hint: what does "normal" mean?
No. The normal force is always in one particular direction relative to the surface. The angle never changes. Hint: what does "normal" mean?

question.name: kinetic vs. static friction
question.questiontext: A block is stationary on an inclined plane. If you slowly tip the plane at steeper and steeper angles then the block will eventually start sliding. The friction force that acts on the block while it slides is

answer.feedback: No. In general when one surface slides across another there is a nonzero frictional force that acts between them. Just because the object is moving doesn't mean there is no frictional force acting.

answer.answertext: less than the friction force that held it in place.
answer.feedback: Yes, a kinetic friction force between two surfaces is always less than the maximum possible static friction between those two surfaces.

answer.answertext: the same as the friction force that held it in place.
answer.feedback: No. The coefficient for kinetic friction (which is one thing that determines the strength of the frictional force) is generally different from the coefficient of static friction.

answer.answertext: greater than the friction that held it in place.
answer.feedback: No. How do coefficients of kinetic friction usually compare with coefficients of static friction?
No. The air drag force (exerted by the air) would be quite separate from the frictional forces (which are due to the surface that the block is sliding on).

question.name: FBD of elevator accelerating up
question.questiontext: An elevator is accelerating upwards. Which of the following is the correct free body diagram for the elevator?

answer.feedback: Yes, the only forces acting on the elevator are the tension (due to the cable) and the gravitational force.
Well, presumably this elevator is one Earth (i.e. not in some spacestation in deep space). Is there a force that always acts on all objects on Earth?
The upward force labeled "ma" is presumably the net force. But this is not a real force on the object. It is the sum of all the real forces. Since it isn't a real force, it doesn't belong on the FBD.

answer.answertext: It could be a or b depending on the acceleration.

question.name: FBD of puck
question.questiontext: A hockey puck is gliding across the ice. The ice is newly cleaned and the puck has been well chilled so that friction between the puck and ice is negligible. Air resistance is also negligible. Hence the puck is gliding along with constant velocity (at least to a good approximation). The most correct free body diagram for the puck is

answer.feedback: What object would be applying that force labeled "Fa"? Any force that has no identifiable agent can't exist.

Yes. The only forces acting on the puck are the gravitational force (which is due to the Earth) and the normal force due to the ice surface (really there would be a small frictional force and a drag force, but you have been told that they are small enough to be negligible). So these two forces are the only ones that should be on the FBD. The force labeled ma in A, C and D has no identifiable source so it cannot exist. Note that nobody is pushing the puck (e.g. with their hockey stick). The puck is not accelerating up or down so the wieght and normal force must be equal. So the net force on the puck is zero. The puck continues moving because in the absence of a nonzero net force, the acceleration is zero, so it moves at constant speed. Changes in velocity are caused by forces.

The force labeled "ma" is presumably an attempt to include a net force on the FBD. But the net force isn't a real force (it is a sum of all of the real forces) so it doesn't belong on the FBD. Also, this particular attempt to include the net force is incorrect because the other forces can't possibly add up to a force to the right.

The force labeled "ma" is presumably an attempt to include a net force on the FBD. But the net force isn't a real force (it is a sum of all of the real forces) so it doesn't belong on the FBD. Also, this particular attempt to include the net force is incorrect because the other forces can't possibly add up to a force to the right.
The force labeled "Fr" is presumably a friction, but you've been told that friction is negligible.

question.name: identify forces on a skater
question.questiontext: You are skating. You want a rest so you just let yourself glide for a while. The forces acting on you are (select all that apply)

answer.answertext: A normal force on you due to the ice surface.
answer.feedback: Yes, you are in contact with the ice so it must exert a normal force on you.

answer.answertext: A (small) friction force between your skates and the ice.
answer.feedback: Yes, you are sliding on the ice so it must exert a frictional force on you.

answer.answertext: Your inertia which keeps you going.
answer.feedback: Inertia is not a force. It is the tendency of an object to resist having its velocity changed.

answer.answertext: A very small force of air drag.
answer.feedback: Yes. You are moving relative to the air so it should exert a drag force on you.
You are (presumably) on Earth, so there must be a gravitational force acting on you.

answer.answertext: A normal force exerted on the ice by you.
answer.feedback: Note that we are thinking about forces on you. We are going through the same thought process that we would while drawing a free body diagram. We are interested in the forces on you because these are the forces which affect your motion. Forces exerted by you do not affect your motion.

question.name: Identify forces on box (1)
question.questiontext: You kick a box. The box slides some distance across the floor after leaving contact with your foot. The forces acting on the box after it has left contact with your foot are (select all that apply)

answer.answertext: A force applied by your foot on the box.
answer.feedback: The force applied by your foot was acting on the box while you were kicking it (for the fraction of a second that your foot was in contact with the box). But once the box has left contact with your foot this force will no longer exist.

answer.answertext: Friction between the box and the floor.
answer.feedback: Yes, the box is sliding on the floor, so the floor must exert a frictional force on the box.
Yes, the box is (presumably) on Earth, so there must be a gravitational force on it.

answer.answertext: A normal force exerted on the box by the floor.
answer.feedback: Yes, the box is in contact with the floor so the floor must exert a normal force on it.

answer.answertext: The inertia of the box which keeps it sliding.
answer.feedback: Inertia is not a force. It is the tendency of an object to resist changes to its velocity.

answer.answertext: A very small force of air drag (which can probably be neglected).
answer.feedback: Yes, it is moving relative to the air so the air must exert a drag force on the box.

answer.answertext: A normal force exerted on the floor by the box.
answer.feedback: Note that the question asks for forces acting on the box. We are going through the thought process we would as we draw a free body diagram. We are thinking of all the forces exerted on the box. These forces will affect its motion. Forces exerted by the box do not affect its motion.

question.name: Identify forces on box (2)
question.questiontext: You are pulling a box across the floor using a rope. The forces acting on the box are (select all that apply)

answer.answertext: The tension force in the rope.
answer.feedback: Yes, the rope is in contact with the box so it must exert a tension force on it.

answer.answertext: Friction between the box and the floor.
answer.feedback: Yes, the box is sliding on the floor so the floor must exert a frictional force on the box.
Yes, the box is (presumably) on Earth, so there must be a gravitational force acting on it.

answer.answertext: A normal force exerted on the box by the floor.
answer.feedback: Yes, the box is in contact with the floor so the floor must exert a normal force on the box.

answer.answertext: A force equal to the mass of the box times its acceleration which keeps it sliding.
answer.feedback: The net force on the box must equal its mass times its accleration. But the net force is, by definition, just the sum of all the real forces on the box, not a force in and of itself.

answer.answertext: A very small force of air drag (which can probably be neglected).
answer.feedback: Yes, the box is moving relative to the air, so the air must exert a drag force on it.

answer.answertext: A normal force exerted on the floor by the box.
answer.feedback: Note that we are thinking about forces on the box. We are going through the same thought process that we would while drawing a free body diagram. We are interested in forces on the box because these are the forces that will affect the box's motion. Forces exerted by the box have no affect on the box's motion.

question.name: What is inertia?
question.questiontext: What is inertia?

answer.answertext: Inertia is the tendency of an object to resist any change to its velocity.
answer.feedback: Yes. All objects have inertia. All we mean by this is that, in the absence of forces, an object moves with consant velocity. So "objects have inertia" is just another way of stating Newton's 1st Law.

answer.answertext: Inertia is the force that tends to keep an object moving in the absence of other forces.
answer.feedback: Inertia is not a force. No force is needed to "keep an object moving". If an object is slowing down and stopping this must be caused by a force.

answer.answertext: Inertia is the same a weight.
answer.feedback: The weight is a force. Inertia is not a force.

answer.answertext: Inertia is the same as velocity.
answer.feedback: You would probably say that a car moving at 5 m/s has "more inertia" than a marble moving at 5 m/s. Since they have the same velocity but different "amounts of inertia" this indicates that inertia must not be the same as velocity. Careful though! Inertia isn't really something we quantify (i.e. we don't think of it as a measureable quantity that can have some number attached to it).

answer.answertext: Inertia is the same as momentum.
answer.feedback: Does an object at rest have inertia? Yes it does. To get it moving you need to "overcome its inertia". But an object at rest has no momentum. So inertia must not be the same as momentum. Careful though! Inertia isn't really something we quantify (i.e. we don't think of it as a measureable quantity that can have some number attached to it).

question.name: Why does an object stop?
question.questiontext: You give a book a hard push and it slides across the table. It eventually stops. The reason it stops is that

answer.answertext: There must be a force acting on it causing it to slow down.
answer.feedback: Yes. In this case it is a frictional force.

answer.answertext: There is no force acting on it to keep it moving.
answer.feedback:
If you push the same book on a very smooth surface it will slide farther. Does this mean that perhaps there is a force keeping it going in this case? Why would there be a force keeping it going in one case but not in the other? What would exert this force? Does this picture make sense?

What does Newton's 1st Law tell us? Is a force needed for an object to continue moving?

answer.answertext: Its "natural state" is to be at rest.
answer.feedback: Aristotle would agree with you. Newton would not. Newton's laws are consistent with experiment. What does Newton's 1st Law have to say about this?

answer.answertext: It eventually runs out of inertia.
answer.feedback:
The inertia is the tendency of an object to move with constant velocity. Can this tendency "run out"? Does it get easier to push when it has been moving for longer?

Does Newton's 1st Law have anything to say about this?

question.name: Is latex working?
question.questiontext:
Here is a latex expression:

$$y = mx^2 +b$$

did that work? How about in the answers?

question.name: line breaks around latex in answers?
question.questiontext:
The expression $$x^2$$ as opposed to x2 might cause some subtle formatting problems in Moodle.
This is after a line break.

Does this work?
<math>x^2</math>

How about this?
$$\begin{eqnarray} y & = & x^2 \\ z & = & x^3 \end{eqnarray}$$

How about 3 dollar signs? $$$x^2$$$

And one dollar sign? $x^2$

What about dollar signs with math invoked? $\begin{math}x^2\end{math}$

Double dollar signs with math invoked? $$\begin{math}x^2\end{math}$$

question.name: academic misconduct
question.questiontext: Which of the following are examples of academic misconduct (select all that apply)?

answer.feedback: Yes.

answer.answertext: Allowing another student to copy your work
answer.feedback: Yes. Help your fellow students. But don't damage their learning by doing their work for them.

answer.answertext: Copying and pasting from an online source into any document that you are submitting for marks
answer.feedback: Yes! And it's very easy for me to catch it.
No. Helping each other is encouraged.

answer.answertext: Receiving help from another student on an assignment
answer.feedback: No. Helping each other is encouraged.

answer.answertext: Asking the professor for help during an exam
answer.feedback: No. I'm happy to give clarifications of questions during the exams.

answer.answertext: Copying assignment solutions from solutions manuals or online sources such as "homework help" sites
answer.feedback: Yes. You learn nothing by doing this, so why would you do it anyway?

question.name: Completing a lesson
question.questiontext:
Each topic unit has an online lesson associated with it.  Except at the very beginning of the course, these lessons are always due at the start of the first class where we will cover that topic unit.  This is so that you are always doing the lessons ahead of us covering that material, so that you are ready to use the ideas during class.

5% of your mark in the course is for completion of the lessons.  What do you need to have done for a lesson to be counted as "complete"?  Check all that apply.

answer.answertext: Complete the online part of the lesson, answering some number of questions that the lesson asks.
answer.feedback: Yes.  Watch the videos, answer the questions.
Yes, follow the instructions and answer the questions that the lesson asks in the parts where it asks to do your written response.

answer.answertext: Submit your cheat sheet on moodle, with new material added to it related to the lesson.
answer.feedback: Yes.  This cheat sheet will be useful to you when you are working on assignments or writing exams.

answer.answertext: Get a passing grade (50%) on the online lesson.
answer.feedback: No.  The grade, for answering questions correctly in the lesson, is irrelevant to determining whether you have completed the lesson or not.  If you get a low grade then this indicates to you that you are not understanding the material and you should do some more studying to resolve this.  But I will not pay attention to the grade that moodle calculates when I am determining whether you completed the lesson.  The mark you receive is just for *doing* the lesson.

answer.answertext: Watch every minute of each video in the lesson.
answer.feedback: No.  Most of the time you probably *should* watch all of each video.  But, frankly, I have no way of knowing whether you did and so I can't use this to determine whether you completed the lesson.  If there are parts of the videos which are review for you from a previous course then perhaps you should *consider* skipping those parts.  However, I will probably explain things differently from how you saw them in earlier courses, so you will probably benefit from watching all of the videos, even parts that might be review.

question.name: Exam format
question.questiontext: What is the format of the exams and midterms?

answer.answertext: Two components: a written component with a breakout session where you get to discuss the exam with other students, and a one-on-one appointment to work through a problem with Geoff
answer.feedback: Yup.

answer.answertext: A public oral examination, open to the general public.
answer.feedback: No.  That's done a lot in Europe.  I don't think we could get away with it in North America.  Students would be terrified!
No.  By now you may be seeing that there is very little about this course that is "traditional"...

answer.answertext: Two components: A component done as a quiz on moodle, and a traditional written component.
answer.feedback: No.  The  main reason I would not do this is that I don't feel that moodle quizzes are an acceptable way to assess at the end of a course like this.

answer.answertext: Three components: A component done as a quiz on moodle, a one-on-one appointment to work through a problem with Geoff, and a take-home exam.
answer.feedback: No.  That's how I did it last year when we had to run the exams remotely.  While it worked, I would not do this in a face-to-face course, mostly because I do not believe moodle  quizzes are really acceptable as a final assessment in a course like this.

question.name: Handing in Assignments
question.questiontext: How many times should you be handing in each assignment?

answer.feedback: Yes.  The first stage will only be a selection of the parts of the assignment, is just for feedback, and is handed in on moodle.  The second stage is handed in on paper and will be marked for correctness.

answer.answertext: Once.  Duh!  What kind of question is this, Geoff?
answer.feedback: No, not "duh".  Look at the Course Outline again.

answer.answertext: As many times as you want,  until you get a perfect mark.
answer.feedback: That would be fabulous!  But unfortunately, no.  I would be totally overwhelmed with the marking if  I tried to do this.

opposite to the direction that the ball is moving
