question.name: How would you characterize your contribution to your group?
question.questiontext: How would you characterize your contribution to your group? Remember that you are judging how well you have contributed to the learning of your group. If you needed your group members to explain a lot of things to you this will have still contributed to the group members learning because of the discussions that will have resulted.

answer.answertext: poor (e.g. contributed little to the solution, and took little action to understand the solution)
fair (e.g. asked some questions that required other people to give an explanation of important concepts)
good (contributed to the solution, and/or asked lots of useful questions)
excellent (made major contributions to the solution, and/or asked questions which made others recognize their own misconceptions and correct them)

question.name: A hypothetical question re. not doing labs
question.questiontext: Imagine if you will that you have arrived at the end of the course. You have got perfect marks on all of the assignments, exams and other parts of the theory component of the course. However, you did not attend even a single lab. Simply computing your course mark tells you that your final mark is 75%. Do you pass the course?

answer.feedback: Right.  You need to pass both the theory and lab portions of the course to pass the course as a whole.
No.  Look at the explanation of the marks distribution in the course outline.

answer.answertext: Yes, you get 75%. But you were very naughty skipping those labs.
answer.feedback: No.  Look at the explanation of the marks distribution in the course outline.

question.name: Only doing the exam?
question.questiontext: Suppose the only thing you do in this course (other than write this quiz) is write the final exam and the midterm. What is the absolute maximum final mark you can achieve?

answer.answertext: 30%, if you get perfect on the exams
answer.feedback: Yup, that's what the exams add up to in the marking scheme.
Read the marking scheme.

answer.answertext: it depends on how good you are at begging
answer.feedback: Begging gets you nowhere.

answer.answertext: 50%. Surely Geoff couldn't fail you if you get over 90% on the final, right?
answer.feedback: Well, Geoff wouldn't have failed you. You would have failed you. Cramming for exams as the only thing you do in a course is a good way to guarantee that you will forget it all when the course is over. So I will not compromise on insisting that you work steadily throughout the course.

question.name: academic misconduct
question.questiontext: Which of the following are examples of academic misconduct (select all that apply)?

answer.feedback: Yes.

answer.answertext: Allowing another student to copy your work
answer.feedback: Yes. Help your fellow students. But don't damage their learning by doing their work for them.

answer.answertext: Copying and pasting from an online source into any document that you are submitting for marks
answer.feedback: Yes! And it's very easy for me to catch it.

answer.answertext: Helping another student on an assignment
answer.feedback: No. Helping each other is encouraged.

answer.answertext: Receiving help from another student on an assignment
answer.feedback: No. Helping each other is encouraged.

answer.answertext: Asking the professor for help during an exam
answer.feedback: No. I'm happy to give clarifications of questions during the exams.

answer.answertext: Copying assignment solutions from solutions manuals
answer.feedback: Yes. You learn nothing by doing this, so why would you do it anyway?

match.answertext: Hand in with no penalty if you have arranged to do so in advance. Hand in with one mark per day penalty otherwise.
Write at another time with valid reason for missing it.
Can't be made up, but not counted towards mark if missed for a valid reason.

question.name: Assignment policy

answer.answertext: Available as long as you ask before the due date

question.name: Assignment policy
question.questiontext: {1:MULTICHOICE:Chris will hunt you down~You will get zero~=You will get a one mark per day late penalty}

answer.answertext: You will get a one mark per day late penalty

question.name: Assignment policy
question.questiontext: {1:MULTICHOICE:Chris is an ogre~=Chris would rather get good assignments late than lousy ones on time}

answer.answertext: Chris would rather get good assignments late than lousy ones on time

question.name: A hypothetical question re. not doing labs
question.questiontext: Imagine if you will that you have arrived at the end of the course. You have got perfect marks on all of the assignments, exams and other parts of the theory component of the course. However, you did not attend even a single lab. Simply computing your course mark tells you that your final mark is 80%. Do you pass the course?

answer.answertext: Yes, you get 80%. But you were very naughty skipping those labs.

question.name: Only doing the exam?
question.questiontext: Suppose the only thing you do in this course is write the final exam and the midterm. What is the absolute maximum final mark you can achieve?

answer.answertext: 35%, if you get perfect on the exams
answer.feedback: Yup, that's what the exams add up to in the marking scheme.
Read the marking scheme.

answer.answertext: it depends on how good you are at begging
answer.feedback: Begging gets you nowhere.

answer.answertext: 50%. Surely Chris couldn't fail you if you get over 90% on the final, right?
answer.feedback: Well, Chris wouldn't have failed you. You would have failed you. Cramming for exams as the only thing you do in a course is a good way to guarantee that you will forget it all when the course is over. So I will not compromise on insisting that you work steadily throughout the course.

question.name: The moodle site
question.questiontext: The Moodle site for this course is

answer.answertext: Important. You should be using it regularly.
answer.feedback: Yup.

answer.answertext: Not important at all. Chris maintains it for kicks.
answer.feedback: Fun? Most things about teaching are fun. But maintaining online resources is not.

answer.answertext: Optional. It is just a supplement to the course.

answer.answertext: Physics for Lords and Knights, 3rd ed., by R. Engineer

answer.answertext: College Physics, 2nd ed. by Knight, Jones and Field
answer.feedback: This is the text for PHYS 1101/1201.

answer.answertext: Any old physics textbook you can find
answer.feedback: No, I've chosen the text carefully.
No, none of you are dummies.

question.name: academic misconduct
question.questiontext: Which of the following are examples of academic misconduct (select all that apply)?

answer.feedback: Yes.

answer.answertext: Allowing another student to copy your work
answer.feedback: Yes. Help your fellow students. But don't damage their learning by doing their work for them.

answer.answertext: Copying and pasting from an online source into any document that you are submitting for marks
answer.feedback: Yes! And it's very easy for me to catch it.

answer.answertext: Helping another student on an assignment
answer.feedback: No. Helping each other is encouraged.

answer.answertext: Receiving help from another student on an assignment
answer.feedback: No. Helping each other is encouraged.

answer.answertext: Asking the professor for help during an exam
answer.feedback: No. I'm happy to give clarifications of questions during the exams.

answer.answertext: Copying assignment solutions from solutions manuals
answer.feedback: Yes. You learn nothing by doing this, so why would you do it anyway?

question.name: A hypothetical question re. not doing labs
question.questiontext: Imagine if you will that you have arrived at the end of the course. You have got perfect marks on all of the assignments, exams and other parts of the theory component of the course. However, you did not attend even a single lab. Simply computing your course mark tells you that your final mark is 80%. Do you pass the course?

answer.answertext: Yes, you get 80%. But you were very naughty skipping those labs.

question.name: Only doing the exam?
question.questiontext: Suppose the only thing you do in this course (other than write this quiz) is write the final exam and the midterm. What is the absolute maximum final mark you can achieve?

answer.answertext: 40%, if you get perfect on the exams
answer.feedback: Yup, that's what the exams add up to in the marking scheme.
Read the marking scheme.

answer.answertext: it depends on how good you are at begging
answer.feedback: Begging gets you nowhere.

answer.answertext: 50%. Surely Geoff couldn't fail you if you get over 90% on the final, right?
answer.feedback: Well, Geoff wouldn't have failed you. You would have failed you. Cramming for exams as the only thing you do in a course is a good way to guarantee that you will forget it all when the course is over. So I will not compromise on insisting that you work steadily throughout the course.

question.name: A hypothetical question re. not doing labs
question.questiontext: Imagine if you will that you have arrived at the end of the course. You have got perfect marks on all of the assignments, exams and other parts of the theory component of the course. However, you did not attend even a single lab. Simply computing your course mark tells you that your final mark is 80%. Do you pass the course?

answer.answertext: Yes, you get 80%. But you were very naughty skipping those labs.

question.name: Only doing the exam?
question.questiontext: Suppose the only thing you do in this course (other than write this quiz) is write the final exam and the midterm. What is the absolute maximum final mark you can achieve?

answer.answertext: 40%, if you get perfect on the exams
answer.feedback: Yup, that's what the exams add up to in the marking scheme.
Read the marking scheme.

answer.answertext: it depends on how good you are at begging
answer.feedback: Begging gets you nowhere.

answer.feedback: Well, Geoff wouldn't have failed you. You would have failed you. Cramming for exams as the only thing you do in a course is a good way to guarantee that you will forget it all when the course is over. So I will not compromise on insisting that you work steadily throughout the course.

question.name: The moodle site
question.questiontext: The Moodle site for this course is

answer.answertext: Important. You should be using it regularly.
answer.feedback: Yup.

answer.answertext: Not important at all. Geoff maintains it for kicks.
answer.feedback: Fun? Most things about teaching are fun. But maintaining online resources is not.

answer.answertext: Optional. It is just a supplement to the course.

question.questiontext: The textbook for this course is

answer.answertext: College Physics, 3rd ed., by R. Knight, B. Jones and S. Field

answer.answertext: Physics for Knights, 3rd ed., by R. College

No, none of you are dummies.

question.name: Q1 - two metal balls dropped
question.questiontext: Two metal balls are the same size but one weighs twice as much as the other.The balls are dropped from the roof of a single story building at the same instant. The time it takes the balls to reach the ground below will be

answer.answertext: about half as long for the heavier ball as for the lighter one.
about half as long for the lighter ball as for the heavier one.
considerably less for the heavier ball, but not necessarily half as long.
considerably less for the lighter ball, but not necessarily half as long.

question.name: Q2 - two metal balls roll off table
question.questiontext:
The two metal balls of the previous problem roll off a horizontal table with the same
speed. In this situation

answer.answertext:
both balls hit the floor at approximately the same horizontal distance from the
base of the table.

the heavier ball hits the floor at about half the horizontal distance from the base
of the table than does the lighter ball.

the lighter ball hits the floor at about half the horizontal distance from the base
of the table than does the heavier ball.

the heavier ball hits the floor considerably closer to the base of the table than the
lighter ball, but not necessarily at half the horizontal distance.

the lighter ball hits the floor considerably closer to the base of the table than the
heavier ball, but not necessarily at half the horizontal distance.

question.name: Q3 - stone dropped from roof
question.questiontext: A stone dropped from the roof of a single-story building to the surface of Earth

answer.answertext:
reaches a maximum speed quite soon after release and then falls at a constant
speed thereafter.

speeds up as it falls because the gravitational attraction gets considerably stronger
as the stone gets closer to Earth.
speeds up because of an almost constant force of gravity acting upon it.
falls because of the natural tendency of all objects to rest on the surface of Earth.

falls because of the combined effects of the force of gravity pushing it downward
and the force of the air pushing it downward.

question.name: Q4 - truck collides with compact car
question.questiontext: A large truck collides head-on with a small compact car. During the collision

answer.answertext:
the truck exerts a greater amount of force on the car than the car exerts on the
truck.

the car exerts a greater amount of force on the truck than the truck exerts on the
car.

neither exerts a force on the other, the car gets smashed simply because it gets in
the way of the truck.
the truck exerts a force on the car but the car does not exert a force on the truck.
the truck exerts the same amount of force on the car as the car exerts on the truck.

question.name: Q5 - forces on ball in circular channel
question.questiontext:
Use the statement and figure below to answer the next two questions (5 and 6).

The figure shows a frictionless channel in the shape of a segment of a circle with its center at O. The channel has been anchored to a frictionless horizontal table top. You are looking down at the table.  Forces exerted by the air are negligible. A ball is shot at high speed into the channel at P and exits at R.

Consider the following distinct forces:
A. a downward force of gravity.
B. a force exerted by the channel pointing from Q to O.
C. a force in the direction of motion.
D. a force pointing from O to Q.

Which of the above forces is (are) acting on the ball when it is within the frictionless channel at position Q?

question.name: Q6 - ball in circular channel, path after leaving
question.questiontext: Which of the paths 1–5 below would the ball most closely follow after it exits the channel at R and moves across the frictionless table top?

question.name: Q7 - ball on string, string breaks
question.questiontext:
A steel ball is attached to a string and is swung in a circular path in a horizontal
plane as illustrated in the figure below.

At point P, the string suddenly breaks near the ball.
If these events are observed from directly above, which of the paths 1–5 would
the ball most closely follow after the string breaks?

question.name: Q8 - hockey puck kicked
question.questiontext:
Use the statement and figure below to answer the next four questions (8–11).

The figure depicts a hockey puck sliding with constant speed vo in a straight line from point to P to point Q on a frictionless horizontal surface. Forces exerted by the air are negligible. You are looking down on the puck. When the puck reaches point Q, it receives a swift horizontal kick in the direction of the heavy print arrow. Had the puck been at rest at point P, then the kick would have set the puck in horizontal motion with a speed vk in the direction of the kick.

Which of the paths 1–5 below would the puck most closely follow after receiving the kick?

question.name: Q9 - hockey puck kicked - speed
question.questiontext: The speed of the puck just after it receives the kick is

answer.answertext: equal to the speed vo it had before it received the kick.
equal to the speed vk resulting from the kick and independent of the speed vo.
equal to the arithmetic sum of the speeds vo and vk.
smaller than either of the speeds vo or vk.
greater than either of the speeds vo or vk, but less than the arithmetic sum of these two speeds.

question.name: Q10 - puck kicked - speed change after kick
question.questiontext: Along the frictionless path you have chosen in question 8, the speed of the puck after receiving the kick

answer.answertext: increases for a while and decreases thereafter.
is constant for a while and decreases thereafter.

question.name: Q11 - puck kicked - forces
question.questiontext: Along the frictionless path you have chosen in question 8, the main force(s) acting on the puck after receiving the kick is (are)

answer.answertext: a downward force of gravity, and a horizontal force in the direction of motion.
a downward force of gravity, an upward force exerted by the surface, and a horizontal force in the direction of motion.
a downward force of gravity and an upward force exerted by the surface.

question.name: Q12 - cannon ball
question.questiontext: A ball is fired by a cannon from the top of a cliff as shown below. Which of the paths 1–5 would the cannon ball most closely follow?

question.name: Q13 - ball thrown straight up, forces
question.questiontext: A boy throws a steel ball straight up. Consider the motion of the ball only after it has left the boy’s hand but before it touches the ground, and assume that forces exerted by the air are negligible. For these conditions, the force(s) acting on the ball is (are)

answer.answertext: a downward force of gravity along with a steadily decreasing upward force.

a steadily decreasing upward force from the moment it leaves the boy’s hand until it reaches its highest point; on the way down there is a steadily increasing downward force of gravity as the ball gets closer to Earth.

an almost constant downward force of gravity along with an upward force that steadily decreases until the ball reaches its highest point; on the way down there is only an almost constant downward force of gravity.
an almost constant downward force of gravity only.
none of the above. The ball falls back to ground because of its natural tendency to rest on the surface of the Earth.

question.name: Q14
question.questiontext:
A bowling ball accidentally falls out of the cargo bay of an airliner as it flies along in a horizontal direction.

As observed by a person standing on the ground and viewing the plane as in the figure below, which of the paths 1–5 would the bowling ball most closely follow after leaving the airplane?

question.name: Q15 - car pushing truck
question.questiontext:
Use the statement and figure below to answer the next two questions (15 and 16).

A large truck breaks down out on the road and receives a push back into town by a small compact car as shown in the figure below.

While the car, still pushing the truck, is speeding up to get up to cruising speed,

answer.answertext: the amount of force with which the car pushes on the truck is equal to that with which the truck pushes back on the car.
the amount of force with which the car pushes on the truck is smaller than that with which the truck pushes back on the car.
the amount of force with which the car pushes on the truck is greater than that with which the truck pushes back on the car.

the car’s engine is running so the car pushes against the truck, but the truck’s engine is not running so the truck cannot push back against the car. The truck is pushed forward simply because it is in the way of the car.
neither the car nor the truck exerts any force on the other. The truck is pushed forward simply because it is in the way of the car.

question.name: Q16 - car pushes truck, cruising speed
question.questiontext: After the car reaches the constant cruising speed at which its driver wishes to push the truck,

answer.answertext: the amount of force with which the car pushes on the truck is equal to that with which the truck pushes back on the car.
the amount of force with which the car pushes on the truck is smaller than that with which the truck pushes back on the car.
the amount of force with which the car pushes on the truck is greater than that with which the truck pushes back on the car.

the car’s engine is running so the car pushes against the truck, but the truck’s engine is not running so the truck cannot push back against the car. The truck is pushed forward simply because it is in the way of the car.
neither the car nor the truck exerts any force on the other. The truck is pushed forward simply because it is in the way of the car.

question.name: Q17 -
question.questiontext: An elevator is being lifted up an elevator shaft at a constant speed by a steel cable as shown in the following figure. All frictional effects are negligible. In this situation, forces on the elevator are such that

answer.answertext: the upward force by the cable is greater than the downward force of gravity.
the upward force by the cable is equal to the downward force of gravity.
the upward force by the cable is smaller than the downward force of gravity.
the upward force by the cable is greater than the sum of the downward force of gravity and a downward force due to the air.
none of the above. (The elevator goes up because the cable is being shortened, not because an upward force is exerted on the elevator by the cable).

question.name: Q18 - boy on swing
question.questiontext:
The following figure shows a boy swinging, starting at a point higher than P.

Consider the following distinct forces:

A. a downward force of gravity.
B. a force exerted by the rope pointing from P to O.
C. a force in the direction of the boy’s motion.
D. a force pointing from O to P.

Which of the above forces is (are) acting on the boy when he is at position P?

question.name: Q19 - two blocks, motion diagrams
question.questiontext:
The positions of two blocks at successive 0.20-s time intervals are represented by the numbered squares in the following figure. The blocks are moving toward the right.

Do the blocks ever have the same speed?

answer.answertext: Yes, at some time during the interval 3 to 4.

question.name: Q20 - two blocks, acceleration
question.questiontext:
The positions of two blocks at successive 0.20-s time intervals are represented by the numbered squares in the figure below. The blocks are moving toward the right.

The accelerations of the blocks are related as follows:

answer.answertext: The acceleration of A is greater than the acceleration of B.

The acceleration of A equals the acceleration of B. Both accelerations are greater
than zero.
The acceleration of B is greater than the acceleration of A.
The acceleration of A equals the acceleration of B. Both accelerations are zero.
Not enough information is given to answer the question.

question.name: Q21 - Spaceship paths
question.questiontext:
Use the statement and figure below to answer the next four questions (21 through 24).

A spaceship drifts sideways in outer space from point P to point Q as shown below. The spaceship is subject to no outside forces. Starting at position Q, the spaceship’s engine is turned on and produces a constant thrust (force on the spaceship) at right angles to the line PQ. The constant thrust is maintained until the spaceship reaches a point R in space.

Which of the paths 1–5 below best represents the path of the spaceship between points Q and R?

question.name: Q22 - spaceship speed
question.questiontext: As the spaceship moves from point Q to point R its speed is

answer.answertext: increasing for a while and constant thereafter.
constant for a while and decreasing thereafter.

question.name: Q23 - spaceship, engine off
question.questiontext: At point R, the spaceship’s engine is turned off and the thrust immediately drops to zero. Which of the paths 1–5 will the spaceship follow beyond point R?

question.name: Q24 - spaceship, speed with engine off
question.questiontext: Beyond position R the speed of the spaceship is

answer.answertext: increasing for a while and constant thereafter.
constant for a while and decreasing thereafter.

question.name: Q25 - constant force on box
question.questiontext: A woman exerts a constant horizontal force on a large box. As a result, the box moves across a horizontal floor at a constant speed vo.  The constant horizontal force applied by the woman

answer.answertext: has the same magnitude as the weight of the box.
is greater than the weight of the box.
has the same magnitude as the total force that resists the motion of the box.
is greater than the total force that resists the motion of the box.
is greater than either the weight of the box or the total force that resists its motion.

question.name: Q26 - double force on box
question.questiontext: If the woman in the previous question doubles the constant horizontal force that she exerts on the box to push it on the same horizontal floor, the box then moves

answer.answertext: with a constant speed that is double the speed vo in the previous question.
with a constant speed that is greater than the speed vo in the previous question, but not necessarily twice as great.
for a while with a speed that is constant and greater than the speed vo in the previous question, then with a speed that increases thereafter.
for a while with an increasing speed, then with a constant speed thereafter.

question.name: Q27 - stop force on box
question.questiontext: If the woman in question 25 suddenly stops applying a horizontal force to the block, then the block

answer.answertext: continues moving at a constant speed for a while and then slows to a stop.
increases its speed for a while and then starts slowing to a stop.

question.name: Q28 - students on chairs
question.questiontext:
In the following figure, student A has a mass of 75 kg and student B has a mass of 57 kg. They sit in identical office chairs facing each other.

Student A places his bare feet on the knees of student B, as shown. Student A then suddenly pushes outward with his feet, causing both chairs to move.

During the push and while the students are still touching one another,

answer.answertext: neither student exerts a force on the other.
student A exerts a force on student B, but B does not exert any force on A.
each student exerts a force on the other, but B exerts the larger force.
each student exerts a force on the other, but A exerts the larger force.
each student exerts the same amount of force on the other.

question.name: Q29 - office chair on floor
question.questiontext:
An empty office chair is at rest on a floor. Consider the following forces:

A. a downward force of gravity.
B. an upward force exerted by the floor.
C. a net downward force exerted by the air.

Which of the forces is (are) acting on the office chair?

answer.answertext: None of the forces. (Since the chair is at rest, there are no forces acting upon it.)

question.name: Q30 - tennis ball, wind
question.questiontext:
Despite a very strong wind, a tennis player manages to hit a tennis ball with her racquet so that the ball passes over the net and lands in her opponent’s court.

Consider the following forces:

A. a downward force of gravity.
B. a force by the “hit.”
C. a force exerted by the air.

Which of the above forces is (are) acting on the tennis ball after it has left contact with the racquet and before it touches the ground?

question_category.name: Default for New Quiz #0
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'New Quiz #0'.

question_category.name: Default for Online Part of In-Class Activity: Landing on an Alien World
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'Online Part of In-Class Activity: Landing on an Alien World'.

question_category.name: Questions for In-Class: Landing on an Alien World
question_category.info: These are for use in the Landing on an Alien World in-class activity.

question.name: First second of fall
question.questiontext: The probe has been released from rest.  Its retro thrusters are not firing during the first second of fall.  So, during this second it is falling with an acceleration of (3 m/s2, down).  Match the following quantities for the probe to their correct values.  In all cases we are considering "initial" to mean the beginning of this second (t = 0) and "final" to mean the end of this second (t = 1.0 s).

question_hint.hint:
One or more of your responses were incorrect (the incorrect ones have been cleared).  Discuss with your group partners and try again.  Common points of confusion:

  1. What does "average" mean?
  2. Pay attention to what we mean by "initial" and "final".
That's still not quite right.  Get Geoff to come over and give you some help.

question.name: Second second of fall
question.questiontext: You should have found that at the end of the second from t = 0 to t = 1.0 s the probe was moving at (3 m/s, down) and that it has gone down 1.5 m from where it started.  Suppose that in the next second (t = 1.0 s to t = 2.0 s) its retro thrusters are still not firing.  So, during this second it is falling with an acceleration of (3 m/s2, down) again.  Match the following quantities for the probe to their correct values.  In all cases we are considering "initial" to mean the beginning of this second (t = 1.0 s) and "final" to mean the end of this second (t = 2.0 s).

question_hint.hint:
One or more of your responses were incorrect (the incorrect ones have been cleared).  Discuss with your group partners and try again.  Common points of confusion:

  1. What does "average" mean?
  2. Pay attention to what we mean by "initial" and "final".
That's still not quite right.  Get Geoff to come over and give you some help.

question.name: Third second of fall
question.questiontext: You should have found that at the end of the second from t = 1.0 to t = 2.0 s the probe was moving at (6 m/s, down) and that it had gone down 6 m from where it was dropped.  Suppose that in the next second (t = 2.0 s to t = 3.0 s) its retro thrusters are firing.  So, during this second it is falling with an acceleration of (2 m/s2, up).  Match the following quantities for the probe to their correct values.  In all cases we are considering "initial" to mean the beginning of this second (t = 2.0 s) and "final" to mean the end of this second (t = 3.0 s).

question_hint.hint:
One or more of your responses were incorrect (the incorrect ones have been cleared).  Discuss with your group partners and try again.  Common points of confusion:

  1. What does "average" mean?
  2. Pay attention to what we mean by "initial" and "final".
  3. What happens when the velocity is down but the acceleration is up?
That's still not quite right.  Get Geoff to come over and give you some help.

question.name: phase at 0 (increasing) of sinusoidal wave
question.questiontext: A plane wave in 3D is represented by $$D(x, t) = A \sin{[kx - \omega t - \phi_0]}$$. The value of the phase of this expression when D(x,t) = 0 and D(x,t) is increasing is

question.name: phase difference between 0s
question.questiontext: A plane wave is represented by $$D(x, t) = A\sin{(kx - \omega t + \phi_0)}$$. The phase difference between a place where D(x, t) = 0 and is increasing and a place where D(x, t) = 0 and is decreasing is

question.name: wave near point source in 3D
question.questiontext: A speaker is acting, to a good approximation, as a point source of sound. Near the speaker the wave fronts of sound from the speaker are

question.name: wave far from source in 3D
question.questiontext: A speaker is acting, to a good approximation, as a point source of sound. Far from the speaker the wave fronts of sound from the speaker are

question.name: Intensity level from intensity
question.questiontext: If the sound intensity increases by a factor of 10 then the sound intensity level

question.name: phase at min. of sinusoidal wave
question.questiontext: A plane wave in 3D is represented by $$D(x, t) = A \sin{[kx - \omega t - \phi_0]}$$. The value of the phase of this expression at a minimum (where D(x,t) is at its greatest negative value) is

question.name: phase at max. of sinusoidal wave
question.questiontext: A sinusoidal wave in 3D is represented by $$D(x, t) = A \sin{[kx - \omega t - \phi_0]}$$. The value of the phase of this expression at a maximum (where D(x,t) is at its greatest positive value) is

question.name: kilowatt hours?
question.questiontext: A kilowatt hour is a unit of

question.name: current through wires due to different applied voltages
question.questiontext: A length of copper wire, A, is connected to a 1.5 V battery so that current flows through it. An identical wire, B, is connected to a 3.0 V battery . Which of the following is correct?

answer.answertext: The current through wire B will be greater than the current through wire A.
The current through wire B will be less than the current through wire A.
The current through wire B will be the same as the current through wire A.

question.name: inducing polarization on a ball
question.questiontext: A ping-pong ball wrapped in aluminum foil is very lightweight, but has a surface that is a good electrical conductor. You give an ebonite rod a negative charge by rubbing it with fur. You then bring it close to a ping-pong ball wrapped in foil which is hanging from an electically insulating string. Which statement describes the behaviour of the charges on the aluminum foil wrapped ping-pong ball?

answer.answertext: Some of the electrons on the ping-pong ball will be pushed from the side near to the ebonite rod to the side far from the ebonite rod.
Some of the electrons on the ping-pong ball will be pulled from the side far from the ebonite rod to the side near to the ebonite rod.
Some of the protons on the ping-pong ball will be pulled from the side far from the ebonite rod to the side near to the ebonite rod.
Some of the electrons on the ping-pong ball will be pushed from out of the ball and into the ground.
Nothing will happen to the charges on the ping-pong ball unless it is actually touched with the rod.

question.name: sort in increasing Ue
question.questiontext: The four diagrams, A through D, show several pairs of charges. Sort the pairs in order of increasing electrical potential energy.

question.name: flux through two loops (different sizes)
question.questiontext: The diagram below shows a uniform B field pointing out of the screen. Two square current loops, each carrying an identical current, I, are oriented in the plane of the screen. One square loop measures L on each side and the other measures 2L. The magnetic flux through the larger loop is

answer.answertext: 4 times the flux through the smaller loop.
2 times the flux through the smaller loop.
the same as the flux through the smaller loop.
1/2 (half) the flux through the smaller loop.
1/4 (a quarter) of the flux through the smaller loop.

question.name: flux through two loops (different angles)
question.questiontext: The diagram below shows a uniform B field pointing out of the screen. Two square current loops, each carrying an identical current, I, are shown. Loop A is oriented in the plane of the screen. Loop B is "side on" so that it is perpendicular to the screen and we see it from the side (so it looks like a line). Both loops measures L on each side. Which statement best describes the magnetic fluxes through the two loops?

answer.answertext: Loop A has a nonzero magnetic flux through it. The magnetic flux through loop B is zero.
The magnetic flux through A is zero. Loop B has a nonzero magnetic flux through it.
The magnetic flux is zero through both loops.
The magnetic flux is the same through both loops.
The magnetic flux through loop B is greater than the magnetic flux through A.

question.name: change flux (increase B)
question.questiontext: The diagram shows a loop of wire. The loop is not attached to a battery or other current source. The loop is in the plane of the screen. A uniform B field points out of the screen. At some instant the magnitude of the B field suddenly increases. It then remains constant at a new, higher, value. Which statement best describes the current in the wire.

answer.answertext: No current initially flows in the wire. When the B field increases a current will flow clockwise in the wire while it is increasing. No current flows once the B field reaches its new higher magnitude.

No current initially flows in the wire. When the B field increases a current will flow counterclockwise in the wire while it is increasing. No current flows once the B field reaches its new higher magnitude.
No current will flow in the wire at any time throughout this process.
A current flows clockwise in the loop while the B field is at its initial value. The current increases when the B field increases in magnitude.
A current flows counterclockwise in the loop while the B field is at its initial value. The current increases when the B field increases in magnitude.

question.name: inductor with const. I
question.questiontext: A circuit containing an inductor has a constant current, I. The potential drop across the inductor is

question.name: when does current flow?
question.questiontext: A solenoidal coil has no current flowing it but is connected to an ammeter. A permanent magnet is slowly inserted into the coil, left stationary in the solenoid for a while and then quickly pulled out. A current in the solenoid is detected by the ammeter at various times during this process. Which of the following best describes this current?

answer.answertext: A small current flows while the magnet is being slowly inserted. There is no current while the magnet is stationary in the solenoid. A larger current flows when the magnet is quickly withdrawn.
A large current flows while the magnet is being slowly inserted. There is no current while the magnet is stationary in the solenoid. A smaller current flows when the magnet is quickly withdrawn.
The current builds slowly as the magnet is inserted. The current remains high while the magnet is left in the solenoid. The current then quickly drops to zero as the magnet is withdrawn.
There is no current in the solenoid.

question.name: when does current flow (moving loop)?
question.questiontext: A loop of wire is held over the north pole of a permanent magnet. The loop is not connected to a battery or other current source but it is connected to an ammeter. The loop is moved slowly towards the magnet, held near it for a short time and then moved quickly away from it. Which of the following best describes the current in the loop?

answer.answertext: A small current flows in the loop when it is moved slowly towards the magnet. The current stops while the loop is held close to the magnet. A larger current flows when the loop is moved quickly away from the magnet.

A large current flows in the loop when it is moved slowly towards the magnet. The current stops while the loop is held close to the magnet. A smaller current flows when the loop is moved quickly away from the magnet.

The current increases as the loop is brought closer to the magnet. It remains at a high value while the loop is held close to the magnet. It then rapidly decreases when the loop is pulled quickly away from the magnet.
There is no current in the loop.

question.name: Where do electrons go in moving conductor?
question.questiontext: The diagram shows a square piece of copper (a very good conductor) moving to the right through a region where the magnetic field is directed out of the screen. The electrons in the piece of copper will

answer.answertext: collect at the top of the piece of copper.
collect at the bottom of the piece of copper.
collect at the back (left side) of the piece of copper.
collect at the front (right side) of the piece of copper.

question.name: continuity in a tube
question.questiontext: An incompressible fluid is flowing through a cylindrical tube of radius R. The tube constricts to a radius R/2. In the constriction, the speed of the fluid is

answer.answertext: greater than in the wider section of tube.
less than in the wider section of tube.
the same as in the wider section of tube.
unrelated to the speed in the wider section of tube.

question.name: laminar flow in a stream
question.questiontext:
You are standing by a stream watching it flow. It is fall and the trees
around the stream have been dropping their leaves into the stream. As
the leaves float past you note that the paths of any two leaves never cross.
This is an indication of

question.name: volume flow rate in a constriction
question.questiontext: An incompressible fluid is flowing through a cylindrical tube of radius R. The tube has a constriction in which its radius is reduced to R/2. The volume flow rate in the constricted part of the tube is

answer.answertext: the same as in the wider part.
less than in the wider part.
greater than in the wider part.
unrelated to the volume flow rate in the wider part.

question.name: continuity in a tube [2]
question.questiontext: An incompressible fluid is flowing through a cylindrical tube of radius R. The tube widens to a radius 2R. In the wider part, the speed of the fluid is

answer.answertext: greater than in the narrower section of tube.
less than in the narrower section of tube.
the same as in the narrower section of tube.
unrelated to the speed in the narrower section of tube.

question.name: Constants in incompressible fluid flow
question.questiontext: In the flow of a nonviscous, incompressible fluid there are two important quantities which are conserved. They are

answer.answertext: the volume of the fluid and the energy.
the volume of the fluid and the momentum.
the speed of the fluid and the energy.
the speed of the fluid and the momentum.

question.name: volume flow rate in a constriction [2]
question.questiontext: An incompressible fluid is flowing through a cylindrical tube of radius R. The tube widens to a radius of 2R. The volume flow rate in the wider part of the tube is

answer.answertext: the same as in the narrower part.
less than in the narrower part.
greater than in the narrower part.
unrelated to the volume flow rate in the narrower part.

question.name: lead vs. styrofoam
question.questiontext: In your right hand you have a 1.0 kg block of styrofoam. In your left hand you have a 0.010 kg block of lead. The density of the styrofoam is

answer.answertext: less than the density of the lead.
greater than the density of the lead.
the same as the density of the lead.

question.name: pressure - fluid squirting out of the side of a broken vessel
question.questiontext: A large tank of water has a crack in the wall near the bottom. Water sprays out of this hole at high speed because

answer.answertext: The pressure inside the tank is much greater than the pressure outside so the water is accelerated out the hole.
Gravity pulls very strongly on the water lower in the tank so it falls out of the crack faster.
The water deep in the tank is highly compressed by the pressure so it expands out the hole with great speed.
The water deep in the tank is moving very fast because of the high pressure, so it emerges from the crack with high speed.

question.name: definition of pressure
question.questiontext: Pressure is

question.name: which are fluids
question.questiontext:
Which of the following are fluids?
A: water
B: air
C: wood

question.name: principle difference between liquids and gases
question.questiontext: Which of the following statements is true?

answer.answertext: Gases and liquids are both fluids but a gas is much more compressible than a liquid.
A liquid is a fluid but a gas is not.
A gas is a fluid but a liquid is not.
Gases and liquids are both fluids but a gas flows more quickly than a liquid.
Gases and liquids are both fluids but a gas exerts pressure while a liquid does not.

question.name: Force due to air pressure
question.questiontext: Atmospheric pressure is 101.3 kPa. You have stretched a 1.0 m<sup>2</sup> membrane over the top of a container. The force exerted on this membrane by the air outside the container is

question.name: V is conserved (bulbs connected by tube)
question.questiontext: The diagram shows two balloons which are connected by a short tube. The balloons and tube are completely filled with water. If you squeeze balloon 1 causing V<sub>1</sub> to decrease then

answer.answertext: V<sub>2</sub> increases by the same amount that V<sub>1</sub> decreases.
V<sub>2</sub> decreases by the same amount as V<sub>1</sub>.
V<sub>2</sub> increases, but not by the same amount as V<sub>1</sub> decreases.
V<sub>2</sub> decreases, but not by the same amount as V<sub>1</sub>.

question.name: comparing density - water with water
question.questiontext: 1 kg of water occupies a volume of 1 L. 1000 kg of water occupies a volume of 1 m<sup>3</sup>. The density of the smaller quantity of water is

answer.answertext: the same as the density of the larger quantity.
less than the density of the larger quantity because the mass the smaller.
greater than the density of the larger quantity because the volume is smaller.
unrelated to the density of the larger quantity (we would need to know more to rank their densities).

question.name: How much fluid displaced?
question.questiontext: A piece of wood floats on the surface of water. How much water does the piece of wood displace?

answer.answertext: It displaces an amount of water whose weight is equal to the wood's weight.
It displaces an amount of water whose volume is equal to the wood's volume.
It displaces an amount of water whose volume is equal to the submerged volume of the wood.
It displaces an amount of water whose weight is equal to the weight of the submerged portion of the wood.

question.name: How do we find buoyant force?
question.questiontext: A brick sinks in water. Because it sinks, it displaces a volume of water equal to its own volume. The buoyant force acting on the brick is

answer.answertext: equal to the weight of the displaced water.
equal to the mass of the displaced water.
equal to the weight of the submerged portion of the brick.

question.name: Brick vs. styrofoam block
question.questiontext: A brick sinks in water. A styrofoam block of the same volume floats (so only as small portion of its volume is submerged). How do the buoyant forces on these two objects compare?

answer.answertext: The buoyant force on the brick is greater.
The buoyant force on the styrofoam block is greater.
The buoyant forces on the two objects are the same.

question.name: match fluid types
question.questiontext: Match the fluid type to its description.

match.questiontext: conforms to shape of container, has fixed volume
conforms to both the size and shape of its container

question.name: behaviour of colliding waves
question.questiontext: What happens to two waves as they run into each other?

answer.answertext: They pass through each other and the displacement of the medium is the sum of the displacements due to the individual waves.
They bounce off of each other.
They bounce off of each other and during the collision the displacement of the medium is the sum of the displacements due to the individual waves.
They pass through each other and the displacement of the medium is the displacement due to the larger wave.

question.name: cutting a magnet in half
question.questiontext: You have a bar magnet. It has a north end and a south end. The north end is attracted to the south pole of another magnet. The south end is repelled by the south pole of another magnet. What happens if you cut your bar magnet in half?

answer.answertext: Each end is a complete new magnet with a north pole and a south pole. The north end of each will be attracted to the south pole of another magnet. The south end of each will be repelled by the south pole of another magnet.

Each end is a new magnet. The entire end that was the north end will be attracted to the south pole of another magnet. The entire end that was the south end will be repelled by the south pole of another magnet.
The magnetic properties of the bar magnet are destroyed by cutting it in half.

question.name: monopoles?
question.questiontext: Magnetic monopoles

answer.answertext: are not known to exist, but might exist.

question.name: path integral for straight path through uniform field
question.questiontext:
The diagram shows a region of space with a uniform magnetic field of 3 T. A straight path, 2 m long, parallel to the field is indicated from point i to point f. Evaluate the path integral

$$\int_i^f \vec{B} \cdot d\vec{s}$$

question.name: magnetism in oxygen?
question.questiontext: Liquid oxygen is not normally magnetic, but when placed in a magnetic field it becomes temporarily magnetized (its magnetization disappears as soon as it is removed from the magnetic field). Given the explanation of magnetism in materials from this chapter of the text, which of the following explanations seems most likely for this phenomenon.

answer.answertext: The atoms of oxygen are magnetic, but they are not normally aligned, so their magnetic fields cancel. When placed in a magnetic field they line up and the oxygen becomes magnetized.
The atoms of oxygen are not normally magnetic, but they become magnetized when placed in a magnetic field.
The electrons in oxygen are not normally magnetic, but they become magnetized when placed in a magnetic field.

question.name: spectrum of hydrogen
question.questiontext: When a current is passed through it, a sample of hydrogen gas is seen to glow. It emits light at

question.name: how does an interferometer work?
question.questiontext: A Michelson interferometer produces interference fringes by

answer.answertext: splitting the light, passing the two beams through different distances and recombining them on a screen.
passing the light through a diffraction grating.
passing the light through a double slit.
combining light from two different sources.
creating a standing wave in a light beam.

question.name: correct expression for wave of specified omega and k [2]
question.questiontext: Which of the following expressions represents a wave moving in the positive x direction with a wavenumber of 2.0 m<sup>-1</sup> and an angular frequency of 0.5 s<sup>-1</sup>?

question.name: correct expression for wave of specified omega and lambda
question.questiontext: Which of the following expressions represents a wave moving in the positive x direction with a wavelength of 2.0 m and an angular frequency of 6.0 s<sup>-1</sup>?

question.name: correct expression for wave of specified omega and k [1]
question.questiontext: Which of the following expressions represents a wave moving in the positive x direction with a wavenumber of 5.0 m<sup>-1</sup> and an angular frequency of 6.0 s<sup>-1</sup>?

question.name: history from snapshot graph [2]
question.questiontext: In the box below is a snapshot graph of a wave moving to the left. Which of a), b) or c) is a correct history graph for a point at the origin?

answer.answertext: none of a), b) or c)

question.name: history from snapshot graph
question.questiontext: In the box below is a snapshot graph of a wave moving to the right. Which of a), b) or c) is a correct history graph for the point labeled A?

answer.answertext: none of a), b) or c)

question.name: colour is wavelength
question.questiontext: Two light sources have different colours, but are otherwise identical. What wave property is different for light from these sources?

answer.answertext: colour is not connected to any wave property

question.name: pitch from frequency
question.questiontext: A speaker produces a sound of some frequency and pressure amplitude. It then produces a second sound of the same pressure amplitude but higher frequency. How will the two sounds differ according to your hearing (assuming that you can hear)?

answer.answertext: The second sound will be higher pitched.
The second sound will be lower pitched.
The second sound will be louder (higher volume).
The second sound will be quieter (lower volume).
You will not hear any difference. The difference between the sounds could only be detected with a sonometer.

question.name: What travels in a sound wave?
question.questiontext: A speaker is playing a steady note. Sound waves are travelling from the speaker to your ears. What do we mean by "the sound wave is travelling"? i.e. what is actually moving from the speaker to your ear?

answer.answertext: compressions (regions of higher pressure and density) and rarefactions (regions of lower pressure and density)
crests and troughs just like in a water wave
disturbances which cause the molecules to move back and forth perpendicular to the direction of motion of the sound wave
molecules of the air move from the speaker to your ear in bunches that we identify as the wave crests.

question.name: what changes with frequency?
question.questiontext: You have two identical strings under the same tension. Each is connected to an oscillator which sends waves down the string. The oscillator on string A is set to a high frequency (say, 20 Hz). The oscillator on string B is set to a low frequency (say, 2 Hz). Which statement is most correct?

answer.answertext: The speeds of the waves on both strings are the same. The waves on string B have a longer wavelength.
The speeds of the waves on both strings are the same. The waves on string B have a shorter wavelength.
The waves on both strings have the same wavelength. The waves on string B move at a higher speed.
The waves on both strings have the same wavelength. The waves on string B move at a lower speed.

question.name: speeds of waves of different wavelength on string
question.questiontext: You are holding one end of a rope. You give the rope a short, sharp twitch so that a wave propagates down it. You then give it a slower twitch so that a longer wave propagates down the string. Which of the two waves travels faster?

answer.answertext: Both travel at the same speed
The wave produced by the short sharp twitch (the shorter wave) travels faster
The wave produced by the slower twitch (the longer wave) travels faster

question.name: wavelength from frequency
question.questiontext: You are holding the end of a rope. You move your hand back and forth repeatedly with a period of 1.0 s to produce a train of waves which propagate down the rope. You now move your hand back and forth repeatedly with a period of 0.5 s to produce a new train of waves. Which of these waves has the longer wavelength?

answer.answertext: The waves produced by the motion with a period of 1.0 s are longer than those produced with a period of 0.5 s.
The waves produced by the motion with a period of 0.5 s are longer than those produced with a period of 1.0 s.
Both sets of waves have the same wavelength.

question.name: direction of travel of ribbon on transverse wave
question.questiontext: The figure shows a snapshot of a wave travelling along a slinky. Suppose a ribbon were tied to one coil of the spring. As a wave passed by it which way would the ribbon move?

answer.answertext: the ribbon would travel along with the crest of the wave
the ribbon would not move at all

question.name: direction of travel of ribbon on longitudinal wave
question.questiontext: The figure shows a wave traveling along a slinky. Suppose a ribbon were tied to one coil of the slinky. As a wave passed by it which way would the ribbon move?

answer.answertext: the ribbon would be carried along with the "compression" part of the wave
the ribbon would not move at all

question.name: longitudinal and transverse waves on slinky
question.questiontext: Consider the two snapshots, A and B, of a slinky. Which of the following is true?

answer.answertext: A is a transverse wave, B is a longitudinal wave.
A is a longitudinal wave, B is a transverse wave.
A is a wave, B is not.
Neither A nor B are waves.

question.name: What is intensity?
question.questiontext: Intensity is a measure of

question.name: reducing intensity as you move away from a light
question.questiontext: You have a light meter and are measuring the output of a lightbulb. You measure the light intensity at a distance of 1.0 m. Now you move to 2.0 m from the light and measure the light intensity again. You should expect that the intensity at 2.0 m should be

answer.answertext: the same as the intensity at 1.0 m

question.name: diagram of wave interference [2]
question.questiontext: The diagram below shows two waves approaching each other on a string. Which of A, B, C or D represents the shape of the string as the waves pass through each other (while their centers are coinciding)?

question.name: diagram of wave interference
question.questiontext: The figure below shows two waves approaching each other on a string. Which of A, B, C or D represents the shape of the string as the waves pass through each other (while their centers are coinciding)?

question.name: wavelengths of standing waves on a string
question.questiontext: A string of length, L, is fixed (tied down) at both ends. Possible lengths of standing waves on this string are:

question.name: wavelengths of standing waves in a flute
question.questiontext: A flute is essentially a tube that is open at both ends (an "open-open" tube). The possible wavelengths of standing waves in a flute of length, L, are:

question.name: harmonics on a violin
question.questiontext: When the A string of a violin is played it vibrates at its fundamental frequency and produces a note at 440 Hz. If you gently touch the middle of the string you force there to be a node there so that the string vibrates in its second harmonic. This changes the frequency of vibration of the string to

answer.answertext: The frequency does not change, only the wavelength.

question.name: frequencies of harmonics of rope
question.questiontext: As you excite a rope to higher and higher harmonics the wavelengths of the standing waves on the rope become shorter and shorter. What happens to the frequency of vibration?

answer.answertext: The frequencies become higher as you excite higher harmonics.
The frequencies become lower as you excite higher harmonics.
The frequencies of all the harmonics are the same.
It depends on how you excite the harmonics.

question.name: wave fronts
question.questiontext: In each of the following figures the small blue circles indicate wave sources. In which of the following figures do the lines/curves show the wave fronts produced by this pair of sources?

question.name: pattern of nodes
question.questiontext: In each of the following figures the small blue circles indicate wave sources. In which of the following figures do the lines/curves show an antinode pattern that could be produced by this pair of sources?

question.name: antinode location
question.questiontext: The diagram below shows waves from two sources. The point marked A lies on

answer.answertext: neither a node nor an antinode
sometimes a node and sometimes an antinode (it switches back and forth)

question.name: node location
question.questiontext: The diagram below shows waves emanating from two sources. The point marked A lies on

answer.answertext: neither a node nor an antinode
sometimes a node and sometimes an antinode (it switches back and forth)

question.name: What is path length difference?
question.questiontext: You are investigating the interference between sounds produced by two speakers, speaker A and speaker B. You mark a point that you label P. The distance from A to P is 12 cm. The distance from B to P is 16 cm. What is the path length difference?

answer.answertext: The path length difference is just the distance between the speakers (not given).

question.name: Wavelength from fact of antinode at a point
question.questiontext: Two speakers a few meters apart are playing a single steady note and are in phase. As you walk around the speakers you note that there are places where you hear nothing (nodes) and others where the sound is loud (antinodes). You mark a position of an antinode and measure the distance to each speaker from that point. You find that the distances to the speakers differ by 30 cm. What is the longest wavelength of sound that the speakers could be producing?

question.name: Wavelength from fact of node at a point
question.questiontext: Two speakers a few meters apart are playing a single steady note and are in phase. As you walk around the speakers you note that there are places where you hear nothing (nodes) and others where the sound is loud (antinodes). You mark a position of an node and measure the distance to each speaker from that point. You find that the distances to the speakers differ by 30 cm. What is the longest wavelength of sound that the speakers could be producing?

question.name: condition for destructive interference
question.questiontext: The condition for perfect destructive interference by waves from identical sources is

question.name: constructive interference halfway between two speakers
question.questiontext: Two speakers separated by several meters are in phase with each other and are playing a constant note. As you walk along the line between them you notice that there are places where you hear nothing (nodes) and others where the note is loud (antinodes). Do you expect to find a node or an antinode exactly halfway between the speakers?

answer.answertext: depends on the wavelength of the sound

question.name: When is diffraction an important effect?
question.questiontext: Under what conditions is diffraction an important effect (i.e. under what conditions do we see it)?

answer.answertext: when a wave of any sort passes through an opening that is comparable in size to the wavelength of the wave
with water waves and other 2 or 3-D mechanical waves but not with light or sound.
with light or sound but not with water waves or other 2 or 3-D mechanical waves.
when a wave of any sort passes through an opening that is comparable in size to the amplitude of the wave
when a wave of any sort passes through an opening less than about 1/10 of a millimeter

question.name: pattern from large hole vs. pattern from pinhole
question.questiontext:
Light from a small, bright, single-wavelength lamp is passed through a
2.0 cm diameter hole and projected onto screen A. Light from the same
lamp is passed through a 0.1 mm pinhole onto screen B. What will be
seen on the screens?

answer.answertext:
Screen A will show a sharp-edged, round spot of light but screen B
will show alternating rings of light and dark.
Both screens will show sharp edged, round spots of light.
Both screens will show alternating rings of light and dark.

Screen A will show alternating rings of light and dark but screen B
will show a sharp-edged, round spot of light.
Screen A will show a sharp-edged, round spot of light, but the light will be unable to pass through such a small pinhole so screen B will show nothing.

question.name: reason for interference from single slit
question.questiontext: Light passing through a single slit refracts (the wave fronts spread out behind the slit). It produces an interference pattern because

answer.answertext: light leaving from anywhere in the slit can interfere with light half of the slit spacing away (a/2).
light leaving from one side of the slit interferes with light leaving from the other side of the slit.
the two sides of the slit act like two sources, just like a double slit would.
the light simply does not diffract through some angles so there are dark bands.

question.name: effect of narrowing a single slit
question.questiontext: Light shines through a single, narrow, slit and produces a single slit interference pattern. If the width of the slit were adjustable, what would happen to the interference pattern as you made the slit narrower?

answer.answertext: The fringes would move farther apart.
The fringes would move closer together.
It depends on the wavelength of the light.

question.name: what happens to waves passing through narrow opening?
question.questiontext: Water waves pass into a narrow opening (the width of the opening is similar to the wavelength of the waves). The waves that leave the opening on the other side

answer.answertext: are the same shape as they were before they passed through the opening
are essentially nonexistent (they don't pass through the opening well)

question.name: term for waves spreading after passing through hole
question.questiontext:
Light or other waves spreading after passing through an opening is
called

question.name: light of two wavelengths through diffraction grating
question.questiontext: Light of two different colours passes through a diffraction grating. On the screen behind the grating you will see

answer.answertext: two interference patterns with different spacings - one in each colour of light that was passed through the grating.
one interference pattern in a colour that is the combination of the of the two colours of light that passed through the grating.
nothing (the two light beams will interfere and cancel each other out).

question.name: interference pattern dependence on slit separation
question.questiontext:
A laser shines on an adjustable double slit (the slit separation, d, can
be changed). If the slit separation is increased while the laser shines on
the double slit then the fringes in the interference pattern will

answer.answertext: The fringes close to the middle will move closer together and the ones towards the edges of the pattern will move farther apart.

question.name: path length difference on m = 2 fringe
question.questiontext: Light of wavelength, $$\lambda$$, arriving at a bright fringe in a double slit interference pattern is a mix of light from the two slits. The light from one slit has traveled slightly farther than the light from the other slit. The difference in the path lengths from the two slits to the m = 2 bright fringe is:

answer.answertext: We don’t know without knowing the slit separation.

question.name: path length difference on m = 1 dark fringe
question.questiontext: Light of wavelength, $$\lambda$$, arriving at a dark fringe in a double slit interference pattern is a mix of light from the two slits. The light from one slit has traveled slightly farther than the light from the other slit. The difference in the path lengths from the two slits to the m = 1 dark fringe is:

answer.answertext: We don’t know without knowing the slit separation.

question.name: source of charges on silk shirt in the wash
question.questiontext: Your silk shirt develops a negative charge while being run through the dryer. This could be a result of (select all that are possible)

answer.answertext: negative molecular ions being transferred from your other clothes onto the silk shirt.
positive molecular ions being transferred from the silk shirt onto your other clothes
negative molecular ions being transferred from your silk shirt to your other clothes.
new electrons being formed on the silk shirt during the drying process.
protons in the silk shirt being transformed to electrons.

question.name: transfer of positive charge to metal sphere
question.questiontext: When a metal sphere is touched with a positively charged glass rod it gains a positive charge. This is a result of

answer.answertext: electrons being transferred from the metal sphere to the glass rod
electrons being transferred from the glass rod to the metal sphere
protons being produced on the metal sphere
protons being transferred from the glass rod to the metal sphere
electrons being destroyed in the metal sphere

question.name: charge conserved on polarized object
question.questiontext: A negatively charged acrylic rod is brought close to a small metal ball which is initially neutral. The ball is polarized as a result and is attracted to the rod. The ball is well insulated from its surroundings. The net charge on the ball while the rod is near it is

question.name: metal spheres with equal and opposite charges touching
question.questiontext:
A metal sphere is charged with a charge of 0.2 C. A second metal
sphere is charged with -0.2 C. If the spheres are touched together what
will be the charge on the first sphere?

answer.answertext: It will simultaneously have charges of 0.2 C and -0.2 C.

question.name: force between charges at different distances [1]
question.questiontext: Two small metal spheres (approximately point charges) have been charged with unknown charges. They are placed 0.10 m apart and it is found that they exert an attractive force of 1.0 N on each other. If the metal spheres are moved so that the separation between them is 0.20 m then the force between them should be

question.name: force between charges at different distances [2]
question.questiontext: Two small metal spheres (approximately point charges) have been charged with unknown charges. They are placed 0.20 m apart and it is found that they exert an attractive force of 1.0 N on each other. If the metal spheres are moved so that the separation between them is 0.10 m then the force between them should be

question.name: like charged spheres
question.questiontext: You rub an ebonite rod with fur so that the rod is negatively charged. You touch the rod to a ping-pong ball wrapped in aluminum foil that is hanging from the ceiling by a thread. You now rub the ebonite rod again and touch it to another aluminum-wrapped ping-pong ball. When the two ping-pong balls are brought close together

answer.answertext: they repel each other (they are pushed apart).
they attract each other (they are pulled together).
there is no force between them.
there may be a force between them, but we cannot know without knowing more about the charges on each.

question.name: differently charged spheres
question.questiontext: You rub an ebonite rod with fur so that the ebonite rod is negatively charged (thus, the fur is now positively charged). You touch the (negative) ebonite rod to a ping-pong ball wrapped in aluminum foil that is hanging from the ceiling by a thread. You touch a second aluminum-wrapped ping-pong ball with the (positive) fur. When the two ping-pong balls are brought close together

answer.answertext: they attract each other (they are pulled together).
they repel each other (they are pushed apart).
there is no force between them.
there may be a force between them, but we cannot know without knowing more about the charges on each.

question_category.name: trios - concluding relative signs of charges

question.name: three balls all repelling
question.questiontext: Metal balls A, B and C are charged in various ways. Once charged it is found that A and B repel each other and that B and C also repel each other. From this we can conclude that

answer.answertext: All three metal balls carry charges of the same sign.
A and C have charges of the same sign, but B has the opposite sign.
A and B have charges of opposite sign, and B and C have charges of the opposite sign.
One of the balls has zero charge.
We would have to do more tests to determine anything about the charges.

question.name: three balls, 2 pairs attracting
question.questiontext: Metal balls A, B and C are charged in various ways (we verify that they are all charged - none of them are neutral). Once charged it is found that A and B attract each other and that B and C attract each other. A and C should therefore

answer.answertext: exert no force on each other.
we need to do more tests to determine how A and C would interact.

question.name: charges on rods with same linear charge density
question.questiontext: Two rods have the same linear charge density. Rod A is twice as long as rod B. If the net charge on rod B is Q then the net charge on rod A is

answer.feedback: Yes, because $$Q = \lambda L$$ where $$\lambda$$ is the linear charge density and $$L$$ is the length.
The rods have the same linear charge density, where linear charge density is charge per unit length. But the rod's lengths are different, so their total charges should be different.
Why would doubling the length quadruple the charge if the rods have the same charge density? This would suggest that the charge is proportional to the length squared. Does this make sense?
The rods have the same charge density. So if one of them has a positive charge then the other one must also have a positive charge.
The rods have the same charge density (charge per unit length). Given this, shouldn't the longer rod have more more charge on it in total?

question.name: charges on spheres with same charge density
question.questiontext: Two charged spheres have the same surface charge density. Sphere A is twice the radius of sphere B. If the net charge on sphere B is Q then the net charge on sphere A is

answer.feedback: Yes, because $$Q = \eta A$$ where $$\eta$$ is the charge density and A is the area. The area is proportional to the radius squared so doubling the radius should quadruple the area (and thus quadruple the charge).
Certainly increasing the size of the sphere should increase the charge. But the spheres have the same charge density (charge per unit area). When you double the radius what happens to the area?
The spheres have the same charge density (charge per unit area). Increasing the radius would increase the area. So shouldn't it increase the charge as well?
The spheres have the same charge density. So if one has a positive charge then the other one should as well.
The spheres have the same charge density (charge per unit area). Increasing the radius ought to increase the area. So shouldn't it increase the charge as well?

question.name: charge densities on rods with different length and same charge
question.questiontext: Two rods carry the same charge. Rod A is twice as long as rod B. If the charge density on rod A is $$\lambda$$ then the charge density on rod B is

answer.feedback: Yes, because $$Q = \lambda L$$ where $$\lambda$$ is the linear charge density and $$L$$ is the length.
The rods have the same charge. Remember that linear charge density is charge per unit length. But the rods' lengths are different, so their charge densities should be different.

Why would cutting the length in half have the effect of quadrupling the charge density if the rods have the same charge? This would suggest that the charge is proportional to the length squared. Does this make sense?
The rods have the same charge. So if one of them has a positive charge density then the other one must also have a positive charge density.
The rods have the same charge. Given this, shouldn't the shorter rod have a larger charge density (the same charge packed into a smaller space)?

question.name: E field of negative spherical charge

question.name: motion of charge in uniform field
question.questiontext: A charged object moves in a region of space with a uniform electrical field. Its motion will be

answer.feedback: Yes, the field is constant so the electrical force constant. A constant force results in a constant acceleration.
The field is constant. So the electrical force acting on the charge will be constant. What sort of motion results from a constant force?

This would require a constant (magnitude) force acting inward towards the center of the circular path. But this field (and hence the electrical forces that result from it) is constant both in magnitude and in direction.

answer.answertext: restricted to being in the direction that the field points in
answer.feedback: The field causes a force (in the direction of the field or opposite the direction of the field, depending on the sign of the charge). We have seen that objects do not always move in the direction of the net force on them.

question.name: two charges with same ratio of mass to charge
question.questiontext: A particle with charge +2 nC and mass 2 mg is placed in a region with a constant electric field. Its acceleration is measured. Now a particle with a charge of +1 nC and mass 1 mg is placed at the same location. We should expect that

answer.answertext: it will have the same acceleration that the first particle did.
answer.feedback: Yes, the second particle experiences only half of the force of the first one, but it also has half of the mass. So the resulting acceleration is the same.

answer.answertext: it will have a higher acceleration than the first particle did.
answer.feedback: Note that the second particle has a smaller charge and is placed in the same field. What does this tell you about the force acting on it compared to the force acting on the first particle?

answer.answertext: it will have a smaller acceleration than the first particle did.
answer.feedback: No. The second particle does have a smaller force acting on it than the first particle, because it has a smaller charge and is placed in the same field. But the second particle is also less massive than the first one. What does this tell us about the resulting acceleration?
The electric field exerts a force on the particle and there is no other force opposing it. So the particle must accelerate.

question.name: test charges with different masses
question.questiontext: Probe charge A is placed between two charged plates. The electrical force on it, F<sub>A</sub>, and its acceleration, a<sub>A</sub> are measured. Probe charge B has the same charge as probe charge A, but a greater mass than probe charge A. It is now placed between the plates. Which of the following is true?

answer.feedback: Yes, they have the same charge and they are placed in the same field so the forces acting on them are the same. But the more massive one will experience a smaller acceleration as a result of this force.
You are correct that the forces will be the same (the charges are the same and they are placed in the same field). But how does a more massive object behave when subjected to the same force?
No. The charges are the same and they are placed in the same field. What does this tell us about the forces they experience?
No. The charges are the same and they are placed in the same field. What does this tell us about the forces they experience?

answer.answertext: We need to know the strength of the field between the plates.
answer.feedback: No. If we wanted numerical values for the forces and accelerations then we would need this. But the information given is enough to come to some conclusions. The charges are the same and they are placed in the same field. What does this tell us about the forces they experience?

Probe charge B has the same mass as probe charge A, but a greater charge than probe charge A. It is now placed between the plates. Which of the following is true?

answer.feedback: Yes. The second charge has a larger charge and is placed in the same field. So the force exerted on it is larger. It has the same mass, so the larger force results in a larger acceleration.
No. The second particle has a larger charge and is placed in the same field. What does this tell you about the force that acts on it?

question.name: field due to rod at point perpendicular to center (positive)
question.questiontext: The figure shows a rod with uniform charge density. Point A lies on a line that is perpendicular to the rod and bisects it (intersects the rod halfway along its length). If the charge on the rod is positive then what is the direction of the electric field at point A?

answer.answertext: straight to the right (directly away from the rod)
answer.feedback: Yes. The vertical components of the field due to the parts of the rod above and below the dotted line must cancel (by symmetry). The rod is positive so it will repel a positive test charge.

answer.answertext: straight to the left (directly towards the rod)

answer.answertext: straight to the left (directly towards the rod)
