question.name: Description of field inside a parallel plate capacitor
question.questiontext: Which statement best describes the electrical field inside a parallel-plate capacitor?

answer.answertext: The field is uniform (same strength and direction everywhere) and points from the positive plate to the negative plate.
answer.feedback: Yes. As long as we can approximate the plates as infinite this is true. A positive test charge would be repelled from the positive plate and attracted towards the negative one.

answer.answertext: The field is uniform (same strength and direction everywhere) and points from the negative plate to the positive plate.
answer.feedback: As long as we can approximate the plates as infinite then the field is certainly uniform. But which way would a force be exerted on a positive test charge placed between the plates?

answer.answertext: The field is strongest near the positive plate and gets progressively weaker as you move towards the negative plate.
answer.feedback: No. Recall that in a parallel plate capacitor we can approximate the plates as infinite. What is the field due to an infinite plane like?

answer.answertext: The field is strongest near either plate and is weakest in the very middle.
answer.feedback: No. Recall that in a parallel plate capacitor we can approximate the plates as infinite. What is the field due to an infinite plane like?

question.name: Field near a piece of plastic
question.questiontext: A thin, square sheet of acrylic, about 10 cm on each side, is lying flat on a table top. It was recently rubbed with wool and has picked up a uniform charge density on its surface as a result. As the text says, if we are very near a surface then we can approximate the surface as an infinite plane. If we test the electric field strength at a point 0.1 mm from the surface and test it again 0.2 mm from the surface we should find that

answer.answertext: The field strength at 0.2 mm is about the same as the field strength at 0.1 mm.
answer.feedback: Yes. For very short distances from any object (short compared to the size of the object) the object "looks like" an infinite plane.

answer.answertext: The field strength at 0.2 mm is significantly less than the field strength at 0.1 mm.
answer.feedback: No. Think of what the Earth looks like from your perspective. When you stand outside can you tell that the Earth is round? When we are sufficiently close to any object, what does that object "look like"?

answer.answertext: The field strength at 0.2 mm is significantly more than the field strength at 0.1 mm.
answer.feedback: No. Think of what the Earth looks like from your perspective. When you stand outside can you tell that the Earth is round? When we are sufficiently close to any object, what does that object "look like"?

answer.answertext: Without knowing the charge density we cannot make any conclusions.
answer.feedback: We can't calculate a numerical value for the field strength. But there are properties of the field (i.e. how it varies with position) that we can state knowing only what is given.

This question consists of some text with an answer embedded right here {#1} and right after that you will have to deal with this short answer {#2} and finally we have a floating point number {#3}.

a) How good is this? {#4}
b) What grade would you give it? {#5}

Good luck!

What will be the ultimate fate of the universe? Provide enough details that someone with sufficient access to resources could build a 1:1 scale model of the final moments of the universe following your description. Your description should be accurate down to the level of quarks.

Extra credit: extend your description to length scales smaller than quarks.

question.name: electron current is the same everywhere (thin to thick)

A number Ne electrons pass through a cross section of the thin wire in a second. The number passing through a cross section of the thick section of wire per second should be

answer.answertext: N<sub>e</sub> (the same as in the thin section of wire)
Less than in the thick section of wire
Greater than in the thick section of wire

question.name: is current "used up"
question.questiontext: The diagram shows a very simple circuit consisting of a battery connected to a lightbulb by two wires, A and B. Which wire, A or B, has a larger current running through it?

answer.answertext: The currents in A and B are equal
The current in A is greater
The current in B is greater
It depends on how thick the wires are

question.name: electron current is the same everywhere
question.questiontext: This question may sound suspiciously like a fluid flow question, and conceptually it is very similar. A wire is shown which narrows from a wide part to a narrow part. A number Ne electrons pass through a cross section of the thick wire in a second. The number passing through a cross section of the thin section of wire per second should be

answer.answertext: N<sub>e</sub> (the same as in the thick section of wire)
Less than in the thick section of wire
Greater than in the thick section of wire

question_category.name: conceptual model of current in a wire

question.name: reason for flow in a wire
question.questiontext: An electrical current in a wire is sustained by an electric field in the wire. If this electrical field is suddenly "shut off" the current stops because

answer.answertext: The electrons suffer frequent collisions with the atoms in the wire whether the field is turned on or off and this has an effect similar to a drag force.
With no push from the electric field the electrons stop moving.
The electrons collide more often with the atoms in the wire once the field is turned off so they can't get anywhere.
With no electric field, gravity dominates and the electrons just "pool" in the bottom surface of the wire.

question.name: nature of motion in electrons flowing in a wire
question.questiontext: A current in a wire is sustained by an electrical field. The motion of an individual conduction electron in the wire is best described as

answer.answertext: frequent collisions with atoms causing random motion, with a constant acceleration due to the field superimposed on this random thermal motion
constant speed in the direction of the electrical field
constant speed opposite the direction of the electrical field
constant acceleration opposite the direction of the electrical field
frequent collisions with atoms causing random motion with a constant speed in the direction of the field superimposed on top of this.

question.name: comparing drift velocities (same current, different metals)
question.questiontext: A 1 mm thick copper wire has a conduction-electron density of 8.5 X 10<sup>28</sup> m<sup>-3</sup>. A 1 mm thick aluminum wire has a conduction electron density of 6.0 X 10<sup>28</sup> m<sup>-3</sup>. Suppose the wires are hooked up end to end and attached to a battery so that the electron current must be the same in both wires. The drift velocity of electrons in the aluminum wire must be

answer.answertext: greater than the drift velocity in the copper wire
less than the drift velocity in the copper wire
the same as the drift velocity in the copper wire

moves at constant speed in a circle in the plane of the page.
curves upward until it is moving parallel to the magnetic field, then moves in a straight line speeding up.
curves downward until it is moving parallel to the magnetic field, then moves in a straight line speeding up.
moves in a straight line at constant speed.

into the screen (i.e. away from you).

down (i.e. opposite to the motion of the charge).

into the screen (i.e. away from you).
up (i.e. in the direction of the magnetic field).
down (i.e. opposite to the direction of the magnetic field).
left (i.e. opposite to the motion of the charge).

question.name: effect of a current on a compass
question.questiontext: A wire runs vertically up through a room. No current is running through it. A compass is placed beside it and points north. When a large current is run upward through the wire what is its effect on the compass needle?

answer.answertext: The compass needle is deflected so that it points tangent to a circle around the wire.
The compass needle is deflected so it points directly at the wire.
The compass needle is unaffected since magnetism and electricity are different phenomena.
The compass needle is deflected so that it points along the wire.

question.name: magnetic field around a wire (no current)

answer.answertext: this wire does not produce a magnetic field.

question.name: magnetic field around a wire (with current)

answer.answertext: this wire has no magnetic field because the charges on it are static.

question.name: why do electrons diffract?
question.questiontext: When electrons are passed through a double slit they produce an interference pattern. This is because

answer.answertext: the electrons diffract and interfere because they have wavelike properties.
the electrons bounce off the edges of the slits and off of each other.
the electrons form multiple images of each slit.

question.name: beam of electrons bounced off crystal surface
question.questiontext: A beam of electrons is bounced off of the clean surface of a sample of crystaline nickel. The beam

answer.answertext: reflects at the same angle that it hit the nickel at (like light off of a mirror)

question.name: photoelectric effect - lights of differing intensity and wavelength
question.questiontext: A clean zinc surface (A) is exposed to dim ultraviolet light of short wavelength. An identical zinc surface (B) is exposed to bright ultraviolet light of longer wavelength. Both are observed to emit electrons as a result. Which one emits electrons with a greater maximum kinetic energy?

answer.answertext: they emit electrons with the same energy

question.name: photoelectric effect - why doesn't light below threshold cause a current
question.questiontext: When a metal is illuminated by light below its threshold frequency no emission of electrons from its surface is observed. This is best explained by

answer.answertext: each photon of the light carries insufficient energy to free an electron from the surface.
the stopping potential is too high.
below the threshold frequency the intensity of the light is simply too low.

question.name: interference from two speakers (in line)
question.questiontext: Two speakers, which are good approximations of point sources, are on the x-axis. They are playing the same steady tone, in phase with each other. The speakers are separated by exactly half of a wavelength. If you walk away from them along the x-axis what will you hear?

answer.answertext: you won't hear the speakers at all because of destructive interference.
the sound from the speakers modulate between high pitch and low pitch as you move along the x-axis.
there will be as steady sound that is twice as loud as the sound from one speaker.
the sound from the speakers alternate between loud and silent as you move along the x-axis.

question.name: interference from two speakers (in line) 2
question.questiontext: Two speakers, which are good approximations of point sources, are on the x-axis. They are playing the same steady tone, in phase with each other. The speakers are separated by exactly one wavelength. If you walk away from them along the x-axis what will you hear?

answer.answertext: there will be as steady sound that is twice as loud as the sound from one speaker.
the sound from the speakers modulate between high pitch and low pitch as you move along the x-axis.
you won't hear the speakers at all because of destructive interference.
the sound from the speakers alternate between loud and silent as you move along the x-axis.

question_category.name: effects of fields on opposite charges

question.name: Two charges feel opposite forces
question.questiontext: A probe charge is placed at a point and is observed to experience a force to the right. Another probe charge is placed at the same point and is observed to experience a force to the left. The electric field at this point is known to be constant and only electrical forces are significant. Which of the following statements about the charges is true.

answer.answertext: The two probe charges must be of opposite sign.
This situation is impossible. If the electric field is constant then all charges at this point must experience forces in the same direction.
One of the probe charges must have a charge of larger magnitude than the other.
The electrical forces tell us nothing about the charges. We can make no conclusions.

question.name: electron and proton in electrical field
question.questiontext: An electron is placed at a point and is observed to accelerate to the right. If a proton is placed at the same point then we should expect it to

answer.answertext: accelerate to the left, with a smaller magnitude of acceleration.
accelerate to the left with the same magnitude of acceleration.
accelerate to the right with the same magnitude of acceleration.
accelerate to the right with a smaller magnitude of acceleration.
accelerate to the right with a larger magnuitude of acceleration.

question.name: Energy of photons emitted from two lights
question.questiontext: One light emitting diode emits blue light (high frequency) with a total output of 0.5 W. Another light emitting diode emits red light (low frequency) with a total output of 2.0 W. Which light emitting diode is emitting higher energy photons?

answer.answertext: The blue diode's photons have greater energy.
The red diode's photons have greater energy.
They are both emitting photons of the same energy.

question.name: Energy of photons emitted from two lights [same frequency]
question.questiontext: One light emitting diode emits red light with a total output of 0.5 W. Another light emitting diode emits identical red light (i.e. same frequency) with a total output of 2.0 W. Which light emitting diode is emitting higher energy photons?

answer.answertext: The 2.0 W light emits higher energy photons.
The 0.5 W light emits higher energy photons.
They are both emitting photons of the same energy.

question.name: particle in a box
question.questiontext: A particle confined to move within a small region (a "box") can have

answer.answertext: an energy that lies only within a restricted range.

question.name: boxes of different sizes
question.questiontext: Electron A is confined to a 1 nm long "box". Electron B is confined to a 2 nm long "box". Which has the smaller minimum possible energy?

answer.answertext: Electron B has the lower minimum energy.
Electron A has the lower minimum energy.
Both electrons have the same minimum energy.
We need to know their momentums.
We need to know the value of the quantum number, n, for each electron.

question.name: wavelengths of protons
question.questiontext: Two protons are travelling through an area. Proton A has a speed of 4 X 10<sup>5</sup> m/s. Proton B has a speed of 6 X 10<sup>6</sup> m/s. Which proton has the longer wavelength?

answer.answertext: What are you talking about, Geoff? They aren't waves so how can they have wavelengths?

question.name: electron vs. proton wavelength
question.questiontext: An electron moves through some region of space with a speed of 1 X 107 m/s. A proton moves through the same region with the same speed. Compare their wavelengths.

answer.answertext: The electron has a longer wavelength than the proton.
The proton has a longer wavelength than the electron.
These a are particles, not waves. So they do not have wavelengths.

question.name: Relationship between y(t) and v_y (t)
question.questiontext: Suppose that some object moves so that it has a y-component of position described by the function, \( y(t) \), and a y-component of velocity described by the function, \( v_y (t) \).  Which of the following is a correct statement about the relationship between \( y(t) \) and \( v_y (t) \).

answer.answertext: \( v_y (t) \) is the derivative with respect to time, \( \frac{d}{dt} y (t) \).
\( v_y (t) \) is the antiderivative with respect to time, \( \int y (t) dt \).
answer.feedback: No.  You may want to review the video lectures for Unit #3.  But also note that y (t) is a function which has an output measured in meters, and dt has units of seconds.  So y(t) dt has units of meters times seconds, which is not a velocity.

answer.answertext: \( y (t) \) is the derivative with respect to time, \( \frac{d}{dt} v_y (t) \).
answer.feedback: No.  You may want to review the video lectures for Unit #3.  But also note that v_y (t) is a function that has units of m/s and when we take the time derivative it introduces an additional 1/s to the units giving an output of m/s^2, which is not a position.

answer.answertext: \( v_y (t) \) is the integral with respect to time, \( \int_{t_i}^{t_f} y (t) dt \).
answer.feedback: No.  You may want to review the video lectures for Unit #3.  But also note that y (t) is a function which has an output measured in meters, and dt has units of seconds.  So y(t) dt has units of meters times seconds, which is not a velocity.

question.name: Take a simple derivative - 1
question.questiontext:
You may not have learned to take a derivative yet, but then again, maybe you have.  If you have then this question should be pretty simple.  If you haven't then you can easily look up how to do a derivative like this since it is just done using the "power rule" for derivatives.  In any case, you will need to take a simple derivative a lot like this later in the lab, so this question is to put you on notice that this is something you need to figure out.

Suppose that we have the function

$$f(t) = 3 t^2 + 4 t + 1 \, .$$ 

Which of the following is the correct derivative, \( \frac{d}{dt} f(t) \)?

answer.feedback: Yes.
No.  You may be mixing up the rule for differentiation with the rule for integration.
No.  Each term in the sum needs to have its derivative found using the power rule.
No.  Have a look at the power rule and also look at what happens to constant multipliers when we take a derivative.
No.  You may be mixing up the rule for differentiation with the rule for integration but this is also not a correct integral of the original function.

question.questiontext:
You may not have learned to take a derivative yet, but then again, maybe you have.  If you have then this question should be pretty simple.  If you haven't then you can easily look up how to do a derivative like this since it is just done using the "power rule" for derivatives.  In any case, you will need to take a simple derivative a lot like this later in the lab, so this question is to put you on notice that this is something you need to figure out.

Suppose that we have the function

$$f(t) = \frac{1}{2} t^2 + 3 t + 5 \, .$$

answer.feedback: Yes.
No.  You may be mixing up the rule for differentiation with the rule for integration.
No.  Each term in the sum needs to have its derivative found using the power rule.
No.  Have a look at the power rule and also look at what happens to constant multipliers when we take a derivative.
No.  You may be mixing up the rule for differentiation with the rule for integration but this is also not a correct integral of the original function.

question.name: Match graphs to parts of motion
question.questiontext: Suppose a projectile is launched so that, initially, both components of its velocity are positive.  Assume "normal" axes so that the y-axis points up and the x-axis is horizontal.  For each of the graphs below, match it with the component of position, velocity, or acceleration which would be expected to appear like it.

question.name: numerical projectile question - 1

Suppose that a ball is launched at \( t = 0 \) with an initial velocity

$$\vec{v}_i = 3.0 \hat{i} + 4.0 \hat{j} \, \textrm{m/s} \, .$$

Assume that the y-axis points up and that the acceleration due to gravity is 10 m/s2 down.  Fill in the spaces below to write the velocity of the ball 1.0 s after launch.

\( \vec{v} (1.0 \, \textrm{s}) = \) {#1} \( \hat{i} + \) {#2} \( \hat{j} \) m/s

question.name: Which changes are the same?
question.questiontext:
Cart A and Cart B are low friction carts on a horizontal track and they have different inertias (\( m_A \neq m_B \)).  They move towards each as shown.  Then they collide.  The velocities, speeds and momentums of both carts change as a result of the collision.  Let variables with "i" subscripts refer to values just before the collision and variables with "f" subscripts refer to values just after the collision.  As usual, \( \vec{v} \) are velocities and \( \vec{p} \) are momentums.  So, for example

$$\Delta \vec{v}_{A} = \vec{v}_{Af} - \vec{v}_{Ai}$$

is the change in velocity of Cart A during the collision.  

Let's also define \( \vec{p} = \vec{p}_A + \vec{p}_B \) to be the total momentum of the system consisting of the two carts. 

Which of the following are true to a reasonable approximation?  More than one may be true.

answer.feedback: Yes.  The changes in momentum of the individual carts point in opposite directions, but have the same magnitudes.
No.  If we go by the picture then \( \Delta \vec{p}_A \) must point to the left while \( \Delta \vec{p}_B \) must point to the right.  Vectors that point in different directions can't be equal.

No.  If we go by the picture then \( \Delta \vec{p}_A \) must point to the left while \( \Delta \vec{p}_B \) must point to the right.  Vectors that point in different directions can't be equal.  But besides, there is no physical law that would tell us that these two changes in velocity should be equal to each other.
Yes.  The system should be approximately isolated (low friction...) and this equation is just the Law of Conservation of Momentum.
No.  If the carts had equal inertias then we would expect this to be true.  But they have different inertias.  So they will be accelerated by different amounts during the collision.

question.name: why does cart move at nearly constant speed?
question.questiontext:
Suppose we place a low friction cart on a horizontal track.  We give it a quick push and then let go.

When we do this in the lab the cart will run along the track.  To our unassisted senses the cart may seem to move at constant speed.  But if we do careful measurements, for example, using video analysis or a motion sensor, we can see that the speed of the cart is decreasing, but only at a very small rate.

Which of the following is the most correct explanation for this set of observations?

answer.answertext: The only interaction causing the cart to slow down is friction.  The friction is a very weak interaction.
answer.feedback: Yes.

answer.answertext: The cart moves because of a force from our push.  The strength of that force gradually decreases after we let go.
answer.feedback: No.  Can you exert a force on an object without touching it?  If so then you have magical powers.  Let's set magic aside and try to explain things using physics.

answer.answertext: The cart is pulled along by a force exerted by its wheels.  But the wheels are slowing down so the cart must slow down as well.
answer.feedback: No.  As we will see in a few weeks when we talk about forces in more detail, no object can exert a force on itself.  The wheels are part of the cart, so they can't exert a force on the cart.

answer.answertext: The cart is pulled along by inertia which is a force that keeps it going.  However, an object's inertia tends to decrease with time, so the cart slows down.
answer.feedback: No.  First of all, inertia is not a force.  Inertia is a fundamental property of any object, which describes its "resistance to being accelerated".  If you are having trouble understanding what inertia is, then it may be useful to think of it as mass.  There are some subtleties, but more or less, mass is a measure of an object's inertia.  Normally objects cannot lose mass, and so they also can't lose inertia.

answer.answertext: The cart moves because of a thrust force.  The thrust force gradually decreases so the cart slows down.
answer.feedback: No.  What would be exerting this this thrust force?  The forces we usually refer to as "thrust" are due to the object pushing on gases or liquids so that those gases or liquids push back on the object.  Examples would be the force exerted by air on a jet engine, or the force exerted by water on a boat propeller.  The cart definitely doesn't have a jet engine.  If it did this would have been stated in the question.

question_category.name: cart v vs t graphs during collisions - inertias

question.name: inertia of cart B - 1
question.questiontext:
Carts A and B collide.  Their x-components of velocity are shown in the graph below.

Based on this graph we can conclude that the inertia of B is {#1} the inertia of A.

If A has an inertia of 250 g then B must have an inertia of {#2} g.

question.name: inertia of cart B - 1
question.questiontext: {2:MULTICHOICE:=greater than#Yes. Smaller change in velocity implies larger inertia.~less than#No. Notice that B's change in velocity is smaller than A's. So B must be harder to accelerate.~the same as#No. Notice that B's change in velocity is smaller than A's. So B must be harder to accelerate.}

answer.feedback: Yes. Smaller change in velocity implies larger inertia.
No. Notice that B's change in velocity is smaller than A's. So B must be harder to accelerate.
No. Notice that B's change in velocity is smaller than A's. So B must be harder to accelerate.

question.name: inertia of cart B - 1
question.questiontext: {3:NUMERICAL:=500:1#Yes. Half the change in velocity implies two times the inertia.~%25%125:1#No. You've got the right ratio (factor of 2) but B has a smaller change in velocity than A so it must have a larger inertia.~1000:1#No. You seem to think that B is 4X the inertia of A. Are you looking at their final velocities and noting that B is going 1/4 the speed of A? You need to look at the *changes* in velocities, not the final velocities.}

answer.feedback: Yes. Half the change in velocity implies two times the inertia.
No. You've got the right ratio (factor of 2) but B has a smaller change in velocity than A so it must have a larger inertia.

No. You seem to think that B is 4X the inertia of A. Are you looking at their final velocities and noting that B is going 1/4 the speed of A? You need to look at the *changes* in velocities, not the final velocities.

No. Notice that B's change in velocity is larger than A's. So B must be easier to accelerate.
No. Notice that B's change in velocity is larger than A's. So B must be easier to accelerate.

Are you looking at their final velocities and noting that B is going 4X the speed of A? You need to look at the *changes* in velocities, not the final velocities.}

question.name: classify collisions - 1
question.questiontext: Match each \( v_x \) vs. \(t\) graph with the type of collision that it is showing.

matchoptions.partiallycorrectfeedback: Your answer is partially correct.  Remember that we need to look at the relative speeds of the carts before and after the collision.  If they are equal then the collision is elastic.  If the relative speed is zero after the collision it is totally inelastic.  Anything between these two extremes is inelastic.
matchoptions.incorrectfeedback: Your answer is incorrect.  Remember that we need to look at the relative speeds of the carts before and after the collision.  If they are equal then the collision is elastic.  If the relative speed is zero after the collision it is totally inelastic.  Anything between these two extremes is inelastic.

question.name: verify conservation of momentum - 1
question.questiontext:
Consider the collision between two low friction carts, on a horizontal track, shown in this \( v_x \) vs. \( t \) graph.

We expect that the total momentum of the system of two carts will be {#1}

The inertia of A is \( m_A = \) 400 g.  So, the inertia of B must be \( m_B = \) {#2} g.

The initial x-component of the system momentum is \( p_{ix} = \) {#3} kg m/s.

The final x-component of the system momentum is \( p_{fx} = \) {#4} kg m/s, which makes sense given our expectation about whether the momentum should be conserved.

question.name: verify conservation of momentum - 1
question.questiontext: {1:MULTICHOICE:=conserved#Yes~not conserved#No. The only external interactions (friction) should be very weak. The system is approximately isolated.}

answer.feedback: Yes

question.name: check Ki Kf - 1
question.questiontext:
Consider the collision between two low friction carts, on a horizontal track, shown in this \( v_x \) vs. \( t \) graph.

Let the system be cart A and cart B.  Based on this graph we can tell that the final kinetic energy of the system should be {#1} the initial kinetic energy of the system.

The inertias of the carts are \( m_A = 700 \) g, \( m_B = 100 \) g.  So the initial kinetic energy of the system is {#2} J.

The final kinetic energy of the system is {#3} J.  This agrees with our expectation about whether the kinetic energy increased, decreased or stayed the same.

question.name: Match choice of axes with x vs. t graph
question.questiontext:
Now let's think about the consequences of different choices for our xy-axes.

The puck is 4.0 cm across and the video was shot at 25 frames per second.  Below are several choices of axes, each shown superimposed over frame 0 of the video.  As shown, in each case we are using the center of the puck as the reference point for determining the position of the puck.

Below are several x vs. t graphs.  Match the choices of axes in the diagrams above with the appropriate x vs. t graphs.

matchoptions.partiallycorrectfeedback: You have some of the graphs matched to the correct axes, but not all of them.

question_hint.hint: There are many ways to figure this out, and you are probably using  some of them.  One thing to realize is that the direction that the x-axis points, by convention, tells you which way the "positive x-direction" is.  So use the axes definitions to decide which side of the origin is the positive x side and which is the negative x side.
Another thing to notice is that once you know which side is the positive x side, noticing what the value of x at t = 0 should be able to tell you which graph matches which axes.

question.name: t axis
question.questiontext:
Let's start working on how we would draw an x vs. t graph.  We will start by thinking about the time axis.

The puck is 4.0 cm across.  For the moment let's use the choice of xy-axes shown below, and using the centre of the puck as the "location of the puck".  In a later question we will look at the effect of making different choices for the xy-axes.

The relevant facts and choices that you need to know for constructing the time axis on the x vs. t graph are:

  • The video was shot at 25 frames per second. 
  • We are choosing to set t = 0 at the instant of frame 0 in the video.  

Which of the graphs below uses a correct time axis, consistent with the details given above?

answer.feedback: Yes.

No.  We already know that during frame 0 we should have x = 2 cm, and we have chosen to set that moment to correspond with t = 0.  That is not what this graph is showing.  Also, there should be 25 frames per second.  This is showing 1 frame per second.
No.  There should be 25 frames per second.  This is showing 1 frame per second.
No.  We already know that with this choice of axes we should have x = 2 cm during frame 0, which we have set to correspond to t = 0.  That is not what this graph is showing.
No.  There should be 25 frames per second.  This is showing 4 frame per second (count them...).

No.  There should be 25 frames per second.  This is showing 4 frame per second (count them...).  Also, we already knew that during frame 0 we should have x = 2 cm.  We have set frame 0 to correspond  with t = 0.  That's not what this graph is showing.

question_hint.hint: No.  See the hint given beside the answer that you chose.
No.  See the hint given beside the answer that you chose.

question.name: x at t = 0
question.questiontext:
In the assignment question you have been given this sequence of frames of video, showing a puck bouncing back and forth between two walls.

The puck is 4.0 cm across.  One of the first issues we need to think about, any time we analyze any motion, is how to set our axes.  There is no right or wrong way to choose axes, but some choices can be more convenient than others.  For the moment let's use the choice of xy-axes shown below, using the centre of the puck as the "location of the puck".  In a later question we will look at the effect of making different choices for the xy-axes.

The diagram is showing that the origin is at the right wall of the container and the x-axis is pointing left.  The "X" with a circle around it is indicating that we are choosing to track the location of the centre of the puck, and let its position represent the position of the whole puck.

With these choices, what is the value of x (the x-component of position for the puck) during frame 0?

answer.feedback: Yes.

No.  By definition x = 0 at the origin (or anywhere along the y-axis.  The centre of the puck is not at the origin and we are choosing to define the location of the puck's centre as the location of the puck as a whole.
No.  Notice that the x-axis is pointing to the left.  So locations to the left of the origin have positive values of x.
No.  Note that the puck is 4 cm across, and its right end is at origin...
No.  Notice that the x-axis is pointing to the left.  So locations to the left of the origin have positive values of x.  Also, notice that the puck is 4 cm across.

question_hint.hint: No.  See the hint given beside the answer that you chose.
No.  See the hint given beside the answer that you chose.

question.questiontext: Now you have thought through the consequences of different choices of axes.  You are ready to do the written parts of the problem which you will submit.  For the rest of the problem, use this choice of axes:

question.name: Identify vectors, then add - 1
question.questiontext:
Consider these two vectors, \( \vec{a} \) and \( \vec{b} \).

These vectors are:

\( \vec{a} \) = {#1} \( \hat{i} + \) {#2} \( \hat{j} \)

\( \vec{b} \) = {#3} \( \hat{i} + \) {#4} \( \hat{j} \)

If we add them then we get

\( \vec{a} + \vec{b} \) = {#5} \( \hat{i} + \) {#6} \( \hat{j} \)

question.questiontext:
Consider these two vectors, \( \vec{a} \) and \( \vec{b} \).

These vectors are:

\( \vec{a} \) = {#1} \( \hat{i} + \) {#2} \( \hat{j} \)

\( \vec{b} \) = {#3} \( \hat{i} + \) {#4} \( \hat{j} \)

If we subtract them then we get

\( \vec{a} - \vec{b} \) = {#5} \( \hat{i} + \) {#6} \( \hat{j} \)

question.name: What is implied by \(\vec{A} + \vec{B} = \vec{C} \)?
question.questiontext:
Consider these three vectors, \( \vec{A} \), \( \vec{B} \), and \( \vec{C} \).

As the diagram shows, \( \vec{A} + \vec{B} = \vec{C} \).

Now let's think about the relationship between the magnitudes, \( A \equiv |\vec{A}| \), \( B \equiv |\vec{B}| \), and \( C \equiv |\vec{C}| \).

The sum of magnitudes, \( A + B \) is {#1} \( C \).

The sum of components, \( A_x + B_x \) is {#2} \( C_x \) {#3}

question.name: What is implied by \(\vec{A} + \vec{B} = \vec{C} \)?

No. Look at the rule for how algebraic vector addition works.

question.name: What is implied by \(\vec{A} + \vec{B} = \vec{C} \)?
question.questiontext: {1:MULTICHOICE:=no matter how we define our axes.#Yes~but only if we align the x-axis with one of the vectors.#No. Vector relationships would not be very useful if they depended on the orientation of our axes.~but only if our x-axis is horizontal.#No. There is nothing special about having the x-axis horizontal. Vector relationships would not be very useful if they were only useful with certain choices of axes.}

answer.answertext: no matter how we define our axes.
answer.feedback: Yes

answer.answertext: but only if we align the x-axis with one of the vectors.
answer.feedback: No. Vector relationships would not be very useful if they depended on the orientation of our axes.

answer.answertext: but only if our x-axis is horizontal.
answer.feedback: No. There is nothing special about having the x-axis horizontal. Vector relationships would not be very useful if they were only useful with certain choices of axes.

question.name: Four vector relationships - which descriptions accurately describe them?
question.questiontext:
Consider these four diagrams of vector relationships.

Match the pictures to the descriptions that apply to them.

question.name: Vector pointing in negative x-direction
question.questiontext:
Consider this vector, \( \vec{B} \).

Choose all of the statements that are true.

answer.answertext: The vector, \( \vec{B} \), is neither positive nor negative.

answer.feedback: No.  Vectors are not numbers.  They cannot be positive or negative.
No.  This equation is claiming that a vector, \( \vec{B} \), is equal to a scalar, \( B \).  A vector cannot equal a scalar.
No.  The vector points left and the x-axis points right.  So the x-component of the vector must be negative.  The vector points parallel to the x-axis, so its y-component must be zero.

answer.answertext: There is no scale or grid, so we can't make any statement about how we might write the vector.
answer.feedback: No.  We can at least relate the vector, \( \vec{B} \), to its own magnitude, \( B \equiv |\vec{B}| \).  Given that the vector is parallel to  the x-axis there are some very simple ways to write the vector in terms of its own magnitude.

question.name: Add accelerations to motion diagram - 1
question.questiontext:
Consider this motion diagram.  It is on a grid to help you compare the velocity vectors with each other.

Think about acceleration vectors added to this diagram.  As always we are only concerned with the directions of these acceleration vectors, not their magnitudes.  Use this figure as a "library" of directions for the acceleration vectors to point.

Some of the acceleration vectors may also be zero.

At point 2 the best representation of the acceleration vector is {#1}.

At point 5 the best representation of the acceleration vector is {#2}.

At point 9 the best representation of the acceleration vector is {#3}.

At point 10 the best representation of the acceleration vector is {#4}.

question_category.name: displacement and distance travelled for motions with reversals of direction

question.name: reverse direction - displacement and distance travelled - 1
question.questiontext:
A person starts at point A, at x = -1 m, walks to point B, at x = 6 m, then reverses direction and walks to point C, at x = 2 m, as shown.

From A to C, the person's x-component of displacement is {#1} m.

From A to C, the distance travelled by the person is {#2} m.

From when it leaves the person's hand to when it hits the ground, the distance travelled by the stone is {#2} m.

question_category.name: Default for Nerf ball in-class "problem" - 1
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'Nerf ball in-class "problem" - 1'.

question.name: Nerf ball drop - energy bar chart
question.questiontext:
A NerfTM ball (a low-density foam ball) is dropped from a high building. Note that, because the ball has a very low density, air drag is not negligible. The ball has an inertia of m = 25 g and is dropped from rest, from a height of hi = 50 m. Just before hitting the ground it is going at a speed of vf = 8 m/s.  Assume the ground is at h = 0.

Use the following definitions:

System: ball, Earth, air that ball passes through

Initial: just after the ball is released

Final: just before the ball hits the ground

Drag and drop full, half full, and empty bars to complete the energy bar chart.  Note: if you want to represent zero then drag an empty bar into that location on the bar chart.

question_hint.hint: \( U_G \) = mgh.  The ball starts with large h and ends with h = 0.
Remember that "final" should mean just *before* the ball hits the ground.  It should be going quite fast at that moment.

If we dropped high density ball from the same height it would be going be much faster than the Nerf ball because there is no air drag.  So, we must conclude that the air drag results in a lower kinetic energy.  Energy can't just disappear so that energy that isn't transformed to K must be transformed to some other form.

question.name: Nerf ball - conservation equation
question.questiontext:
A NerfTM ball (a low-density foam ball) is dropped from a high building. Note that, because the ball has a very low density, air drag is not negligible. The ball has an inertia of m = 25 g and is dropped from rest, from a height of hi = 50 m. Just before hitting the ground it is going at a speed of vf = 8 m/s.  Assume the ground is at h = 0.

Use the following definitions:

System: ball, Earth, air that ball passes through

Initial: just after the ball is released

Final: just before the ball hits the ground

On the previous question you should have come up with an energy bar chart like this:

Drag and drop the correct right and left sides to complete the equation of conservation of energy which would be most useful to write as the next step in solving this.  You are looking for a nice simple form of the equation, which we can write down using what we already know from the bar chart.  However, we want it to be written in terms of the variables that we know values for.

question_hint.hint: Remember that you are just "translating" the bar chart into the equation.  Each bar in the bar chart should correspond with a term in the equation.

If we know that some "pool" of energy is zero at some time then there is no point in including that in the equation.  It is just something we should be able to cross out right away and make our equation nice and simple.
I have included some things that can't be correct because they don't  have units of energy.  Don't get fished in by those wrong answers.

question.name: Nerf ball - final E_th
question.questiontext:
A NerfTM ball (a low-density foam ball) is dropped from a high building. Note that, because the ball has a very low density, air drag is not negligible. The ball has an inertia of m = 25 g and is dropped from rest, from a height of hi = 50 m. Just before hitting the ground it is going at a speed of vf = 8 m/s.  Assume the ground is at h = 0.

Use the following definitions:

System: ball, Earth, air that ball passes through

Initial: just after the ball is released

Final: just before the ball hits the ground

You should already have written down the conservation of energy equation.  Use it to calculate the amount of thermal energy that the system has just before the ball hits the ground.  Note: Use g = 10 m/s2.

Don't forget to include units in your answer.

answer.feedback: Yup.
Yes.  But you used g = 9.8 m/s2.  Lucky for you, I input that into the question as one of the correct options.  But you should really follow instructions.  It makes everything so much easier!

Does it make sense for the final thermal energy to be negative??  This implies that things cooled down as the ball fell.  That is not at all what we would observe.  Did you use g = -10 m/s2?  Remember, g is positive by definition.  The formula \( U_G = mgh \) only makes sense if g is positive.  If g was negative then this equation would  say that objects *lose* gravitational potential energy as they are moved higher, which makes no sense.

Did you use g = -10 m/s2 (then drop the negative in your final answer...)?  Remember, g is positive by definition.  The formula \( U_G = mgh \) only makes sense if g is positive.  If g was negative then this equation would  say that objects *lose* gravitational potential energy as they are moved higher, which makes no sense.
You must not have converted g to kg.  So your answer is wrong by a factor of 1000.

question_hint.hint: Don't forget to work in mks (meters, kilograms, seconds) units.
Remember that g is positive by definition.

question_category.name: cart v vs. t graphs interpret, including collision type

question.name: inertia of cart B - 1
question.questiontext:
Carts A and B collide.  Their x-components of velocity are shown in the graph below.

Based on this graph we can conclude that the inertia of B is {#1} the inertia of A.

If A has an inertia of 250 g then B must have an inertia of {#2} g.

This collision is {#3}

question.name: inertia of cart B - 1
question.questiontext: {1:MULTICHOICE:=greater than#Yes. Smaller change in velocity implies larger inertia.~less than#No. Notice that B's change in velocity is smaller than A's. So B must be harder to accelerate.~the same as#No. Notice that B's change in velocity is smaller than A's. So B must be harder to accelerate.}

answer.feedback: Yes. Smaller change in velocity implies larger inertia.
No. Notice that B's change in velocity is smaller than A's. So B must be harder to accelerate.
No. Notice that B's change in velocity is smaller than A's. So B must be harder to accelerate.

question.name: inertia of cart B - 1
question.questiontext: {2:NUMERICAL:=500:1#Yes. Half the change in velocity implies two times the inertia.~%25%125:1#No. You've got the right ratio (factor of 2) but B has a smaller change in velocity than A so it must have a larger inertia.~1000:1#No. You seem to think that B is 4X the inertia of A. Are you looking at their final velocities and noting that B is going 1/4 the speed of A? You need to look at the *changes* in velocities, not the final velocities.}

answer.feedback: Yes. Half the change in velocity implies two times the inertia.
No. You've got the right ratio (factor of 2) but B has a smaller change in velocity than A so it must have a larger inertia.

No. You seem to think that B is 4X the inertia of A. Are you looking at their final velocities and noting that B is going 1/4 the speed of A? You need to look at the *changes* in velocities, not the final velocities.

question.name: Observers agree/disagree on - 1
question.questiontext:
You are sitting stationary in your lab, observing a collision between two carts.  According to your measurements the system of two carts obeys the Law of Conservation of Momentum during the collision.

Your friend, Sam, is gliding through the lab at a constant velocity on their skateboard.  They also observe the collision.

According to Sam's measurements the system of carts {#1} the Law of Conservation of Momentum because {#2}

At the same time, Elvis passes through the lab riding on a rocket which is speeding up.  Elvis also observes the collision.

According to Elvis the system of carts {#3} the Law of Conservation of Momentum because {#4}

question.name: Observers agree/disagree on - 1
question.questiontext: {1:MULTICHOICE:=obeys#Yes. Sam is an inertial observer.~does not obey#No. Sam is an inertial observer. Sam agrees with you about what laws of physics are obeyed.}

answer.feedback: Yes. Sam is an inertial observer.
No. Sam is an inertial observer. Sam agrees with you about what laws of physics are obeyed.

question.name: Observers agree/disagree on - 1
question.questiontext: {1:MULTICHOICE:=Sam is an inertial observer.#Yes.~momentum is always conserved.#No. The momentum of the UNIVERSE is always conserved according to inertial observers, but that isn't what this is asking about.~the system of carts is isolated.#No. The system is apparently isolated. But that isn't why Sam agrees with you. Sam is an inertial observer and inertial observers agree on the laws of physics.~Sam is moving.#No. Everyone and everything is moving from some perspective. All motion is relative. So this really doesn't answer anything.~Sam is accelerating.#No. The question says that Sam is moving at constant velocity. Sam is not accelerating.}

answer.feedback: Yes.
No. The momentum of the UNIVERSE is always conserved according to inertial observers, but that isn't what this is asking about.

answer.answertext: the system of carts is isolated.
answer.feedback: No. The system is apparently isolated. But that isn't why Sam agrees with you. Sam is an inertial observer and inertial observers agree on the laws of physics.
No. Everyone and everything is moving from some perspective. All motion is relative. So this really doesn't answer anything.
No. The question says that Sam is moving at constant velocity. Sam is not accelerating.

question.name: Observers agree/disagree on - 1
question.questiontext: {1:MULTICHOICE:obeys#No. Elvis is a non-inertial observer.~=does not obey#Yes, Elvis is a non-inertial observer.}

answer.feedback: No. Elvis is a non-inertial observer.
Yes, Elvis is a non-inertial observer.

question.name: Observers agree/disagree on - 1
question.questiontext: {1:MULTICHOICE:Elvis is an inertial observer.#No. Elvis is accelerating. Elvis is a non-inertial observer.~momentum is always conserved.#No. The momentum of the UNIVERSE is always conserved according to inertial observers, but that isn't what this is asking about.~the system of carts is isolated.#No. The system is apparently isolated. But that isn't what the question is asking about.~Elvis is moving.#No. Everyone and everything is moving from some perspective. All motion is relative. So this really doesn't answer anything.~=Elvis is accelerating.#Yes.}

answer.feedback: No. Elvis is accelerating. Elvis is a non-inertial observer.
No. The momentum of the UNIVERSE is always conserved according to inertial observers, but that isn't what this is asking about.

answer.answertext: the system of carts is isolated.
answer.feedback: No. The system is apparently isolated. But that isn't what the question is asking about.
No. Everyone and everything is moving from some perspective. All motion is relative. So this really doesn't answer anything.
Yes.

question.name: Observers agree/disagree on - 2
question.questiontext:
Officer Alice is standing by the side of a straight road using a radar gun to monitor the speed of cars. She observes that a car is driving east at 70 km/hr and it slows down to 50 km/hr.  Sergeant Bob is driving down the same road at some constant velocity  observing the same car with the radar gun in his patrol cruiser.  Note: I have not specified what direction Bob is driving.  We want to think about all possibilities.

 

Alice observes that the car's change in velocity is {#1}

Bob observes {#2} change in velocity because {#3}

Clearly, according to Alice, the car is slowing down.  According to Bob {#4}

question.name: Observers agree/disagree on - 2
question.questiontext: {1:MULTICHOICE:=(20 km/hr, west)#Yes.~20 km/hr#No, change in velocity is a vector.~(20 km/hr, east)#No, draw the vector subtraction, or recognize that if the car slows down then the acceleration must point in the opposite direction to the velocity.}

answer.feedback: Yes.
No, change in velocity is a vector.
No, draw the vector subtraction, or recognize that if the car slows down then the acceleration must point in the opposite direction to the velocity.

question.name: Observers agree/disagree on - 2
question.questiontext: {1:MULTICHOICE:=the same#Yes, inertial observers observe the same change in velocity.~a different#No. Inertial observers agree on changes in velocity.}

answer.feedback: Yes, inertial observers observe the same change in velocity.
No. Inertial observers agree on changes in velocity.

question.name: Observers agree/disagree on - 2
question.questiontext: {1:MULTICHOICE:=Bob is an inertial observer.#Yes.~Bob agrees with Alice about the initial and final velocities.#No. Bob is in a different reference frame, so he measures different velocities, but he still agrees with Alice's measurement of the change in velocity.~Bob is moving.#No. Everyone and everything is moving from some perspective. All motion is relative. So this really doesn't answer anything.~Bob is accelerating.#No. The question says that Bob is moving at constant velocity. Bob is not accelerating.}

answer.feedback: Yes.

answer.answertext: Bob agrees with Alice about the initial and final velocities.
answer.feedback: No. Bob is in a different reference frame, so he measures different velocities, but he still agrees with Alice's measurement of the change in velocity.
No. Everyone and everything is moving from some perspective. All motion is relative. So this really doesn't answer anything.
No. The question says that Bob is moving at constant velocity. Bob is not accelerating.

question.name: Observers agree/disagree on - 2
question.questiontext: {1:MULTICHOICE:=the car might be speeding up or slowing down, depending on Bob's velocity.#Yes. Depending on Bob's velocity the car could be going either east or west in his frame and so we don't know whether the car's acceleration points in the same or opposite direction to its velocity.~the car is definitely slowing down, no matter what Bob's velocity is.#No. Depending on Bob's velocity the car could be going either east or west in his frame and so we don't know whether the car's acceleration points in the same or opposite direction to its velocity.~the car is definitely speeding up, no matter what Bob's velocity is.#No. Depending on Bob's velocity the car could be going either east or west in his frame and so we don't know whether the car's acceleration points in the same or opposite direction to its velocity.~the car is definitely going at a constant velocity, no matter what Bob's velocity is.#No. Depending on Bob's velocity the car could be going either east or west in his frame and so we don't know whether the car's acceleration points in the same or opposite direction to its velocity.}

answer.answertext: the car might be speeding up or slowing down, depending on Bob's velocity.
answer.feedback: Yes. Depending on Bob's velocity the car could be going either east or west in his frame and so we don't know whether the car's acceleration points in the same or opposite direction to its velocity.

answer.answertext: the car is definitely slowing down, no matter what Bob's velocity is.
answer.feedback: No. Depending on Bob's velocity the car could be going either east or west in his frame and so we don't know whether the car's acceleration points in the same or opposite direction to its velocity.

answer.answertext: the car is definitely speeding up, no matter what Bob's velocity is.
answer.feedback: No. Depending on Bob's velocity the car could be going either east or west in his frame and so we don't know whether the car's acceleration points in the same or opposite direction to its velocity.

answer.answertext: the car is definitely going at a constant velocity, no matter what Bob's velocity is.
answer.feedback: No. Depending on Bob's velocity the car could be going either east or west in his frame and so we don't know whether the car's acceleration points in the same or opposite direction to its velocity.

question.name: Observers agree/disagree on - 3
question.questiontext:
Two space probes, A and B, are observing a collision between two asteroids, 1 and 2.  Let's consider the situation as viewed by probe A.  According to it, B, 1, and 2, move with velocities \( \vec{v}_B \), \( \vec{v}_{1i} \), and \( \vec{v}_{2i} \).  Then the two asteroids collide so that after the collision, according to A, they are moving with new velocities \( \vec{v}_{1f} \) and \( \vec{v}_{2f} \).  The collision is inelastic.

Let's first think about the system of asteroid 1 and asteroid 2, as viewed by probe A.

According to A, the centre of mass kinetic energy, \( K_{CM} \) {#1} 

According to A, the convertible kinetic energy, \( K_{Conv} \) {#2}

Now let's think about how  the measurements of A compare with measurements made by B.

If we compare the \( K_{CM} \) measured by A and B we will find that they {#3}

If we compare the \( K_{Conv} \) measured by A and B we will find that they {#4}

question.name: Observers agree/disagree on - 3
question.questiontext: {1:MULTICHOICE:=does not change during the collision, because the system is isolated.#Yes. K_CM can't change for an isolated system.~changes during the collision because the collision is inelastic.#No, K_CM can't change for an isolated system. Whether the collision is inelastic or elastic has nothing to do with whether the system's CM velocity (and therefore K_CM) changes.~does not change because the system is isolated, so its energy does not change.#No. Isolated has nothing to do with energy. It is all about momentum. But anyway, even if the system energy doesn't change, its kinetic energy still can.~changes because the velocities of both asteroids change.#No. The velocities of objects *must* change during a collision. But the center of mass velocity (and thus the K_CM) can still remain constant.}

answer.answertext: does not change during the collision, because the system is isolated.
answer.feedback: Yes. K_CM can't change for an isolated system.

answer.answertext: changes during the collision because the collision is inelastic.
answer.feedback: No, K_CM can't change for an isolated system. Whether the collision is inelastic or elastic has nothing to do with whether the system's CM velocity (and therefore K_CM) changes.

answer.answertext: does not change because the system is isolated, so its energy does not change.
answer.feedback: No. Isolated has nothing to do with energy. It is all about momentum. But anyway, even if the system energy doesn't change, its kinetic energy still can.

answer.answertext: changes because the velocities of both asteroids change.
answer.feedback: No. The velocities of objects *must* change during a collision. But the center of mass velocity (and thus the K_CM) can still remain constant.

question.name: Observers agree/disagree on - 3
question.questiontext: {1:MULTICHOICE:=changes, because the collision is inelastic.#Yes. In an inelastic collision the system loses K. The K_CM can't change, so it must be the K_Conv that changes.~changes, because the velocities of both asteroids change.#No. In some collisions (elastic collisions...) the velocities of the objects change but the K_Conv doesn't change. So this does not answer why the K_Conv must change.~does not change, because the system is isolated.#No. The fact that the system is isolated tells us that its momentum doesn't change. There is no connection between the system's momentum and its K_Conv.~does not change because the relative speed does not change.#No. The collision is inelastic. The relative speed of the objects in a collision always decreases in an inelastic collision.}

answer.answertext: changes, because the collision is inelastic.
answer.feedback: Yes. In an inelastic collision the system loses K. The K_CM can't change, so it must be the K_Conv that changes.

answer.answertext: changes, because the velocities of both asteroids change.
answer.feedback: No. In some collisions (elastic collisions...) the velocities of the objects change but the K_Conv doesn't change. So this does not answer why the K_Conv must change.

answer.answertext: does not change, because the system is isolated.
answer.feedback: No. The fact that the system is isolated tells us that its momentum doesn't change. There is no connection between the system's momentum and its K_Conv.

answer.answertext: does not change because the relative speed does not change.
answer.feedback: No. The collision is inelastic. The relative speed of the objects in a collision always decreases in an inelastic collision.

question.name: Observers agree/disagree on - 3
question.questiontext: {1:MULTICHOICE:=are different because the CM velocities of the system are different as measured by the two probes.#Yes.~are different because the collision is inelastic.#No. Whether the collision is inelastic or elastic has nothing to do with how we compare measurements made by A and B.~are the same because all inertial observers agree on CM velocities.#No. Inertial observers *don't* agree on CM velocities. They agree on changes of velocity and they agree on relative velocities.~are the same because the center of mass velocity isn't changing.#No. They might (and do...) agree that the center of mass velocity is constant, but they don't agree on its value.}

answer.answertext: are different because the CM velocities of the system are different as measured by the two probes.
answer.feedback: Yes.

answer.answertext: are different because the collision is inelastic.
answer.feedback: No. Whether the collision is inelastic or elastic has nothing to do with how we compare measurements made by A and B.

answer.answertext: are the same because all inertial observers agree on CM velocities.
answer.feedback: No. Inertial observers *don't* agree on CM velocities. They agree on changes of velocity and they agree on relative velocities.

answer.answertext: are the same because the center of mass velocity isn't changing.
answer.feedback: No. They might (and do...) agree that the center of mass velocity is constant, but they don't agree on its value.

question.name: Observers agree/disagree on - 3
question.questiontext: {1:MULTICHOICE:=are the same because inertial observers agree on relative speeds.#Yes.~are the same because the relative speed isn't changing.#No. The relative speed *is* changing. In an inelastic collision the relative speed decreases.~are different because the collision is inelastic.#No. The fact that the collision is inelastic tells us that the K_Conv *changes*. But A and B will agree on its value before the collision and they will also agree on its value after the collision.~are different because the probes are moving at different speeds.#No. The probes won't agree on the velocities of the asteroids, but they will agree on the *relative* velocity of the asteroids, and K_Conv only depends on relative velocity.}

answer.answertext: are the same because inertial observers agree on relative speeds.
answer.feedback: Yes.

answer.answertext: are the same because the relative speed isn't changing.
answer.feedback: No. The relative speed *is* changing. In an inelastic collision the relative speed decreases.

answer.answertext: are different because the collision is inelastic.
answer.feedback: No. The fact that the collision is inelastic tells us that the K_Conv *changes*. But A and B will agree on its value before the collision and they will also agree on its value after the collision.

answer.answertext: are different because the probes are moving at different speeds.
answer.feedback: No. The probes won't agree on the velocities of the asteroids, but they will agree on the *relative* velocity of the asteroids, and K_Conv only depends on relative velocity.

question_category.name: Long answer - is this system isolated and/or closed?

question.name: Truck going up a hill
question.questiontext:
A truck is driving up a hill.  It is speeding up.

Define:

System: Truck (and everything in/on the truck, such as the load it is carrying, the fuel in the tank, etc.).  Note that the Earth, the surface of the road etc. are NOT in the system.

Initial: Truck is moving up the hill.

Final: Truck is still going up the hill, but faster.

Is the system isolated?  Explain.

Is the system closed?  Explain.

question.name: Nail gun, block
question.questiontext:
A nail gun uses a spring to launch a nail.  The nail embeds itself in a block which is resting on a smooth surface.  After embedding in the block, the nail and the block move together.  At t1 the spring is compressed and the nail is stationary.  At t2 the spring is relaxed and the nail is moving.  At t3 the nail has just embedded itself in the block and the nail and the block are moving together.

Define:

System: spring, nail, block (NOT the wall that the spring is attached to or the smooth surface that the block rest on)

Initial: t1 (everything stationary, spring compressed)

Final: t3 (spring relaxed, nail and block moving together)

Is the system isolated?  Explain.

Is the system closed?  Explain.

question.name: Cylinder, piston, spring
question.questiontext:
A cylinder with a piston and spring inside is filled with a fuel/air mix.  The fuel/air mix undergoes combustion (i.e. it burns) and the expanding gases push on the piston, resulting in the spring being compressed as shown.  The cylinder is clamped to a benchtop so that it does not move (though the spring and piston inside can move).  The cylinder is well oiled so taht friction can be ignored.  Also the gases in the cylinder after combustion are vvery hot, but there has been insufficient time for the piston or cylinder to be heated up by them significantly.

Define:

System: piston, fuel/air mix (spring and cylinder not in system)

Initial: just before combustion (spring is relaxed, piston is stationary)

Final: after combustion (spring is maximally compressed, so piston is stationary again)

Is the system isolated?  Explain.

Is the system closed?  Explain.

question.name: Rocket separation
question.questiontext:
During flight of a typical orbital rocket the first stage is usually discarded when it
runs out of fuel.  It is important that the two stages get pushed apart during separation so that they do not run into each other.  This is most often done with explosive charges which push the two stages apart.  Suppose a rocket is separating.  At the instant when it separates it is travelling horizontally, and it is above the atmosphere, so there is no air drag.

Define:

System: 1st stage of rocket, 2nd stage of rocket, explosives used to separate them.

Initial: Just before separation.

Final: Just after separation.

Is the system isolated?  Explain.

Is the system closed?  Explain.

question.name: Random (Long answer - is this system isolated and/or closed?)
Random (Long answer - is this system isolated and/or closed?)
Low friction cart, collide with rigid post and spring
question.questiontext:
A low friction cart is rolling to the right along a horizontal track.  It collides with a spring mounted to a rigid support.  The cart bounces off of the spring so that after the collision it is going to the left at the same speed it was going before hitting the spring.

Define:

System: cart, spring

Initial: just before cart hits spring

Final: just after cart hits spring

Is the system isolated?  Explain.

Is the system closed?  Explain.

question.name: cart launch and collision - energy bar chart
question.questiontext:
A spring is used to launch a low friction cart.  The cart collides with another cart.  They collide with their "velcro ends" so they stick together.

Use the following definitions:

System: spring, both carts

Initial: just before the cart is launched with the spring (t1 in the diagram)

Final: just after the carts have stuck together (t3 in the diagram)

Drag and drop full, partly full, and empty bars to complete the energy bar chart.  Note: if you want to represent zero then drag an empty bar into that location on the bar chart.

question_hint.hint: \( U_G \) = mgh.  The ball starts with large h and ends with h = 0.
Remember that "final" should mean just *before* the ball hits the ground.  It should be going quite fast at that moment.

If we dropped high density ball from the same height it would be going be much faster than the Nerf ball because there is no air drag.  So, we must conclude that the air drag results in a lower kinetic energy.  Energy can't just disappear so that energy that isn't transformed to K must be transformed to some other form.

question.name: launch clay ball onto ceiling - energy bar chart
question.questiontext:
A spring is used to launch a ball of clay vertically.  The clay ball hits the ceiling and sticks there.

Use the following definitions:

System: spring, Earth, clay ball, ceiling

Initial: just before the clay ball is launched with the spring

Final: just after the clay ball has stuck to the ceiling (ball is stationary)

Drag and drop full, partly full, and empty bars to complete the energy bar chart.  Note: if you want to represent zero then drag an empty bar into that location on the bar chart.

question_hint.hint: \( U_G \) = mgh.  The ball starts with large h and ends with h = 0.
Remember that "final" should mean just *before* the ball hits the ground.  It should be going quite fast at that moment.

If we dropped high density ball from the same height it would be going be much faster than the Nerf ball because there is no air drag.  So, we must conclude that the air drag results in a lower kinetic energy.  Energy can't just disappear so that energy that isn't transformed to K must be transformed to some other form.

question.name: spring inside piston - energy bar chart
question.questiontext:
A cylinder contains a piston, a spring, and a fuel/air mix as shown.  The fuel/air mix burns rapidly and the hot expanding gases push the piston so that it compresses the spring.  This all happens very quickly so the cylinder has not had time to heat up significantly.

Use the following definitions:

System: spring, piston, fuel/air mix

Initial: just before the fuel/air mix starts to burn

Final: the fuel/air mix is burned, the spring is fully compressed and the piston has been brought to rest

Drag and drop full, partly full, and empty bars to complete the energy bar chart.  Note: if you want to represent zero then drag an empty bar into that location on the bar chart.

question_hint.hint: \( U_G \) = mgh.  The ball starts with large h and ends with h = 0.
Remember that "final" should mean just *before* the ball hits the ground.  It should be going quite fast at that moment.

If we dropped high density ball from the same height it would be going be much faster than the Nerf ball because there is no air drag.  So, we must conclude that the air drag results in a lower kinetic energy.  Energy can't just disappear so that energy that isn't transformed to K must be transformed to some other form.

question.name: throwing a ball - energy bar chart
question.questiontext:
You throw a ball in a high arc.

Use the following definitions:

System: ball, Earth, you, surrounding air

Initial: just before you throw the ball

Final: the ball is at its maximum height.

Drag and drop full, partly full, and empty bars to complete the energy bar chart.  Note: if you want to represent zero then drag an empty bar into that location on the bar chart.

question_hint.hint: \( U_G \) = mgh.  The ball starts with large h and ends with h = 0.
Remember that "final" should mean just *before* the ball hits the ground.  It should be going quite fast at that moment.

If we dropped high density ball from the same height it would be going be much faster than the Nerf ball because there is no air drag.  So, we must conclude that the air drag results in a lower kinetic energy.  Energy can't just disappear so that energy that isn't transformed to K must be transformed to some other form.

question_category.name: Interpret K vs. t graphs for collisions

question.name: Interpret K vs. t graph - 1
question.questiontext:
The graph below shows kinetic energy vs. time for a tennis racquet hitting a ball.  It shows K vs. t for the racquet, for the ball, and for the racquet-ball system.

Like many collisions, there is and instant when the two objects are moving with the same velocity.  From the graph we can see that this instant occurs at t =  {#1} ms.

From this graph we can tell that this collision is {#2}.

question.name: Interpret K vs. t graph - 1
question.questiontext: {1:NUMERICAL:=25:0.01#Yes.~30:0.01#No. That is when the two objects have the same kinetic energy. But they wouldn't have the same speed at that instant since they have different inertias.}

answer.feedback: Yes.
No. That is when the two objects have the same kinetic energy. But they wouldn't have the same speed at that instant since they have different inertias.

question.name: Interpret K vs. t graph - 1
question.questiontext: {1:MULTICHOICE:=inelastic#Yes.~elastic#No. If the collision was elastic then the final system kinetic energy would be the same as the initial system kinetic energy.~an explosive separation#No. If this was an explosive separation then the final system kinetic energy would be larger than the initial system kinetic energy.~totally inelastic#No. Notice that the system kinetic energy "recovers" partly in the later parts of the collision. question.questiontext:
The graph below shows kinetic energy vs. time for a collision between two low friction carts.  It shows K vs. t for the cart A, for cart B, and for the system of two carts.

Like many collisions, there is and instant when the two objects are moving with the same velocity.  From the graph we can see that this instant occurs at t =  {#1} ms.

From this graph we can tell that this collision is {#2}.

question.name: Random (Interpret K vs. t graphs for collisions)
CLOZE - Interpret U(x) graph - 1
question.questiontext:
An object moves to the right along the x-axis subject to only a single non-dissipative interaction.  The interaction is described by a potential energy function U(x) which is shown in the graph below.

As the object moves through x = 1 cm it has 3 J of kinetic energy.

As it moves from left to right it will be moving fastest as it passes through x = {#1} cm.

Between x = 1 cm and x = 9 cm it will be moving the slowest as it passes through x = {#2} cm.

As it passes through x = 7 cm the object will have a kinetic energy of {#3} J.

As it passes through x = 5 cm the object's acceleration will be {#4}.

question.name: Compare spring launch with chemical explosive
question.questiontext:
Let's compare two situations.  In one situation two carts start stationary and are pushed apart by a spring.  The spring had an initial amount of stored energy equal to 5 J.

In the second situation we have the same two carts, and they are initially stationary again.  This time they are pushed apart by the explosion of a firecracker.  The firecracker had an initial amount of stored energy equal to 5 J.

Which will be going faster, the carts pushed apart by the spring or the carts pushed apart by the firecracker?

answer.answertext: The carts pushed apart by the spring will be moving faster, because some of the stored energy of the firecracker is converted to thermal energy.
The carts pushed apart by the firecracker will be moving faster because the firecracker must exert a larger force than a spring would.
They will be going at the  same speed because the spring and the firecracker converted the same amount of stored energy.
We can't tell.  We need more information, such as the stiffness of the spring and how strong the force exerted by the firecracker is.
The carts pushed apart by the  firecracker will be going  faster because thermal energy will be converted to kinetic energy in this process.

question.name: Nerf ball thrown up
question.questiontext:
A low density foam ball is thrown straight up.  Because the ball is low density air drag is not negligible.

Compare the speed of the ball just after it leaves the person's hand (v1 in the diagram) with the speed later when the ball returns to the same height (v3 in the diagram).

answer.answertext: v3 is less than v1 because drag by the air dissipates some of the energy.
v3 is equal to v1 because a projectile is always at the same speed at any two times when it is at the same height.
v3 is equal to v1 and both must be 9.8 m/s because the ball is in freefall.
v3 is greater than v1 because it is slowing down just after it leaves the person's hand but it is speeding up by the time it returns to the same height.
v3 is equal to v1 because the ball moves with constant velocity.
