question.name: FBD for ruptured gas cylinder
question.questiontext:
A 4.0 kg high pressure vessel is resting on the ground. A leak has developed in the wall so that high pressure gas is ejected in a jet angled up and left as shown. This results in a 50 N "thrust" force exerted on the cylinder and the cylinder starts sliding to the right, accelerating as shown. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the vessel and the floor is 0.60.

Which of the following is the most correct free body diagram for the cylinder?

answer.feedback: Yes.
This FBD should be for the vessel so all forces appearing on it should be forces *on* the vessel.  You have included a force that is exerted *by* the vessel.
No.  Which way does the vessel exert a force on the gases?  Therefore, what does Newton's 3rd Law tell us about which way the gases should exert a force on the vessel?

No.  Which way does the vessel exert a force on the gases?  Therefore, what does Newton's 3rd Law tell us about which way the gases should exert a force on the vessel?  Also, if  the vessel is sliding why would the floor exert a force of static friction?

No.  What is the agent for that F_thrust?  Also, this FBD should be for the vessel so all forces appearing on it should be forces *on* the vessel.  You have included a force that is exerted *by* the vessel.

question_hint.hint: See feedback on your answer, above.  Think about what agents are able to exert forces  on the vessel.

See feedback on your answer, above.  Aside from  agents, also think about Newton's 3rd Law.  Which way does the vessel exert a  force on the escaping gases?  Therefore, which way do the gases exert a force on the vessel?

question.name: Gas cylinder - equation of motion
question.questiontext:
The gas cylinder is sliding to the right because it is being propelled by the jet of  escaping gases.

The correct free body diagram  for the vessel looks like this:

 

Drag and drop the correct right and left sides to complete the x- and y-components of the equation of motion for the vessel.

question_hint.hint: Remember that you are just "translating" the FBD into the equation.
Careful of signs.
Careful of trigonometry, breaking up components.

question.name: Ruptured cylinder - friction force (final answer)
question.questiontext:
A 4.0 kg high pressure vessel is resting on the ground. A leak has developed in the wall so that high pressure gas is ejected in a jet angled up and left as shown. This results in a 50 N "thrust" force exerted on the cylinder and the cylinder starts sliding to the right, accelerating as shown. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the vessel and the floor is 0.60.

You should already have the equations of motion written down.  Find the strength of the friction force acting on the vessel.

Use g = 10 m/s2 in your calculation.  Don't forget to include units in your final answer.

answer.feedback: Yup.
Yes.  But you used g = 9.8 m/s2.  Lucky for you, I input that into the question as one of the correct options.  But you should really follow instructions.  It makes everything so much easier!

question_hint.hint: Don't forget to work in mks (meters, kilograms, seconds) units.
Remember that g is positive by definition.
Make sure your calculator is in degree mode.

question.name: cart launch
question.questiontext: Consider a low-friction cart with a spring attached to it. Let our system be the spring and cart. Initially the cart is held stationary with the spring compressed against a rigid wall. The cart is released so that the spring uncompresses. Let the final time be a moment very shortly after the spring is no longer in contact with the wall. This system, or variants of it, have been discussed in the video lectures and during class, so you should understand that it is (approximately) closed, but not isolated.

question_hint.hint: When the spring is compressed, what kind of energy is stored in it?
After launch the cart-spring combination is moving.  So what kind of energy does the system have?
Deformation of a spring is a reversible process.  This tells you about one kind of energy that the system *won't* gain during this process.

question.name: U_i of system
question.questiontext: Suppose the cart-spring combination has inertia, 400 g.  After leaving the wall, the cart-spring combination moves with speed 50 .0 cm/s. What was the initial potential energy of the system?

answer.feedback: Yup.

You've got the right idea but you are not being careful of units.  Your answer is of the order of magnitude that we would expect for a car driving down a highway.  Does this make sense for a low-friction cart that you could easily pick up in your hand, moving at a speed slower than a typical walking pace?

Presumably you want an answer in Joules.  To get that you need to work in mks (meters, kilograms, seconds) units.

question_hint.hint: Don't forget to work in mks (meters, kilograms, seconds) units.
Remember that g is positive by definition.

question.name: Double potential energy
question.questiontext:
Suppose we recompress the spring so that we have doubled the initial potential energy of the system.  The cart is then released again.

Compared to the previous release of the cart and spring, this should result in the final kinetic energy of the system being multiplied by{#1} the final kinetic energy of the system.

Compared to the previous release of the cart and spring, this should result in the final speed of the cart-spring combination being multiplied by {#2}

So doubling the available potential energy should certainly change the final K.~4#No. All of the spring potential energy gets converted to kinetic energy when the cart is released. So there is a simple relationship between U_Si and K_f.~1/2#No. All of the spring potential energy gets converted to kinetic energy when the cart is released. So there is a simple relationship between U_Si and K_f.~the square root of 2#No. All of the spring potential energy gets converted to kinetic energy when the cart is released. So there is a simple relationship between U_Si and K_f}

No. All of the spring potential energy gets converted to kinetic energy when the cart is released. So doubling the available potential energy should certainly change the final K.
No. All of the spring potential energy gets converted to kinetic energy when the cart is released. So there is a simple relationship between U_Si and K_f.
No. All of the spring potential energy gets converted to kinetic energy when the cart is released. So there is a simple relationship between U_Si and K_f.
No. All of the spring potential energy gets converted to kinetic energy when the cart is released. So there is a simple relationship between U_Si and K_f

question_category.name: In-class problem - mass pushed against spring

question.name: mass pushed against spring - energy bar chart
question.questiontext:
A spring is to be compressed with a mass pushed against it but it is in an awkward place so we can't push along the line of the spring. All surfaces are well oiled so friction is negligible. The mass is placed against the spring as shown, with the spring relaxed. A constant force of magnitude, F, is exerted on the mass at an angle, θ, as shown in the diagram. A short time later the spring has compressed by some distance, Dx, and the mass is moving at some speed v.

Use the following definitions:

System: spring, mass (whetever is exerting the force, F, is not in the system)

Initial: just before the force, F, starts to  be applied

Final: when the mass has moved a distance, Δx, as shown in the diagram

Drag and drop full, partly full, and empty bars to complete the energy bar chart.  Note: if you want to represent zero then drag an empty bar into that location on the bar chart.  Also note that the spot in the chart for work gives you the option of positive, negative, or zero work

question_hint.hint: Is the system closed?  Is  there an external force doing work?  Does that force have a component in the direction of motion?
Note in the description that at the final time the mass is moving and the spring is compressed.
Nothing moves up or down, and friction is negligible.

question.name: Mass pushed against spring - conservation equation
question.questiontext:
A spring, of stiffness k, is to be compressed with a mass, M, pushed against it but it is in an awkward place so we can't push along the line of the spring. All surfaces are well oiled so friction is negligible. The mass is placed against the spring as shown, with the spring relaxed. A constant force of magnitude, F, is exerted on the mass at an angle, θ, as shown in the diagram. A short time later the spring has compressed by some distance, Δx, and the mass is moving at some speed v.

 

Use the following definitions:

System: spring, mass (whetever is exerting the force, F, is not in the system)

Initial: just before the force, F, starts to  be applied

Final: when the mass has moved a distance, Δx, as shown in the diagram

Drag and drop the mathematical expressions to construct the conservation of energy equation which would allow us to find the final speed of the mass.

question_hint.hint: Remember that you are just "translating" the bar chart into the equation.  Each bar in the bar chart should correspond with a term in the equation.

If we know that some "pool" of energy is zero at some time then there is no point in including that in the equation.  It is just something we should be able to cross out right away and make our equation nice and simple.
I have included some things that can't be correct because they don't  have units of energy.  Don't get fished in by those wrong answers.

question_category.name: In-class problem - roller coaster going up

question.name: FBD of roller coaster car
question.questiontext:
A roller coaster is going through a loop as shown.

At the instant we are interested in the roller coaster car is going straight up at a speed of 15 m/s. The loop can be thought of as a circle of radius of 7.0 m. Friction is negligible. Note: a roller coaster has no engine. It moves simply because it started from some large initial height.

Which of the following is the most correct free body diagram for the roller coaster and rider at the time shown?  Note that each option is accompanied by a key showing what the agent/target symbols represent.

answer.answertext: where: r - roller coaster, E - Earth, t - track
answer.feedback: Yup.

answer.answertext: where: r - roller coaster, E - Earth, t - track, C - centripetal
answer.feedback: No.  "Centripetal" is not a possible agent.  It is not a physical object.  So any force labelled with that as its agent almost certainly doesn't really exist.

answer.answertext: where: r - roller coaster, E - Earth, t - track, C - centrifugal
answer.feedback: No.  "Centrifugal" is not a possible agent.  It is not a physical object.  So any force labelled with that as its agent almost certainly doesn't really exist.  Also, the roller coaster is moving in a circular path.  The acceleration cannot be zero because the velocity is changing direction.

answer.answertext: where: r - roller coaster, E - Earth, t - track, C - centrifugal
answer.feedback: No.  "Centrifugal" is not a possible agent.  It is not a physical object.  So any force labelled with that as its agent almost certainly doesn't really exist.  Also, the roller coaster is moving in a circular path.  For an object to move in a curve the acceleration must have a component towards the centre of the curve.

answer.answertext: where: r - roller coaster, E - Earth, t - track, C - centripetal
answer.feedback: No.  "Centripetal" is not a possible agent.  It is not a physical object.  So any force labelled with that as its agent almost certainly doesn't really exist.  Also, as the roller coaster is going up, kinetic energy is being converted to gravitational potential energy, so shouldn't the roller coaster be slowing down?

answer.answertext: where: r - roller coaster, E - Earth, t - track, P - centripetal, F - centrifugal
answer.feedback: No.  "Centripetal" and "Centrifugal" are not possible agents.  They are not physical objects.  So any force labelled those as  the agents almost certainly don't really exist.  Also, the roller coaster is moving in a circular path.  So its acceleration can't be zero since the velocity is changing direction.

question_hint.hint: No.  See the specific feedback provided with the  answer  that you chose.
No.  See the specific feedback provided with the  answer  that you chose.

question.name: Roller coaster - equation of motion
question.questiontext:
At the instant we are interested in the roller coaster car is going straight up at a speed of 15 m/s. The loop can be thought of as a circle of radius of 7.0 m. Friction is negligible.

The correct free body diagram  for the roller coaster and rider looks like this:

 

Drag and drop the correct right and left sides to complete the x- and y-components of the equation of motion for the roller coaster and rider.  Use the axes shown with the free body diagram.

Careful of signs.  Make sure you are using the axes shown with the FBD.
One of the two axes is pointing radially.  That tells you a more useful way to write that component of the acceleration.

Consider this Fx vs. x graph for some object moving  along the x-axis.  The force shown in this graph is the only force acting on the object.

question.name: What forces do work - 1
question.questiontext:
A person picks up a ball of clay that is resting on the floor.  Then they drop it from rest.  It hits the floor and sticks, coming quickly to rest.  The person does not move their feet during this whole process - they just crouch down, pick up the ball and stand up.   Then they drop the ball.  Assume:

Initial: Just before the person picks up the ball of clay.  Ball of clay is at rest, on the floor.

Final: just after the ball hits the floor.  Ball of clay is at rest, stuck to the floor.

System: Ball of clay, floor.

What forces do work on the system?  Choose all that apply.

answer.answertext: A force of gravity exerted by the Earth on the ball.
answer.feedback: Yes.  The Earth is not in the system, so gravity is an external force.

answer.answertext: A contact force exerted by the person on the ball.
answer.feedback: Yes.  The person is not in the system, so the force that the person exerts on the ball is an external force.

answer.answertext: A contact force exerted by the floor on the ball.
answer.feedback: No.  First of all, the point of application of this force does not move.  Secondly, and more importantly, the ball and floor are both in the system.  Internal forces cannot do work on the system.

answer.answertext: A contact force exerted by the ball on the floor.
answer.feedback: No.  First of all, the point of application of this force does not move.  Secondly, and more importantly, the ball and floor are both in the system.  Internal forces cannot do work on the system.

answer.answertext: A contact force exerted by the ball's velocity on the ball.
answer.feedback: "The ball's velocity" is not an agent.  This force cannot exist.

answer.answertext: A contact force exerted by the floor on the person.
answer.feedback: This is a force on an object outside the system.

answer.answertext: The gravitational potential energy of the ball.

question.name: What forces do work - 2
question.questiontext:
A block is supported on a spring, which is compressed.  A person pulls up on the block so that the block raises and the spring becomes less compressed  Assume:

Initial: Just before the person starts pulling up on the block.  The block is stationary.  The spring is compressed.

Final: The person has lifted the block.  The block is stationary.  The spring is still compressed, but less compressed than it was.

System: Block and spring.

What forces do work on the system?  Choose all that apply.

answer.answertext: A force of gravity exerted by the Earth on the block.
answer.feedback: Yes.  The Earth is not in the system, so gravity is an external force.

answer.answertext: A contact force exerted by the person on the block.
answer.feedback: Yes.  The person is not in the system, so the force that the person exerts on the block is an external force.

answer.answertext: A contact force exerted by the floor on the spring.
answer.feedback: No.  The point of application of this force does not move.

answer.answertext: A contact force exerted by the spring on the block.
answer.feedback: No.  The block and spring are both in the system.  Internal forces cannot do work on the system.
No.  That isn't a force.

answer.answertext: A contact force exerted by the floor on the person.
answer.feedback: No.  This is a force on an object outside the system.

answer.answertext: The gravitational potential energy of the block.
answer.feedback: No.  That isn't a force.

answer.answertext: A contact force that the block exerts on the person.
answer.feedback: No.  That is a force on an object outside the system.

question.name: What forces do work - 3
question.questiontext:
A box is being pulled down a slope by a rope.  The box is speeding up.  Assume:

Initial: Box is moving down the slope.

Final: Box is farther down the slope, moving faster.

System: Box, slope.

What forces do work on the system?  Choose all that apply.

answer.answertext: A force of gravity exerted by the Earth on the box.
answer.feedback: Yes.  The Earth is not in the system, so gravity is an external force.

answer.answertext: A contact force exerted by the rope on the box.
answer.feedback: Yes.  The rope is not in the system, so the force that the rope exerts on the box is an external force.

answer.answertext: A friction force exerted by the surface on the box.
answer.feedback: No.  The surface and the box are both in the system.  Internal forces cannot do work on the system.

answer.answertext: A perpendicular force exerted by the surface on the box.
answer.feedback: No.  First of all the perpendicular force is perpendicular to the motion, so it does no work.  Secondly, and more importantly, the box and the surface are both in the system.  Internal forces cannot do work on a system.
No.  That isn't a force.

answer.answertext: A contact force exerted by the box on the rope.
answer.feedback: No.  This is a force on an object outside the system.

answer.answertext: The gravitational potential energy of the box.
answer.feedback: No.  That isn't a force.

answer.answertext: A contact force exerted by the box's velocity on the box (the force of motion).
answer.feedback: No.  The velocity of the box is not an agent.  Only physical objects can exert forces.  This force does not exist.

question.name: Box on conveyor belt, speeding up

A box is on a conveyor belt.  The conveyor belt is going to the right, and speeding up.  The box does not slip.

Help the student by identifying what each of these forces must be, or whether they even exist at all.

match.answertext: Static friction, exerted by the conveyor belt
Perpendicular force, exerted by the belt
There is no agent that could exert this force. It doesn't exist.

question.name: Car speeding up, going up hill
question.questiontext:
A car is going up a hill, and speeding up as it does.  The car's tires are not slipping.  Air drag and rolling friction are negligible.

A student thinking about this situation has started to draw a free body diagram for the car.  So far this may be correct.  Or maybe it isn't.

Help the student by identifying what each of these forces must be, or whether they even exist at all.

match.questiontext: The force to the right and slightly up is
match.answertext: Static friction, exerted by the road

match.questiontext: The force up and slightly to the left is
match.answertext: Perpendicular force, exerted by the road

match.questiontext: The force to the left and slightly down is
match.answertext: There is no agent that could exert this force. It doesn't exist.
The applied force, exerted by the engine of the car
Kinetic friction, exerted by the road

question.name: Airplane speeding up going down the runway
question.questiontext:
An airplane is going right on the runway and speeding up.  It is going quite fast so drag cannot be ignored.  However, rolling friction is negligible.

A student thinking about this situation has started to draw a free body diagram for the car.  So far this may be correct.  Or maybe it isn't.

Help the student by identifying what each of these forces must be, or whether they even exist at all.

match.answertext: Perpendicular force, exerted by the runway
The applied force, exerted by the engine of the plane
Kinetic friction, exerted by the runway
Static friction, exerted by the runway
Thrust, exerted by the engine of the plane

question.name: y at t = 0
question.questiontext:
In the assignment question you have been given this sequence of frames of video, showing a box being raised and lowered by a winch.

The box is 20 cm tall.  One of the first issues we need to think about, any time we analyze any motion, is how to set our axes.  There is no right or wrong way to choose axes, but some choices can be more convenient than others.  For the moment let's use the choice of xy-axes shown below, using the centre of the box as the "location of the box".  In a later question we will look at the effect of making different choices for the xy-axes.

The diagram is showing that the origin is at the height of the middle of the winch.  The "X" with a circle around it is indicating that we are choosing to track the location of the centre of the box, and let its position represent the position of the whole box.

With these choices, what is the value of y (the y-component of position for the box) during frame 0?

answer.feedback: Yes.

No.  By definition y = 0 at the origin (or anywhere along the x-axis).  The centre of the box is not at the origin and we are choosing to define the location of the box's centre as the location of the box as a whole.

That is almost correct.  But, notice that the y-axis points up.  By convention that means that things above the origin are at positive values of y, and things below the origin are at negative values of y.

question.name: t axis (copy)
question.questiontext:
Let's start working on how we would draw a y vs. t graph.  We will focus on the first few frames (you will draw  the rest yourself later), and we will start by thinking about the time axis.

The box is 20 cm tall.  For the moment let's use the choice of xy-axes shown below, and using the centre of the box as the "location of the box".  In a later question we will look at the effect of making different choices for the xy-axes.

Here is the picture of the motion again.

The relevant facts and choices that you need to know for constructing the time axis on the x vs. t graph are:

  • The video was shot at 10 frames per second. 
  • We are choosing to set t = 0 at the instant of frame 0 in the video.  

Which of the graphs below uses a correct time axis, consistent with the details given above?

answer.feedback: Yes.

No.  We already know that during frame 0 we should have y = -90 cm, and we have chosen to set that moment to correspond with t = 0.  That is not what this graph is showing.  Also, there should be 10 frames per second.  This is showing 1 frame per second.
No.  There should be 10 frames per second.  This is showing 1 frame per second.
No.  We already know that with this choice of axes we should have y = -90 cm during frame 0, which we have set to correspond to t = 0.  That is not what this graph is showing.
No.  There should be 10 frames per second.  This is showing 5 frames per second.

No.  There should be 10 frames per second.  This is showing 5 frames per second.  Also, we already knew that during frame 0 we should have y = -90 cm.  We have set frame 0 to correspond  with t = 0.  That's not what this graph is showing.

question.name: Match choice of axes with y vs. t graph (copy)
question.questiontext:
Now let's think about the consequences of different choices for our xy-axes.

The box is 20 cm tall and the video was shot at 10 frames per second.  Below are several choices of axes, each shown superimposed over frame 0 of the video.  As shown, in each case we are using the center of the box as the reference point for determining the position of the box.

Below are several y vs. t graphs.  Match the choices of axes in the diagrams above with the appropriate y vs. t graphs.  Again, these are only showing the first few frames.

matchoptions.partiallycorrectfeedback: You have some of the graphs matched to the correct axes, but not all of them.

question_hint.hint: There are many ways to figure this out, and you are probably using  some of them.  One thing to realize is that the direction that the y-axis points, by convention, tells you which way the "positive y-direction" is.  So use the axes definitions to decide which side of the origin is the positive y side and which is the negative y side.
Another thing to notice is that once you know which side is the positive y side, noticing what the value of y at t = 0 should be able to tell you which graph matches which axes.

question_category.name: position as function of time for constant velocity motion

question.name: 2D position as function of time - 1
question.questiontext:
An object moves along a path as shown in the diagram.  Between  \( t_a = 3 \) s and \( t_b = 5 \) s it moves with a constant velocity of \( \vec{v} = 3 \hat{i} -5 \hat{j} \) m/s.  Before \( t_a \) and after \( t_b \) its motion is more complicated.

At \( t_a \) it passes through \( \vec{r}_a = -5 \hat{i} \) m.

The x-component of position as a function of time for this object, between \(t_a \) and \( t_b \) is:

{#1}.

The y-component of position as a function of time for this object, between \(t_a \) and \( t_b \) is:

 {#2}.
